Text:
User: Miro is easy to use, and has key features that assist in my diagramming. The template I use counts the number of items within a 'cell', and this helps me identify when I'm assigning too many tasks to a given week.
User: Miro has several templates and features that make it unique. This diversity supports different uses, and I can both manage projects and gather feedback through other assets
User: It lacks integration with other services (e.g. Notion), and it also lacks screen reading capabilities for (visual) accessibility. The lack of accessibility is the one thing keeping my organization from using it more widespread.
Summary: Users find Miro easy to use with helpful features for diagramming and appreciate its diverse templates that support various use cases, including project management and feedback gathering. However, they mention the lack of integration with other services like Notion and the absence of screen reading capabilities for visual accessibility, which prevents their organization from adopting it more widely.

Text:
User: üöÄ How to turn an ‚Äûalmost perfect‚Äù UI/UX to ‚Äûperfect‚Äù.
Using <STRICT_LINK> as a perfect example (created by @cnnr_cllhn) <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more ‚Äûconcise‚Äù adjective without using ‚Äûvery‚Äù. Example: very rich = affluent.
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that .It's straight to the point (just like the Google Search homepage). So what's the problem? <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn ‚ùå There are 3 main flaws:
1. Site feels messy
2. Design lacks consistency
3. Elements feel a little too cramped
We'll approach it ‚Äûvia negativa‚Äù style: by removing stuff rather than adding.
üë©üé® Let's work on that that using @figma
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 1Ô∏è‚É£: Decluttering üßπ
The most important step would be to remove the clutter ‚Äì the annoying newsletter popup, the newsletter section and the newsletter banner. We'll get back to it later.
This has already made a difference. The interface looks significantly cleaner. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user discussed how to improve the UI/UX of a website called LoseTheVery, which helps find concise adjectives. They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

Text: User: As a medical student, Notion has huge potential to organize my life. It has notes, calendar, tracker, and collaborative capabilities. I‚Äôm also enjoying the AI integration. I REALLY REALLY wish Notion would include the ability to hand write on iPad. I can guarantee the use of Notion by students would absolutely skyrocket. The other notes options all lack something, and if Notion allowed handwriting over PDF / lecture slides, Goodnotes, onenote and notability would all go out of business.
Summary: User finds Notion to be a useful tool for organizing their life as a medical student, especially appreciating its AI integration and collaborative capabilities. They suggest adding handwriting support for iPad and other note-taking apps, as well as adding more features to the existing options.

Summary: Users appreciate Figma's ease of use and custom plugins for designing different layouts, but they wish for more breakpoint options and full support for tokens and modes. Text:
User: It's a highly collaborative tool that doesn't feel formal; it's not a deck, but can be used to communicate the same information, and there are lots of fun stickers to spice up casual work sessions.
User: It's awesome that FigJam is built in with Figma and it's so highly collaborative. No need for a separate ecosystem. 
 
Love these product features: timer, spotlighting users to see their view of the screen, stickers, auto-align tools and guides, variety of community templates available.
User: Mindmaps are more difficult compared to competitors (ie, Miro). It's difficult to connect words into a cohesive web. 
 
When mood boarding and importing a bunch of images, it doesn't auto-resize photos into a neat masonry layout with consistent sizing like competitors (ie, Pinterest and InVision). 
 
Even though FigJam isn't for video calling, because it's so collaborative, I wish there was a chat feature like other online video call apps.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam's integration with Figma, its collaborative nature, and features like timers, spotlighting, stickers, auto-align tools, and community templates. However, they find mindmaps more challenging compared to competitors and wish for improvements in image resizing and a chat feature for better collaboration.

Text:
User: Miro is solving many problems. Giving me a place to collaborate with others in a hybrid environment along with providing all the templates for a variety of work in one place allows me to use the tool to its fullest potential.
User: I like the dynamic templates for a variety of projects, screen sizing, ability to collaborate with peers in person or virtually, along with the ease of personalization.
User: There aren't too many downsides or dislikes that I've found. Perhaps the most annoying thing is the struggles that come from people working on the same page, but overall that can be mitigated by locking items so they don't get changed.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its collaboration features in a hybrid environment, variety of dynamic templates, and ease of personalization. However, they find it challenging when multiple people work on the same page, which can be mitigated by locking items to prevent changes.

Text:
User: Planning of projects/programs (both short (weeks/months) and long (3+ years). Its interface also makes it very easy to generate flowcharts and mindmaps to identify and clearly document dependencies and sequence of deliverables.
User: How user-friendly it is. I have used other programs in the past (MS Project, Visio, etc.) but the interface of Miro is far beyond other tools. The forums and FAQ websites are also very useful. I have been able to answer most of my questions by looking things up on the forums.
User: Some of the features could be improved. For instance, enabling compatibility with Microsoft Excell, and being able to lock rows and columns in tables (this can be solved with the Kanban for rows but not columns)
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's simplicity, templates, real-time collaboration, and ample workspace for brainstorming and problem-solving. However, they feel that Miro offers more tools and integration options, suggesting that easy access of Miro use could be beneficial

Text:
User: Our Design team needed a tool that is easy to use and with good documentation and training available. This tool also needed to be able to share with anyone in the company. By having organization in the tool (teams, pages, etc.) , it also makes it easy to find what is needed.
User: An easy-to-use tool that allows Design to easily design needed user journeys and feature mocks. They can then easily share with their team(s) and make changes on the fly when needed. The UI is fairly intuitive as well.
User: Maybe it's just me but I found it a bit hard to learn the controls to navigate the tool as someone new to it. Took me longer than I like to admit to know how to zoom in and move around properly. This is likely a me issue more than a UI issue but I wanted to mention it.
Summary: The design team finds Figma easy to use, with good documentation and training available, allowing them to design user journeys and feature mocks efficiently. The tool's organization and sharing capabilities are appreciated. However, one user found it challenging to learn the controls for navigation and zooming, suggesting a potential improvement in user onboarding.

Sorry to hear you‚Äôre having trouble. This does seem like a bug, as it‚Äôs not expected behavior.
Is this happening both in browser and using the desktop app? What troubleshooting steps have you tried so far?
logging out and back in
clearing your browser/desktop app‚Äôs cache
un-installing and re-installing the desktop app
We‚Äôll pass this info along to our team to try to reproduce and fix!
User: Tried everything stated above, but still no luck.
Even to this day, after I click the field, I constantly need either to remove the focus from the field or press a random key on the keyboard before Figma enables me to enter the value manually in the field. Extremely annoying.
Please let me know is there anything else i can provide you with.
User: Sorry to hear that! Please submit a bug report to our support team directly via the form here: <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user is experiencing an annoying issue in Figma where they have to press a random numeric key or remove focus from a field before being able to enter a value manually. They have tried troubleshooting steps such as logging out and back in, clearing cache, and reinstalling the desktop app, but the issue persists. They are advised to submit a bug report to the support team.

User: In our SaaS product, we use custom web fonts for both our main typography as well as an icon font. It would be great to use those in Figma without having to convert, download, and install the fonts as local fonts. This is particularly painful for our icon font.
I want to be able to have these available in Figma as selectable fonts that update as our development team pushes updates to production, instead of trying to coordinate Figma updates after each deployment.
Can we set our account to use webfonts beyond the Google fonts?
Summary: The user wants to use custom web fonts and icon fonts in Figma without converting, downloading, and installing them as local fonts. They would like these fonts to be available in Figma and update automatically as their development team pushes updates to production, instead of coordinating Figma updates after each deployment. They are asking if it's possible to use webfonts beyond Google fonts in their account.

Text:
User: I am working on a large project across multiple teams in different locations. Miro has helped us collaborate and work jointly on material that otherwise would have been more challenging to do in other tools. This is a quick, real time way of working with others, even when you're not in the same room.
User: Miro is a fantastic tool that has been invaluable in helping my remote team collaborate and flesh out ideas. It's a great help when running workshops to hold content and allow all attendees to add in material and notes.
User: There can be a tendency from time to time to accidentally move windows/boxes on the whiteboards, particularly when working with colleagues that have less experience with Miro. However, this can be remedied with a quick CTRL Z or locking the windows.
Summary: The user praises Miro for its ability to facilitate collaboration and work across multiple teams, especially in remote locations. They also mention the tool's usefulness in workshops, allowing all attendees to contribute and add notes. The user also mentions the occasional issue with accidentally moving windows/boxes on the whiteboards, which can be remedied with a quick CTRL Z or locking the windows.

Text:
User: Another problem that Miro solves is the challenge of sharing complex ideas in a simple way. Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes make it easy to share ideas visually, which can be especially helpful for projects that require a lot of detail or complexity. This has allowed me to communicate my ideas more effectively with my team members, resulting in better collaboration and a more efficient workflow.
User: I have found Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams. One of the things I like best about Miro is how easy it is to use. The interface is intuitive and user-friendly, making it simple to get started even for those who are not particularly tech-savvy. 
The real-time collaboration features in Miro are also incredibly helpful. Multiple team members can work on a board simultaneously, which helps to streamline the collaborative process and ensure that everyone is on the same page. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features, such as templates, sticky notes, and diagrams, are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects.
User: One thing that I have found to be a drawback of Miro is its pricing structure. While the platform offers a free plan, its more advanced features are only available with paid plans, which may be expensive for smaller teams or individuals. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users, and it may take some time to learn how to use everything effectively. However, Miro's support resources, including video tutorials and a user community, are quite helpful in getting up to speed quickly.
Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

Text: User: It's one of the apps that have really good features and is well used, but it also takes a lot of lag, and there are too many errors in the middle. Surely the app logo that comes up at the beginning asks you to reconnect to the Internet even though Wi-Fi is connected? That's all it comes out and I can't switch screens.. I think it would be a perfect app if you could solve something like this.. I really like the function itself. I use it really well when planning and recording things.
Summary: User finds the app useful and well-designed, but has issues with lag and errors, especially when switching between screens. They suggest improving the app's connectivity and functionality, as well as fixing the logo issue.

Text:
User: It has made virtual events much more interesting and interactive for our participants, and has made working remotely easier (people can draw connections, group items, etc. like on a flip chart, white board, or with post-its but don't need to be in the same room together).
User: It's flexible - you can really do almost anything you want with it, it's not too hard to learn, and it makes working remotely and hosting virtual events much easier and more engaging.
User: It can make less tech-savvy people feel a bit isolated or left behind in meetings. It might be nice to have a very simple/obvious chat option in Miro where folks can suggest additions if they struggle to add a post-it (which happens).
Summary: The user finds the virtual event tool interesting and interactive, making remote working easier and more engaging. They appreciate its flexibility and ease of use, but mention that it might be difficult for less tech-savvy participants to participate in meetings. They suggest adding a simple chat option in Miro to allow people to suggest additions.

Text:

Summary: User finds the app useful for summarizing thoughts and information on a daily basis, but finds the service difficult to use due to its many functions and bugs. They suggest improving the ability to delete a single note and making it easier to delete multiple notes within 2 taps.

Text:
User: It seems like Figma is cursed with component instances not updating properly when there‚Äôs some color change in main components 
I‚Äôve run into issues like this before. Thanks to this community, I was able to fix them temporarily‚Äîbut now there‚Äôs yet another weird bug happening.
I did a very short video showing the problem: Dropbox Capture
tl;dr: If I make any color change in an icon used in a main component (in a library), the change is not carried over to the component instances (in other files)‚Ä¶ unless I change the instance to a different variant and then revert it back to its original form.
Watch the video for a real tl;dr 
User: This is a problem I am also experiencing.
Summary: Users are experiencing issues with Figma, where component instances do not update properly when there's a color change in main components. This issue can be temporarily fixed by changing the instance to a different variant and then reverting it back to its original form.

Text:
User: We benefit from solving process issues.. mapping current processes, generating ideas and reviewing target state processes. This has helped us visualise the problems regardless of region without having to be there personally.
User: Very user friendly. Not sure how I would have survived without this during the pandemic.. Since then, it has become a part of our daily work. We use this to collaborate between teams.. Share ideas, discuss and review ideas..
User: I find the licensing to be very tedious. My organisation has provisioned limited licenses.. so the others cannot edit the boards when they come to collaborate as they do not have licenses. So we are forced to use personal email accounts to create a free version of the board to collaborate and later transfer to paid version to use all the rich features.. 
 
This is very tedious and needs to be reviewed..
Summary: Users find Figma beneficial for solving process issues, generating ideas, and collaborating between teams, especially during the pandemic. However, they find the licensing process tedious, as limited licenses restrict collaboration, forcing them to use personal email accounts for free versions and later transfer to paid versions to access all features.

Text:
User: Hi all,
After the most recent update of Figma - Pushed a couple of days ago, prototypes using Figma‚Äôs nested component prototyping have been affected. This has been cross checked on web links / alternative machines.
This has new overwrites that aren‚Äôt included and are causing very concerning issues, especially on components that use auto layouts. This, ultimately, means if we hadn‚Äôt complete a round of user testing a couple of weeks prior we would have some serious issues.
Is anyone else getting anything similar?
Thanks,
Alex
User: I‚Äôve reported this issue a week ago, still haven‚Äôt heard from Figma. I‚Äôve send the form to the support team and link as @dvaliao said so, and nothing‚Ä¶
User: Hey @Adriana_DAguiar,
Sorry to hear this! We don‚Äôt see any tickets in our system associated with the email address associated with your Forum account. Did you use another email? Do you have a ticket number? Once we locate your ticket, we can try to escalate it to the right team.
User: Hello, I did fill the form as you said and shared the file with the support team. I‚Äôll do it again if it‚Äôs need it
User: That‚Äôs odd. Thank you for letting us know. We can now see your recent ticket #738343, and someone from our Technical Quality team will reply to you soon!
User: I‚Äôm in contact with the support team, thanks
Summary: Users are experiencing issues with Figma's nested component prototyping after a recent update, particularly with auto layouts. The problem has been reported to the support team, and they are now in contact with the user.

User: Our organization is working on many new priorities, and Miro is helping to organize those initiatives across our team. Including Miro has allowed our team to see everything we are working on and all aspects of each priority.
User: Miro is a very robust place for brainstorming. You can Create teams with access to specific boards and make a board available for everyone. There are a lot of templates to help gather your thoughts efficiently and productively. However, my favorite aspect about Miro is the ability to collaborate.
User: The only thing I dislike about Miro is the ability to collaborate outside your team. You can only share a board with those entered as team members, which you must pay for. I would appreciate the ability to add outside folks to different boards.
Summary: Users find Miro helpful in organizing their team's priorities and appreciate its robust brainstorming features, including various templates and collaboration options. However, they dislike the limitation of collaborating only with team members and wish to include external collaborators on specific boards.

Text: User: Don‚Äôt subscribe through an in app purchase. Their product naming is misleading. The Personal Pro is their free offering with limited ai requests (20) but through an in app purchase they will gladly sell you the same product for a $47 annual subscription. Just like the free product it stops working at 20 ai requests. I‚Äôd say that this product without the ai feature is crap. You can do better with any number of free products on the market. Google docs, etc. And the product without the ai is free anyways so why offer an ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù link when all you are doing is paying for something they offer for free. I‚Äôm angry but glad I subscribed through Apple- there is a chance I can get a refund. The ai is pretty good but I am wary at the shady deal they tried to pull over me. Who know who else made the same mistake?
Summary: User is unhappy with the product name and misleading subscription pricing, as the free version is limited to 20 requests and stops working after 20. They also mention that the ai feature is not as good as other free products, and the upgrade link is misleading. They are considering a refund and are wary of other users making the same mistake.

The use cases for Miro are endless whether you are in the Project, Product, or Engineering space, there are templates and activities at your fingertips aimed at collaboration.
User: Sometimes connecting shapes together is buggy and more difficult than it should be. I also wish there was a better way to connect Miro into powerpoint or another exported solution.

User: It has helped us to execute our duties from anywhere remotely. This has made the collaboration between us to be more effective and efficient.
User: Miro offers a better and a great platform to work in especially in the Morden market. It centralises every file that I make,helping me to see all that I did at a glance. The fact that inviting others to collaborate is very simple and this has made me to involve my clients or colleagues, it has given tremendous results. The numerous and amazing templates on the dashboard gives me ideas and structure to my research. Things that I used to do on paper, or excel and other programs, I now do them on this application. 
The application's dashboard in real time let's us stay connected and I like that in graphic form. You can as well tag people with certain action items on your group.
User: Though its slightly expensive application,it's really worth it.
Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
User: @JiriJerabek @browsercompany Great question. Not right now, but this feature for link routing by Space is coming in a couple weeks üëÄ
Can't wait to hear what you think!
Summary: User is excited about the new features in the latest version of BrowserCO, including the split view and Easel, and is looking forward to becoming an Arc power user.

Text:
User: Up your gradient game! 
Learn how to create this folded gradient effect with @figma, in just a few easy steps ‚Äî no plugins needed.
Ready? Let‚Äôs dive in üëá
#sponsored <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 1
Create a new artboard and add a rectangle with a grey fill <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 2 
Go into vector edit mode and select 2 anchor points. Manipulate those till you get an angle you like <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 3 
Repeat the first 2 steps and make sure to connect each begin of a fold with the end points of the previous one <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 4
Finish your composition, make sure to create artboard copies for different iterations! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 5 
Time for some color! Create a linear gradient going from light to dark, and copy & paste the style to your vectors. (OPT+CMD+C -> OPT+CMD+V) 
Tip: Use more than 2 color stops in your gradient for a unique look! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 6 
Nice! Now we just have to change the gradient angles for every other vector to create more realistic lighting <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 7 
To take your gradient fold to the next level, introduce some extra color combinations! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Bonus Step 
You can try to go for a top and bottom gradient effect as shown below... <STRICT_LINK>
User: Okay one more bonus step. 
You can even try to split up a larger gradient in multiple stops to create an effect like shown below. 
No matter what you do, make sure to experiment and have fun! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Are you trying out this technique? Make sure to share it by tagging @figma and @FonsMans. See you at the next one!
‚ú® Follow me @FonsMans for more
üîÅ Like/Retweet this thread so more people can see it!
Summary: A user shared a tutorial on creating a folded gradient effect in Figma without using plugins. The tutorial includes steps for creating and manipulating rectangles, applying linear gradients with multiple color stops, adjusting gradient angles for realistic lighting, and experimenting with different color combinations. The user encourages others to try the technique and share their results.

Text:
User: Miro helps us solve IT architectural problems by diagramming and then showing to different functional areas and users. We didn't have a collaboration tool before this so it's really been a game changer.
User: I like that collaborating and sharing boards with people is really easy. It's straightforward to spin up a new board and begin working.

User: People often ask me for good examples of executive communication: let's talk about @joshm, the CEO of @browsercompany. ‚Üì
(And the intelligent and underrated use of YouTube for a business) <STRICT_LINK>
User: Its particularity? He chose as a social network to express himself... YouTube. Uncommon.
Concretely, @browsercompany has a channel with 20k subscribers and 2 types of videos:
- the culture and vision of the company
- tutorials and advice for its users
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: We will mainly focus on the first category, the one in which @joshm is personally involved.
In terms of form, these videos are YouTube-friendly, that is to say:
- exclusive (no balanced body videos on all channels)
- 10-20 minutes
- with a chapter
User: There are 2 formats that I particularly like:
1) its Q&A in early 2023 to report and answer, for example, the question of its business model... with embedded graphs and dataviz. 72k views, 3rd channel video.
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: What is interesting is that this video starts from a tweet that he posted in early December, just before the 2nd meeting of the @browsercompany board... with the desire to be transparent and accountable to his users (‚Äúbuild in public‚Äù).
<STRICT_LINK>
User: And, hey presto, 2 weeks later, he answers it in this famous video:
<STRICT_LINK>
User: 2) A video where he films himself in a photo booth from his Mac desktop... which allows him to browse his Finder and show content (images, sounds, videos, etc.) by unfolding his story. Funny, with a touch of brothel/artisan.

User: This format was called ‚Äúvideofile_‚Äù and allows @browsercompany to ‚Äútell‚Äù its new features and the ‚Äúphilosophy behind‚Äù, each time being embodied by an employee (not just the CEO). And given the engagement rates, that's interesting. <STRICT_LINK>

Text:
User: Today I want to give some insights into the TOOLS that we use at our agency that works with startups from around the world including Silicon Valley.
(Giveaway at the end) <STRICT_LINK>
User: 2/12 First up, we use @NotionHQ . It's our hub for everything. Tasks, deadlines, management ‚Äì it's all there. It works like a charm to keep everything organised, especially when working when a team it‚Äôs nice, since everyone knows what‚Äôs where.
User: 3/12 Next, Slack. We use this mainly for internal communication with the team and for communication with a few clients. In the beginning we wanted to use Slack 100% for clients communication, but some clients just don‚Äôt like it, and we don‚Äôt want to force them haha.
User: 4/12 We also use Monday, it's our CRM where we track leads and conversions, basically keeping our clients in the loop. We used to do this in Notion, but it was hard to use which made it less motivating to keep it up to date.
User: 5/12 @zapier is our go-to for automation. It takes care of all the repeat stuff, so we have more time to be creative. Nothing special, but is saves a lot of time.
User: 6/12 For crafting copy we use @OpenAI's ChatGPT. Before GPT released we were actually using a tool called Jasper a year ago, it was around 100USD a month and delivered 30% of the results GPT offers for free, a real game changer.
User: 7/12 @webflow is the platform we use to built our website with, which integrates seamlessly with all our other tools through Zapier.
User: 8/12 For designs, we're all about @figma, from UI designs to logos, it's our go-to for making visuals.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its seamless team communication and collaboration capabilities, as well as its ease in managing agile workflows and projects. They find it simple to create, edit, and share whiteboards, brainstorm ideas, and run online meetings and workshops. However, stable internet connectivity is essential for optimal performance.

In the past browsers didn't keep up and couldn't accurately replicate designer's work. Now it's the design tools that are lagging.
User: @equinusocio @figma It's not a surprise when new features hit browsers - it's often gone through years of spec work and "Intent to ship" - I really wish @figma would step up here and be ready to ship things like oklch/oklab, color-mix, etc along side browsers
User: @jacobrask @figma We also use oklch on our ds but we are forced to stay inside the rgb spectrum because of figma. Dunno but they seem more focused on the canvas feature now.
Summary: Users discuss the limitations of Figma's default color notation, mentioning that modern CSS offers more options, but design tools like Figma are lagging behind in supporting them. This causes challenges in implementing design systems with fallbacks.

Text:
User: It allows me to collaborate easily with other team members for user research or brainstorming. Other tools like Figma do that, too, but people are uncomfortable using those tools because they are complex or not flexible enough to match the need of the hour.
User: Allows me to share boards with people even if they don't have a Miro account and an app installed. People can see each other's cursor. Scroll and Zoom is very smooth. It doesn't have any fixed ways to use it. I can use it any way I want.
User: Icons which are available with the Wireframe library are minimal. I like the IconFinder as an alternative, but it doesn't allow me to change colours easily. It also has issues with writing notes. It doesn't fix spelling mistakes while writing notes. Sometimes it causes a lot of trouble to handle layer ordering. If I want to move one layer in front/back of the other, it takes a lot of effort.
Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

Text:
User: Miro has the power to aggregate what has been shared among multiple tools. In addition, it has the potential to allow multiple people to work at the same time without any problems, and it has been used in seminars and training sessions, and has been very popular. In the training that I participate in, training using miro is increasing, and it is very useful to visualize the result of the discussion in a short time.
User: Miro is easier to use than an actual whiteboard. In particular, it's easy to attach, write, move, and connect sticky notes, and it automatically corrects the connection lines, so you can use it more efficiently than an actual whiteboard. So you can focus on the discussion. Also, miro is great for sharing information you create online, ensuring that the same image information is conveyed. As a comparison to other similar tools, it's nice to have reaction features, icons, and formatting that you can't use up.
User: The disadvantage of miro is that the access can be quite slow depending on the board. When you first open a board with a lot of information on it, you often have to wait a few 10 seconds. I hope that this problem will be solved by devising means such as image processing centered on the area where the display priority is being determined. Also, if you just use it, you don't have a chance to see new or useful functions, so I think it would be good if you were shown it by a pop-up (This feature may already exist and you may have turned it off yourself, but it is true that it does not appear at this time.).
Summary: Users find Miro useful for aggregating information from multiple tools and enabling real-time collaboration during seminars and training sessions. It is considered more efficient than a physical whiteboard, with features like automatic connection line correction and easy sharing of information. However, users experience slow access times on boards with a lot of information and suggest improving display priority and introducing pop-ups to highlight new or useful features.

Text:
User: I really enjoy using notion for note taking and syncing between devices works flawlessly. Also lots of options to structure your notes, embed different components, create small databases for recipies and such etc.
There are a few flaws though: there is no offline mode, the AI features that I don‚Äòt use cannot be deactivated, is is not as fast as a native app like apple notes/simplenote/etc., there is no real pen-support for drawing and sketching, the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of ‚Äûhaving too many eggs in one basket‚Äú
One improvement that would be great: on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet, the URL is the title. It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content. Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful.
Summary: User finds Notion powerful but finds the app difficult to use due to its poor interface and lack of basic functions. They also find it difficult to share content from other apps and find the title of the shared video to be confusing. The user suggests improving the app's interface and functionality, as well as creating a page with the title of the shared video.

Text: User: I love Notion. I am yet to experience another app that allows to tailor your workspace right down to every single one of your needs. However there‚Äôs a big, big flaw in an otherwise nearly perfect app - reminders arrive silently. There‚Äôs no sound, no vibration. Neither on iPhone nor on the watch. So if you have to keep with lots of time sensitive and high priority notifications I‚Äôm afraid you‚Äôll either have to stick to some other app or combine Notion with your run of the mill reminders
Summary: User loves Notion but finds a big flaw in its reminders, as they arrive silently without any sound or vibration on iPhone or the watch. They suggest combining Notion with other apps for time-sensitive and high-priority notifications.

Text: User: This review is more about Notion itself than the app. After reviewing a bunch of other programs I subscribed to Notion to help build my new businesses internal infrastructure. I was happy at first but it seems that the moment anything goes wrong Notion support is less than helpful. I‚Äôve been going back and forth with Notion support trying to fix some billing issues (updating my payment details). Notion seems fairly incapable of actually troubleshooting the problem and at this point as I keep getting the same suggestions from different ‚Äòpeople‚Äô I‚Äôm convinced Notion help is running on AI and not an actual human with problem solving skills. Despite numerous occasions saying the system won‚Äôt let me update my payment details and suggesting an actual bug that may be causing the issues their reply was: It‚Äôs so easy, you don‚Äôt even have to log in. Please update your information with this link. Also to note, you only get a reply every 24 hours, so after every (it‚Äôs so simple update your info) communication gets a bit tiresome. If you‚Äôve seen Sh*+s creek this whole exchange was the equivalent of ‚Äújust fold in the cheese - what do you mean - it‚Äôs easy, you just fold in the cheese‚Äù. I‚Äôve tried to escalate this to a dept manager or someone in tech that would hopefully have the skills beyond ‚Äúit‚Äôs so easy just update your information‚Äù however the more frustrated I get the less inclined they seem to be to help me. It‚Äôs at the point where I‚Äôm considering switching to another service which will be a hard decision seeing as we have put a lot of time into building our systems in Notion. Also to note despite being told that the old payment info is incorrect and I cannot update my payment details they continue to attempt to bill the old card number and then send me warnings that I need to update my information. So, let this be a cautionary tale for anyone using Notion for their business - it‚Äôs good, until it‚Äôs not. At which point you better be able to problem solve on your own. Just fold in the cheese.
Summary: User is frustrated with Notion support, as they are unable to update their payment details and are being billed for the old card number. They are considering switching to another service due to the time and effort they have invested in building their internal infrastructure in Notion.

Text:
User: Collaborating can be challenging while working remotely, but Miro makes it much easier to share ideas, ideate, brainstorm, and create something together. I use it every day to keep track of my tasks and to create conceptual designs before I work in Figma.
User: I like the ease of use with Miro. It's possible to collaborate with colleagues quickly. My favorite feature is the Microsoft Teams integration. With Miro and other whiteboarding tools, we always had issues trying to share editing access on boards, but now that we can embed the boards in Teams, anyone on the call can have access and edit the board, even if they aren't an employee at our company. It honestly has been a game changer for us when we do workshops or user interviews. I also like the single sign on option. It makes getting into Miro much easier and I don't have to enter my password. 
 
I also love that you can take pictures of sticky notes in real life and upload them to Miro and they will turn into Miro stickies. If the handwriting is hard to read, then it might need to be corrected, but this is still a cool feature.
User: There's not much I don't like about Miro. My main frustration is that our company restricts our access and licenses to 30-60 days and deletes our boards after 90 days of inactivity, but I don't think that's a Miro policy, just our company. I do like the fact that you can download a file of the board and reupload it in case any boards get deleted.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its ease of use and collaboration features, especially the Microsoft Teams integration, which allows seamless sharing and editing access to boards. They also like the single sign-on option and the ability to upload real-life sticky notes as Miro stickies. However, some users face frustrations with company-imposed restrictions on access and board deletion.

Text:
User: Dear @NotionHQ,
I recently obtained my certification from your platform, and while I appreciate the knowledge and skills I gained from the experience, I believe it's time for a change in your testing methods.
User: @NotionHQ We're in 2023, and your current question-and-answer format feels outdated. With the vast resources available to us online, including Google, Notion docs, and ChatGPT, it's unnecessary to rely solely on memorization and rote learning.
User: @NotionHQ I suggest implementing a challenge or project-based approach to make the tests more engaging and interesting. Spending an hour answering questions only to fall short of the 70% passing mark feels like a waste of time, and time is a valuable commodity for everyone.
User: @NotionHQ I understand that obtaining a certification is important, but the current system doesn't seem to reflect the dynamic and innovative nature of your platform. I hope you'll consider updating your testing methods to keep up with the times.

Text:
User: It generates great value for me in the team resolution of complex problems. 
It also helps me to promote the participation of my entire team regardless of whether they are extroverts or introverts, which greatly enriches the analysis. 
It also helps me to organize, show, store and share knowledge.
User: It has more that you can get with the conventional blackboard. You can use it not only in remote work but also projecting in meeting rooms making the tool an unlimited whiteboard for interaction, organization, editing, distribution and all the advantages of a digital tool without losing the benefits of face-to-face meetings. Increases the desire to collaborate, create and design.
User: Some dinosaur users are reluctant to use it, but once they learn it, they love it. You just have to break through that first resistance. 
The other thing that I don't like is that you can not freeze the first row and column view to be able to work on large tables like in excel.
Summary: The user finds the tool extremely valuable for team resolution of complex problems, promoting participation, and organizing, sharing, and designing knowledge. They appreciate the unlimited whiteboard features and the ability to freeze the first row and column view. The user dislikes the inability to freeze the first row and column view for large tables in excel.

Text:
User: So I‚Äôm trying to embed video files with alpha channels for a presentation. I ran a test where I included a webm file over some live text. I previewed it as a presentation and it worked perfectly. I sent it to my manager to reveiw and when he looked at it the alpha channel was replaced w/ a black background and a white box around that content that‚Äôd previously been over transparency.
Is Figma re-encoding my file? If so it‚Äôs doing it wrong. If not, why is the video changing after a period of time?
User: I was told by a Figma rep that they don‚Äôt plan on fixing this because safari doesn‚Äôt support webm v9 w/ transparency. This seems silly because that‚Äôs only on mobile. Also the issue is with figma‚Äôs re-compression of uploaded webm. it works fine initially but breaks after they come in and incorrectly re-compress properly encoded files. I‚Äôd prefer my files Not work on safari mobile rather than have them look wrong everywhere.
Summary: User experiences browser flickering and WebGL issues when using Figma with Chrome hardware acceleration enabled, affecting all files. The issue doesn't occur when hardware acceleration is disabled or on another laptop. User tried enabling WebGL and following suggested steps, but the problem persists. They will fill out a form for further investigation.

Text:
User: FigJam is kind of my one-stop shop for pretty much my entire research process. I use FigJam to plan studies in it with my stakeholders, take notes during user interviews, affinity diagram user insights, create final deliverables, prioritize customer feedback, etc. It would be much harder to do these things without FigJam.
User: FigJam makes collaboration with my project stakeholders engaging, easy, and fun. It's approachable and usable regardless of one's tech savvy. FigJam also allows me to perform critical UXR tasks like affinity diagramming in an efficient and visually pleasing manner. I rely heavily on FigJam in my day-to-day work and create almost all of my deliverables in it.
User: Some things in Figjam could be made more efficient. I mainly run into issues with formatting. For example, you can't easily paste Excel rows into it. I also wish you could edit text without having to perform multiple clicks to move through layers in the file (e.g., two clicks to edit text in a sticky). I understand why this exists, but it would also speed up my work process. Resizing things can also get weird sometimes (e.g., highlighting some design assets and trying to make them bigger only expands certain elements, have to manually fix).
Summary: Users find FigJam to be a valuable tool for their research process, as it enables easy collaboration with stakeholders and efficient execution of tasks like affinity diagramming. However, they face issues with formatting, such as difficulty pasting Excel rows and editing text through multiple layers. Resizing elements can also be problematic.

Text: User: I don't understand why this app is so touted. Because there is not a single advantage it has over other similar ones. The application has a lot of bugs, the main screen looks miserable, which makes the whole program feel crude and unfinished. I can't load files, or a list of files will be loaded, but there is nothing inside, or icons disappear all of a sudden. I do not know how you can trust this program with important records, because at the most critical moment it just will not start at all.
Summary: User finds the app lacking in features and bugs, making it feel unfinished and crude, and cannot load files or lists of files. They also mention that the main screen looks messy and unorganized, making it difficult to use. The user expresses concern about trusting the app with important records, as it fails to start at the most critical moment.

Text:
User: Conversations around open source in design - I‚Äôm curious if this would this improve involvement of designers in open source. Indulge me.
Having a design system where standards are defined and designers can jointly contribute components
User: These components would be based on the core styling of that design system. 
This would also include improvements to accessibility guidelines and improvements in documentation.
In turn anyone can use these components either as they are or make slight adjustments.
User: I think @figma already has a foundation to enable this - however it needs to be defined.
Having an actively maintained DS in the public domain. Not tied to any organization.
Anyone can pick it up and suggest improvements.
User: @dnaijatechguy @figma We're seeing more open source design related projects be shared using @penpotapp DS in particular. Also, some contributions here follow that mindset <STRICT_LINK>
User: @diacritica @figma @penpotapp Will take a look at this, Thanks
Summary: User is curious about the potential impact of open source design on designers' involvement in open source. They mention a design system with standards defined and components contributed by designers, which can be used by anyone. They also mention the possibility of an actively maintained design system in the public domain, which anyone can use and contribute to.

Text:
User: People often ask me for good examples of executive communication: let's talk about @joshm, the CEO of @browsercompany. ‚Üì
(And the intelligent and underrated use of YouTube for a business) <STRICT_LINK>
User: Its particularity? He chose as a social network to express himself... YouTube. Uncommon.
Concretely, @browsercompany has a channel with 20k subscribers and 2 types of videos:
- the culture and vision of the company
- tutorials and advice for its users
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: We will mainly focus on the first category, the one in which @joshm is personally involved.
In terms of form, these videos are YouTube-friendly, that is to say:
- exclusive (no balanced body videos on all channels)
- 10-20 minutes
- with a chapter
User: There are 2 formats that I particularly like:
1) its Q&A in early 2023 to report and answer, for example, the question of its business model... with embedded graphs and dataviz. 72k views, 3rd channel video.
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: What is interesting is that this video starts from a tweet that he posted in early December, just before the 2nd meeting of the @browsercompany board... with the desire to be transparent and accountable to his users (‚Äúbuild in public‚Äù).
<STRICT_LINK>
User: And, hey presto, 2 weeks later, he answers it in this famous video:
<STRICT_LINK>
User: 2) A video where he films himself in a photo booth from his Mac desktop... which allows him to browse his Finder and show content (images, sounds, videos, etc.) by unfolding his story. Funny, with a touch of brothel/artisan.
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: This format was called ‚Äúvideofile_‚Äù and allows @browsercompany to ‚Äútell‚Äù its new features and the ‚Äúphilosophy behind‚Äù, each time being embodied by an employee (not just the CEO). And given the engagement rates, that's interesting. <STRICT_LINK>
User: 2 other videos that were a hit: - a ‚Äúmeta-video‚Äù where the CEO watches and reacts to a review of his browser by one of the biggest tech influencers, MKBHD. It's THE most popular video with 343K views. Skilled at surfing on his visibility.
<STRICT_LINK>
User: - a vlog with members of the @browsercompany board who clearly plays the ‚Äúbehind-the-scenes strategic-meetings-that-not-so-see-to-see‚Äù card: the kind of content that always works. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: User is studying Figma and is watching YouTube videos on Envato, discussing UIUXDesigner, User Experience, UI, webdesigner, graphic designer, figma, YouTube, and Envato.

Text:
User: Miro allows me to create and adapt the board to any structure / goal I have and is flexible enough to support various use cases. At thesame time, Miro offers a lot of templates in the Miroverse which educate and inspire me to create better collaboration touchpoints.
User: Miro is my main collaboration toll with my peers and stakeholders. I use iton a daily basis as to create shared understanding of concepts, roadmaps, work to be done, reflect on the results and outcomes and workshop potential solutions. 
 
It's easy to navigate and customize to any type of meeting.
User: I have noticed that for my colleagues who do not have experience with miro or similar tools, the UX can appear complex and overwhelming. In these cases, I spend 5 min in the beginning of the meeting to educate them on how to use the tool.
Summary: Users find Miro to be an effective collaboration tool that helps run meetings smoothly, reduces manual work, and saves costs. They appreciate its user-friendly interface, available templates, sharing capabilities, and affordability. Miro has positively impacted their workplace, and they have no significant dislikes about the tool.

Text:
User: After using the #AI tool for a while, I ran into some issues and also found some tools/platforms suitable for lazy people:
Let's read the conclusion first. I recommend the @poe_platform platform. The supported bots are also quite rich. There are no IP requirements, and if you have advanced requirements, you can directly subscribe on the Poe platform.
#ChatGPT <STRICT_LINK>
User: Currently, I mainly use Claude's robot on the Poe platform. Here's a summary of the advantages I've discovered:
1) Responses will be faster than #ChatGPT in Chinese conversations
2) The corpus will be updated in due course. I don't know the frequency, but at least he can help me sort out the relatively new content #Layer2 and @Starknet
3) Writing and copywriting skills seem to be stronger than ChatGPT (subjective feeling
Let's take a look at other AI tool products in detail:
User: 1chatGPT
There are strict restrictions on IP, and a global proxy+privacy window must be attached to it before it can be used;
There are unstable situations. For example, I went to WeChat to send a message to him halfway through the conversation, and when I came back, I had to refresh the page before I could use it;
There are occasional interruptions in answering, so I need to remind him to continue.
In the end, he blocked me, which is the biggest problem with using it so far. ü•∂
<STRICT_LINK>
User: 2Google Bard Google fought back against OpenAI's products. Currently, I haven't been able to experience them due to IP issues, so I abandoned them according to the purpose of our lazy people. According to feedback from some friends, there is still a certain gap between product power and ChatGPT.
<STRICT_LINK>
User: 3Claude
The founder is the former executive vice president of OpenAI. This product is very popular in the investment community. It's a bit like the capital that didn't invest in Tesla back then placed a heavy bet on Lucid
It's currently completely free to use, and supports use of <STRICT_LINK> on Poe and #Slack
User: 4Poe
This is an integrated platform made by @Quora that supports mainstream AI conversation tools. GPT-4 and Claude+ paid subscriptions are also supported.
It's the best tool/platform to use so far, and you can use it without having to connect to a global agent or open a ladder.

User: Our team likes to use Figjam primarily because it's provided by Figma. We use Figma for design anyway, so its handy to have Figma provide an internal whiteboarding/collaboration tool without us having to create account & learn another platform.
User: What I like about Figjam is that it's easy to use and provides some templates (with instructions) so that teams can get onboarded quickly and start collaborating. I've used Figjam with other designers and also with non-design/tech team members, and we've benefitted tremendously from using Figjam as a fun collaboration tool.
User: While I like that Figjam provides basic tools for brainstorming and real-time collaboration, I sometimes find it can be too limiting. I wish there were more customization options related to shapes, colours, and fonts, so that my teammates and I can explore crude wireframes that are just a little more detailed than the rounded rectangles and other shapes that Figjam allows. When the project moves to that stage, I end up moving to regular Figma and using the comment functionality there, or, if it's difficult to manage access, create shapes in a Figma file then copy/paste into Figjam which can be tedious.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam's collaborative features, intuitive interface, and versatility for remote teams, making it suitable for brainstorming, wireframes, and user flows. However, it lacks advanced design features compared to other design tools, limiting its use for more complex design work.

Text:
User: This is my #1 choice of tool when collaborating with clients. My team uses Miro to document a strategy or wireframe and collect client feedback in real-time, it helps ensure the client that we are listening to their wants and needs. Instead of using a static PPT where we are just jotting down the notes, clients can see the work in action. In addition, we use the Miro board to document processes and attach key artifacts and URLS. This process documentation is exhaustive but Miro allows users to zoom in and out from a micro/macro view to learn about the process which is great for leadership to see and great for onboarding. It especially works for a global remote company where we can all jump in to review no matter the time zone. If you are in the same time zone, it works great to get everyone in the room and use as a collaboration tool. For example, I'm located in California and my client is located in the UK. We use miro to make updates on our timezone and get very detailed in specific areas of question. It allows for transparency, review, and collaboration.
User: In general, I like the whiteboarding and mapping capabilities that allow for deep thought, process documentation, and pure collaboration with teams. It allows me to jot my rough thoughts on paper where I then can find patterns and create a more solid process. Miro is the perfect think tank environment that you use from start (ideation) to a finish (a solid concept). It's also great for inviting colleagues for feedback or collaboration. Anyone can use it with a free license.
User: Miroboards have a size capacity where if you add too many screenshots, it starts to slow down. It can also get extremely messy and often confusing for a new user coming in and unsure where to start. Sometimes if you start your miroboard too big, the details of things like adding arrow connectors can be really tiny. Causing me to selecting all and sizing down my space so you can see these details. I sometimes run into issues with font formatting, if I copied and pasted a highlighted text in bold and then I drag in the text widget, it will copy what I've used when that is not my intention. It's really just the small details that I wish were fixed that could make my experience more easier.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro as their top choice for collaboration with clients, as it allows real-time feedback, process documentation, and easy onboarding. It is particularly useful for remote teams and different time zones. However, users face issues with size capacity, slow performance with too many screenshots, messy boards, and minor formatting problems.

Text:
User: FigJam allows me and my team to quickly and easily make low-fidelity wireframes and conceptual designs as well as collect our findings from our user interviews and other Discovery activities.
User: I love the ability to ideate and diagram in FigJam and then copy it to Figma to use as a reference and modify as necessary. It's really great to use them in tandem. I also find the shapes and arrows easy to use and connect. The stickers are a fun feature as well. 
 
The audio chat in Figjam and Figma is clutch. My team will typically meet in there instead of scheduling a Teams meeting. It's a great way to hop on review a design or ask questions about a specific thing. 
 
I also really like the option to give anyone access for 24 hours. This is great for collaborating with people that are not within the company.
User: There's nothing I don't like about FigJam. I don't feel like there is anything missing from the application.
Summary: The user appreciates FigJam for its ease in creating low-fidelity wireframes and conceptual designs, as well as collecting findings from user interviews. They enjoy using FigJam in tandem with Figma, and find the shapes, arrows, and stickers easy to use. The audio chat feature is highly valued for team collaboration, and the 24-hour access option is appreciated for working with external collaborators. The user has no complaints or suggestions for improvement.

Text:
User: MIRO helps me manage a project schedule with complex deliverables, timeline, swimlane owners, and key cross-functional dependencies. It also helps with basic product roadmap and innovation planning. The visual appeal is also helpful as it can serve as a presentation board for senior management presentations.
User: MIRO is an ideal tool for facilitating collaboration across teams or large groups. I use it with my teams for a variety of applications, including planning project schedules, brainstorming ideas, mapping out solutions and process flow diagrams. It is highly flexible, allowing the user to define the structure and content. I really like the ease of use and the infinite space, which allows you to constantly be adding to existing boards. There are many existing templates that help provide a good starting point for collaboration.
User: One of the challenges that we've seen is integration with other software. I'd like to see a more seamless integration with MS Excel--for instance, the ability to capture live Excel spreadsheets in MIRO that are auto-updates as the underlying Excel sheet changes.
Summary: Users find MIRO helpful for managing complex project schedules, product roadmaps, and facilitating collaboration across teams. They appreciate its visual appeal, ease of use, and infinite space. However, they would like to see improved integration with MS Excel for seamless updates between the two platforms.

Text:
User: Tutorial Thread ‚ú®
Learn how to create this folded gradient effect with @figma, in just a few easy steps ‚Äî no plugins needed!
Ready? Let‚Äôs dive in üëá
#sponsored <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 1
Create a new artboard and add a rectangle with a grey fill <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 2
Go into vector edit mode and select 2 anchor points. Manipulate those till you get an angle you like <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 3
Repeat the first 2 steps and make sure to connect each begin of a fold with the end points of the previous one <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 4 <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 5
Time for some color! Create a linear gradient going from light to dark, and copy & paste the style to your vectors. (OPT+CMD+C -> OPT+CMD+V)
Tip: Use more than 2 color stops in your gradient for a unique look! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 6
Nice! Now we just have to change the gradient angles for every other vector to create more realistic lighting <STRICT_LINK>
User: Step 7
To take your gradient fold to the next level, introduce some extra color combinations! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Bonus Step
You can try to go for a top and bottom gradient effect as shown below... <STRICT_LINK>
User: Okay one more bonus step.
You can even try to split up a larger gradient in multiple stops to create an effect like shown below.
No matter what you do, make sure to experiment and have fun! <STRICT_LINK>
User: Are you trying out this technique? Make sure to share it by tagging @figma and @FonsMans.
See you at the next one!
Summary: A user shared a tutorial on creating a folded gradient effect in Figma without using plugins. The tutorial includes steps for creating and manipulating rectangles, applying linear gradients with multiple color stops, adjusting gradient angles for realistic lighting, and experimenting with different color combinations. The user encourages others to try the technique and share their results.

Text:
User: It replaced physical whiteboards for discovery and brainstorming sessions. It also works as an excellent ice-breaker and teambuilding tool to have everyone active during meetings or learning sessions.
User: For those who miss physical whiteboards and post-its this is the solution to easily (and virtually) visualize projects and organize brainstorming, project management and workflow visualization. It's very friendly, intuitive and compatible with other tools.
User: Some toolboxes usually overlap important information, and sharing options are not that easy to understand and use, mainly with external (not frequent) users.
Summary: Users find Figma valuable for replacing physical whiteboards in discovery and brainstorming sessions, as well as for teambuilding and engagement during meetings. It is user-friendly, intuitive, and compatible with other tools. However, some users face challenges with overlapping toolboxes and sharing options, especially for external or infrequent users.

Summary: Users appreciate Figma's Figjam for its ability to create flowcharts, collaborate with teams, and easily attach images for wireframing. They find the UI and ease of use impressive, but suggest improving the UX for attaching arrows to individual boxes.

Text:
User: FigJam helps fill the gap between collaborating and working remotely. It allows our team to 'whiteboard' together without being in the same room - and not lose value from doing so.
User: FigJam is easy to jump into and get value out of, even when unfamiliar with the tool. The entire product team has found value in it for collaboration - from quick brainstorm sessions to workshops.
User: I wish transferring things from FigJam over to an actual Figma file was easier. I like to have the entire narrative of how a final design came to be within the Figma file; the sessions on FigJam are part of that.
Summary: Users find FigJam valuable for remote collaboration, as it enables 'whiteboarding' without being in the same room. The tool is easy to use and beneficial for the entire product team in various collaborative activities. However, users wish for an easier way to transfer content from FigJam to Figma files to maintain the design narrative.

Text:
User: 1. It would be easier for all native Spanish speakers to use and understand: By having the interface and content in our native language, it would be easier for us to understand the application and use all its functions correctly.
2. It would increase our efficiency at work: By not having to constantly translate terms and concepts into Spanish, it would save us time and allow us to be more efficient at work.
3. We would feel more comfortable: If Spanish is our main language, it would be more comfortable for us to use the application in our native language.
4. It would allow us to learn new technical and business terms in Spanish: Using Notion in Spanish would allow us to learn new technical and business terms in our language, which can be especially useful if we are working in a Spanish-speaking business environment.
5. It would make us feel included and valued: By having the option to use Notion in Spanish, we feel included and valued as users of the application, which would increase our satisfaction and loyalty to it.
Summary: User suggests adding Spanish language support to Notion, as it would be easier for Spanish-speaking users to use and understand, increase efficiency at work, and make them feel more comfortable. They also suggest learning new technical and business terms in Spanish, which would be useful in a Spanish-speaking business environment.

Text:
User: It's the go-to design tool in our team. It responds to all wireframing, prototyping, and design requirements and facilitates team collaboration. It also comes with Figjam, and eliminates need for other whiteboarding tools.
User: It's easy to get started with Figma, and its robust community means there are tons of resources and plugins to inspire and help speed up your design process (and there are some incredible plugins out there)!
User: There isn't much to dislike, but there are a few inconveniences. First, everything is online so you need a strong internet connection, especially when dealing with large files. Second, the way plugins are handled can feel a bit clunky (you have to look for it, save/run it, and it opens as a separate window - wish there was a way to anchor it). Third, it might just be me but I always get confused navigating within the community section... but again these are just minor inconveniences and the pros far outweigh the cons.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma as their go-to design tool for wireframing, prototyping, and collaboration, with the added benefit of Figjam and a robust community offering resources and plugins. However, they mention minor inconveniences such as the need for a strong internet connection, a clunky plugin handling process, and confusing navigation within the community section.

Text:
User: I usually use Miro to map out the user flows, customer journey maps, personas, IA, etc. I also use it a lot for user research analysis, such as affinity maps, empathy maps, competitor analysis, etc.
User: As for workshops, the sticky notes and votings are very convenient. And adding background music with the timer helps create a more joyful environment during the workshops. Some built-in templates are easy to use, which has made my work more efficient.
User: Could provide more formats for file exports.
Summary: The user primarily uses Miro for various user research analysis tasks and finds the sticky notes, voting, and background music features helpful during workshops. They appreciate the built-in templates for efficiency but suggest providing more file export formats.

Text:
User: FigJam has helped solve the problem of real-time collaboration with my team in a virtual setting.
User: What is most helpful with FigJam is the ability to layout work in a whiteboard style and make edits/comments with your team in real-time
User: What can sometimes be an issue with FigJam is that the designs can be more limited on FigJam vs. Figma
Summary: Users find FigJam helpful for real-time collaboration in a virtual setting, appreciating the whiteboard-style layout and real-time editing and commenting features. However, they note that design capabilities are more limited compared to Figma.

Text: User: It doesn't matter if Notion Han is in Chinese or not; I'm very satisfied to be able to update steadily. It's best to enable the offline function; you can also pay offline, and continue to support the Notion team!
Summary: User is satisfied with Notion Han's ability to update steadily and appreciates the offline function, which allows them to pay and support the Notion team.

Text:
User: I can develop my processes in one place and show the progress' creation steps. I can share my work progress whit my colleagues and leadership team consistently and clearly. I believe that my productivity had increased.
User: Miro is intuitive and well-organised, and its collaboration capabilities work great in hybrid environments. I often use Miro for its presentation capabilities. What is very compelling is the visual representation and vibrance of available tools bring presentations to life and give them the right flavour.
User: As intuitive as Miro is, some elements may require more development, like the options for diagramming; it would be great to export diagrams directly to Viso or other flow or diagramming tools. Often diagrams must be inserted into documentation that is outside of Miro.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its ability to develop processes in one place and share progress with colleagues and leadership, resulting in increased productivity. They find Miro intuitive, well-organized, and great for collaboration in hybrid environments, with visually appealing presentation tools. However, they suggest improvements in diagramming options, such as exporting diagrams directly to Visio or other flow tools for easier integration into external documentation.

Text: User: I really love the Notion app!!! Great app for enabling and enhancing productivity. Just a suggestion, it would be lovely to have a particular page or a particular note privatized by lock. In other words, you would need a pass code, password, or pin to open a particular page or note. This will help with people who have teams that are logged onto their notion app, and they want to keep some certain things private.
Summary: User loves the Notion app and finds it very helpful for enhancing productivity, but suggests adding a password or pin to a particular page or note to help with teams using the app. They also suggest adding a page or note to be private.

Text:
User: I have created a Creative Hack workshop template which I use to help teams and clients come up with ideas. 
I'll also use Miro for other team tasks in which multiple people need to make inputs. 
Its helpful for capturing a large amount of information in a little amount time, and ultimately making sense of those inputs.
User: I describe Miro as an Adobe Illustrator Group Chat. I love the drag and drop flexibility of it and ease of use, which allows me to capture ideas and feedback in real time. Even when I'm working with large groups of people, the tool enables me to synthesize conversations and sharebacks in a way that captures the essence of a meeting.
User: I have a few small feedback options for Miro. 
 
1. For some reason I am forced to put a password on a board when I make it publically editable. It didn't used to be like this and I find it annoying that I have to do that every time. I end up just saying "miroboard" for everything. 
 
2. When I invite outside of my org participants to join a board. Via the UX they often think they have to sign up to view the board, which leads to time lost in the session correcting them and getting them to the board as a guest quickly. 
 
3. Not sure if this is still the case but I wish I could give people outside of my "team" permission to lock objects. I work across teams so sometimes I'm unable to lock assets on colleagues' boards and vice versa.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its ease of use, real-time collaboration, and ability to capture ideas effectively. However, they face issues with forced password protection on public boards, confusing UX for inviting external participants, and limited permission options for locking objects across teams.

Text:
User: When we need a meeting, we always decide to use Miro. And this is a standard in our way of working, even if we are all in the same room. The reason is that Miro has been instrumental in brainstorming until we reach agreements that we all like. The methodology has made the meetings less time-consuming and more effective.
User: The fluidity of the application is out of this world. Thanks to it, we can create structures while meeting without waiting for changes. In addition, it's easy to use, so anyone can master it and get a lot out of it to express their ideas.
User: Miro works perfectly, thanks to the fact that it is online, but this is a drawback if the connection is unstable. Therefore, I would like some measures so that the unstable connection does not affect the experience so much.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its effectiveness in facilitating brainstorming and decision-making during meetings, even when everyone is in the same room. They praise its fluidity and ease of use, allowing for real-time collaboration. However, they suggest improvements for handling unstable internet connections to ensure a seamless experience.

Text: User: It's the same, right? Just relax
