Text:
User: Miro really helps when something has to be explained to the customer, we can easily create a plan together or visualize some ideas. It very much helped me get through the workshops I had to host.
User: Collaboration features are very useful, I can easily share link to Miro board with our clients and they don't even have to create Miro account or use Miro app to be able to collaborate. 
What I also like about Miro are multiple tools that we can use to create boards like sticky notes, diagrams, tables, shapes and so on.
User: Thing that I dislike about Miro is that when I click a link to the Miro board (for examlpe shared on Slack) it will open in both website and native app on my PC and I end up having same Miro board opened twice.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's collaboration features, ease of sharing boards with clients, and variety of tools for creating boards. However, they dislike that clicking a shared link opens the board in both the website and native app, causing duplication.

User: Figma helps us maximize our small team and bandwidth by allowing us to design and work asynchronously. We can create and iterate quickly, ultimately delivering better product experiences and marketing initiatives faster -- which is critical for a startup.
User: Figma is most helpful for getting everyone on the team quickly with a visual realization of a campaign, creative asset or even clickable prototype for sales pitches. Organization is logical; comment and approval notifications get attention and are simple to use; overall intuitive platform.

Summary: Users find Figma valuable for maximizing their small team's efficiency, enabling quick design iterations, and providing an intuitive platform for collaboration. They appreciate the logical organization and notification system. However, they suggest offering help articles and tools tailored to users' varying skill levels and familiarity with the product.

Text:
User: Our team uses FigJam to both collect and organize data when planning product updates, and we also use it to visually map out user workflows. This lets us demo the experience internally while taking real-time notes that can be shared with the whole team.
User: For UX design and team collaboration in a remote work environment, FigJam is an excellent way to design product workflows and collaborate with various team members. The controls are intuitive, and it's easy to track comments and changes.
User: I don't have any negative comments about FigJam as my experience has been nothing but positive. It's allowed me as a Product Marketer to collaborate effectively with both designers and engineers.
Summary: Users find FigJam to be an excellent tool for UX design and team collaboration in remote work environments, as it allows them to visually map out workflows, track comments and changes, and collaborate effectively with various team members.

Text:
User: 
Styles1024√ó1024 51.3 KB
When publishing a library I have to uncheck styles that are not meant to be published, and I have to do it every time I publish. Sometimes I accidentally publish styles that were meant to help speed up my work within a file, but that were not meant to be a part of the library. It would be helpful to have an option similar to what I‚Äôve added in the mock-up above. I‚Äôd like to be able to toggle whether or not a style is meant to be a published style.
On a similar note, it would be helpful not only to see which items have changed in the library when I publish, but also what has changed specifically about those items.
Summary: User suggests adding a toggle option for styles in Figma to control whether they should be published or not, as they sometimes accidentally publish styles meant for internal use only. They also request a feature to show specific changes in items when publishing a library.

Text:
User: The ability to have an interactive workshop online that is collaborative and impactful.
User: I love that you can collaborate with everyone at the same time truly. Building out the space for the collaboration is easy to do, allowing it to be prepared ahead of time. You can move between presentation mode and working mode quickly. Miro has made my workshops much more interactive. 
 
I love the built-in grouping and voting functionality. These provide a level of quick feedback you often to do receive in collaboration tools.
User: The number 1 item is don't count on everyone having received your invite to the board when you share. If you need someone in a meeting, you must have them validate prior that they have access. Often I have invited people, and then we have had to search for a way to get them in. I think this happens if they have an account already in place. 
 
There is also trouble with some of the functionality - you can Ctrl/V to paste but if you use the past from the menu often it doesn't work effectively... also things come in very small and you may have to go in search of where they were pasted.
Summary: The user appreciates Miro's interactive and collaborative features, which make workshops more engaging and efficient. They particularly like the built-in grouping and voting functionalities. However, they have experienced issues with inviting participants and some functionalities, such as pasting and resizing elements

Text:
User: As a globally distributed team, we are inherently remote and sit in different time zones. Miro is helping us collaborate more effectively and efficiently, allowing us to gather multiple stakeholders' perspectives from numerous regions. This, in turn, helps us make better-informed decisions.
User: Miro is a one-stop, do it all digital whiteboarding tool that enables and empowers teams to collaborate better in person, remotely, and asynchronously. It has great built-in features for workshops and brainstorming sessions, such as setting a timer, voting and commenting.
User: The only thing that can get a little confusing are the access permissions for each team within an organisation
Summary: Users appreciate Miro as a digital whiteboarding tool that enables effective collaboration for globally distributed teams, offering features for workshops and brainstorming sessions. However, they find the access permissions for teams within an organization confusing.

Text:
User: Miro helps me create a mindmap for a product, share it with clients and other stakeholders, get feedback, and work collaboratively. Miro also allows me to make the initial sketch for a product to give the clients a basic flow of the product so we can solve the problems before the development and keep the product consistent; this also helps in efficiency and reducing costs.
User: The upside of Miro is brainstorming can be done collaboratively with all the stakeholders, including clients; this helps in coming up with solutions quickly and even testing out the ideas in the initial stages of development.
User: Miro is a good app overall, but it can sometimes be overwhelming and cluttered. Miro cannot be used offline. Navigating on a larger gets a little tedious and occasionally inaccurate. lags at times.
Summary: Users find Miro helpful for creating mindmaps, sharing with clients and stakeholders, and working collaboratively on product development. The collaborative brainstorming feature is particularly beneficial for quickly generating and testing ideas. However, some users find the app overwhelming, cluttered, and difficult to navigate on larger projects. Additionally, Miro cannot be used offline and may experience occasional lag.

Text:
User: Being able to collaborate with colleagues in a virtual space is fundamental for remote working. It has also made my research activities easier to manage and more accessible within the business. From team building sessions, retrospectives, or working solo - it honestly is a game changer and I can't imagine how we would manage without it.
User: I honestly cannot rate Miro highly enough. It has become an essential part of remote working for me since I was introduced to it in 2020, and one of the most advanced whiteboard tools I have come across. 
 
In my current role as a UX Researcher, I use Miro for facilitating workshops and analysing and synthesising research. I can dedicate an entire board to a research project and give stakeholders a space that they can refer back to at any time. I also embed my project boards in our internal Confluence pages, which allows my colleagues to interact with the board without having to leave the page. 
 
Other features I find useful are: 
- The vast amount of templates available 
- Giving presentations directly from Miro 
- The addition of a private mode 
- 'Show author' on stickies 
- I'm really excited to try the new 'talkback' feature! 
 
It's very intuitive to use so the barrier for entry is extremely low. I often lead workshops with people that aren't very technical and seldom have any issues with people trying to learn how to use Miro's features.
User: Exporting stickies to CSV format with the columns and rows in the correct order can be a bit fiddly. I have to manually separate columns into rows whilst trying to maintain the integrity of the data. Perhaps there could be/is a way to tabulate stickies in bulk within Miro but I haven't found an easy way to do this yet. 
 
I often run out of sticky note colours and would really like to be able to use my own custom colours like you can with frames and shapes. I would love some more themes for diagramming and flow charts, or the ability to save a set of custom colours as a theme for diagramming shapes.
Summary: Users find Miro helpful for remote collaboration, particularly in user research and Sprint Retrospectives, as it provides inbuilt templates and acts as a virtual whiteboard. However, some users find it has too many features and difficulty locking frames.

Text:
User: Miro is always working on new features that help me as a UX Rersearcher to find new methods of organizing qualitative data, for example with Tags or the new clusters by Sentiment or keywords, among other features through Miro AI, which despite still being in an early stage are very promising.
User: I like the simple and intuitive interface that allows me to start creating right away with sticky notes or a mind map and progressively develop my work. I am very happy with the new features that come out, I always end up using the tags in the sticky notes, the creation of clusters and everything that can help me organize a lot of qualitative data from workshops.
User: The limitations in terms of typography, when I want to present data directly in Miro but I can't create presentations according to the company's identity is something that makes me have to move to other platforms, which is a shame because it works relatively well the part of creating interactive presentations.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's continuous development of new features, such as tags, sentiment-based clusters, and Miro AI, which help in organizing qualitative data for UX researchers. They enjoy the simple and intuitive interface, allowing for easy creation and organization of data from workshops. However, limitations in typography options hinder users from creating presentations that align with their company's identity, causing them to switch to other platforms.

Text:
User: I had a problem of trying to show someone the visual design that was in my head. By using figjam, and an add-on to download examples of designs, I was able to put together a mockup of a design to collaborate with my team and determine a solution that worked for us. The prototype feature meant I was then able to present our mockups to the CEO acting as a functional website. The presentation was a hit, and we got approval to move forward with the changes.
User: The amount of powerful features built into the free version is incredible. I'm using Figjam daily, from mockups of new websites to even simple UI designs to send to our engineering team. The ability to prototype a working design is amazing. There are some crazy good add-ons that you can use to extend the program for insane time-saving benefits.
User: It feels a bit overwhelming when you open it at first, and sometimes things may behave unexpectedly because you might not realise one of the settings is enabled e.g. clip content for a frame.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam's collaborative features, intuitive interface, and versatility for remote teams, making it suitable for brainstorming, wireframes, and user flows. However, it lacks advanced design features compared to other design tools, limiting its use for more complex design work.

Text:
User: Everyone: "Use @googledocs it's simple ‚Äì No use @evernote and @NotionHQ it's shared ‚Äì No do @RoamResearch it's serious ‚Äì No, use Apple Notes and Google Keep..."
Me: They ALL run INSIDE my @obsdmd ü§£üòé ü§Ø
Be a rebel üëá <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd Obsidian is built on a technology called "Electron".
Electron is just a Chrome browser, that runs like an app on your desktop.
So essentially Obsidian = Snazzy Browser for your notes.
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd This allows us - in theory - to browse any website.
(In practice it works 80% of the time, hence I couldn't get it to work with @tana_inc or @logseq )
While Obsidian does not support that out of the box - with a plugin it's easy. Let's get to it!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Go to Settings > Community Plugins. Search for "Custom Frames"
Install it. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq In the Obsidian settings there will be now a new entry "Custom Frames" (towards end of your list)
Find the "New Frame" button and click it. A Frame is such a browser window, that we can use to access all of the services.
The new entry will appear in the list above the button. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Configure your Frame
1 Set the URL (<STRICT_LINK>, <STRICT_LINK> or <STRICT_LINK> - copy & paste from Browser)
2 ‚úÖ "open in center" to open the service like a tab (otherwise it's in the sidebar)
3 ‚úÖ "Add Ribbon Icon" to display a side icon. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Specify the icon you want to use.
Go to <STRICT_LINK> and find an icon you like.
Copy paste it's name into the "icon" textfield in previous step. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq RESTART OBSIDIAN
Your new ribbon icon should now appear on the left.
You will have to log in to Google/Apple/Evernote/... the first time. But then it will remember you. (Just like in a browser)
On the top right you find a few buttons, to reload the page. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Summary:
‚ñ∫ Download "Custom Frames" plugin
‚ñ∫ Add frames to any website, as Obsidian is technically a browser.
‚ñ∫ This technique works with ANY website. So you can integrate google calendar, facebook or a todo app into obsidian!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Obsidian is THE note-taking app to rule them all. I focus on helping Academics & Knowledge Workers, to leverage its capacities to the max. If you want to propel your academic career, join my seminar this week and become an "Effortless Academic"!
<STRICT_LINK>
User: @Artifexx @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq @SaveToNotion #Thread #Study
Summary: User loves the app but is experiencing issues with not being able to access their notes, which they need.

Text:
User: Trying to apply several transformations in a row to a Figma object, including skew, and keeping the full working matrix (with correct scale values), how do I apply the final composite transformation?
I know that Figma objects don‚Äôt care about the scale in the relativeTransform and have to be resized using resize(). How do I adjust the transform to ‚Äúremove‚Äù the scale but keep the correct rotation and especially skew?
In this picture I first scale then rotate, the points are transformed correctly, the rectangle and star are not. 
Here first I rotate then scale:
Here is skew. If that‚Äôs all I do, it works:
but as soon as I rotate the result, the objects and points do different things (the points are correct):
So, if I take an identity matrix and apply a bunch of transforms to it, how do I translate the final result to Figma objects?
User: Oh yes I‚Äôve seen it when it was just released, it evolved quite a lot! Amazing work!
I‚Äôve shared this post in the Figma Discord for visibility, hopefully someone can help.
User: Btw you can also work with text. 
 
 twitter.com
 
 
 
Brainshift Design
@brainshift_
 Making random passwords from custom character sets in #Generator for #Figma - youtube.com/watch?v=0wALOq‚Ä¶
 10:03 AM - 22 May 2023
 
 
 
 
 
 

User: Epic stuff!
Summary: A user is seeking advice on applying multiple transformations, including skew, to Figma objects while maintaining the correct scale values and working matrix. They also mention issues with rotation and resizing. The user appreciates a shared resource and highlights that it can work with text.

User: Miro is serving as a place we can collect images, ideas and more from our clients in the architectural/interior design process. We can message them via Miro in order to keep communication and content in the same "space" throughout a project, and all team members can add to it and use it.
User: The interface is very intuitive, I rarely need to read the FAQ on how to use a tool or function. It is versatile in allowing many different tools to be used for visually communication information to clients/teammbmers. We use it in place of Pinterest boards/ style boards for our interior and architectural design services.
User: I sometimes wish the drawings tools were a bit more robust - they seems to be geared toward flow chart style communication. I'd like to be able to sketch free form shapes or have a larger shape library.
Summary: Users find Miro useful for collecting images, ideas, and communication in the architectural and interior design process, appreciating its intuitive interface and versatility. However, they wish for more robust drawing tools and a larger shape library for better free-form sketching capabilities.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÑ Found this thread helpful? Share it with fellow indie makers and solopreneurs who could use these tips! Let's support each other on our solo business journeys!<STRICT_LINK>
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

User: I find Miro helpful in brainstorming sessions, prototyping new digital products, or mapping a flow chart. It is easy to share and export a Miro file to different formats.
User: I wouldn't say I like that there is no integration between Miro and Microsoft PowerPoint yet, and I believe many users have raised the same request. Since graphic and drawing tools on Miro are better, we want to have the ability to work between the two platforms to present any idea better.
Summary: Users find Miro helpful for brainstorming, prototyping, and creating flowcharts due to its real-time collaboration and easy sharing features. However, they express a desire for integration with Microsoft PowerPoint to enhance presentations and leverage Miro's superior graphic tools.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

Text:
User: Notion is an absolutely fantastic app for projects, notes, sorting, and many many more due to its versatility and freedom. As a single person, notion is completely free with next to no restrictions. Teams will require payment, but it has a free trial to see how you like it, and I consider it fantastic for groups. However, that being said, mobile notion is severely lacking in certain features that the desktop version has. Basic features like renaming your workspace can only be done on desktop. There are also some bugs with the ui, like the back arrow sometimes just straight up sending me out of the current workspace, and the toolbar disappearing and requiring me to restart the app.
These don‚Äôt ruin the app by any means, as notion is still an amazing app and is still amazing in mobile, but I would consider mobile notion a great ADDITION to your desktop notion. Use desktop as your main form of using notion when creating, and use mobile when you‚Äôre away from the desktop or need to check something. Mobile as your only form of using notion isn‚Äôt terrible, but it‚Äôs definitely inferior.
Notion overall is an amazing app with amazing developers, who deserve lots of love and support. They also gave major generosity with the app, of which many other services would‚Äôve charged the individual a large amount of money to use what notion gives for free, which again is pretty much everything except very minor things like upload file size limits.
Summary: User praises Notion for its versatility and freedom, but notes that mobile version lacks certain features and has bugs. They suggest using desktop as the main form of using Notion, and mobile as an addition to it.

Text:
User: 1/ a month ago i asked ChatGPT to help me cultivate more discipline. had been feeling chaotic, unfocused, and just not like myself.
gave me 10 things to do. it worked.
big fan of AI as personal coach. no more reading airport books. just a few bullet points w minimal filler.
User: 2/ the list was:
- declutter your environment
- prioritize your tasks
- set clear goals - limit screen time
- learn to say no
- automate and delegate
- cultivate a minimalist mindset
- simplify your finances
- create routines
- practice mindfulness
User: 3/ i ported this list into @NotionHQ and then used their embedded AI feature to expand each list item into practical steps with examples
i then made daily action items to help me actually *do* these things every day
and then i blocked time on my calendar to do the action items
Summary: User finds Notion to be a great app for collaboration and brainstorming, but has experienced numerous bugs and glitches, including issues with adding checkboxes and creating to-do lists. They also mention that the app is slow and buggy, and the AI tool is not useful for their needs.

Text:
User: Miro helps solve group collaboration on final presentations. I had been using InDesign before, but couldn't get everyones eyes on my document quickly. The ability to brainstorm, and share notes when conducting research has also been an important part for my team, with some members having fully remote positions.
User: The thing I find most helpful with Miro is the collaboration. Instead of sharing versions of documents around, or trying to record physical notes in a way for my whole team to see, we all have the most current online version that is easy to work with and create beautiful designs.
User: There are few downsides to using Miro, sometimes others feel intimidated by using it, but usually, that changes quick. I use Miro to create presentations and designs, which works well and creates high-resolution documents, and while it offers more flexibility in design than PowerPoint, I have to be creative to get the designs I want.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its collaboration features, enabling teams to work together on presentations and designs more efficiently than with InDesign or PowerPoint. Miro is particularly helpful for remote team members, though some users may initially feel intimidated. While it offers more design flexibility, users may need to be creative to achieve desired results.

Text:
User: I usually have to make presentations to my clients to let them know how the progress of the projects has been going. I used Powerpoint and other similar software because they are pretty well known. 
However, Miro has been great for making these presentations because it is easier to use.
User: Miro has fascinating visuals. The board is a perfect virtual space to dump images and others to communicate ideas. 
 
I also love how interactive the software is. I especially see this when I think of it as a virtual whiteboard
User: Browsing is a bit tedious when too much content is on the same board. It would be interesting to have filters or something similar for these cases. Sometimes, I use more than an unique space for big projects.
Summary: Users find Miro easier to use for presentations compared to PowerPoint, appreciating its interactive and visually appealing features. However, they suggest adding filters or similar tools to improve navigation when dealing with large amounts of content on a single board.

Text:
User: üöÄ How to turn an ‚Äûalmost perfect‚Äù UI/UX to ‚Äûperfect‚Äù.
Using <STRICT_LINK> as a perfect example (created by @cnnr_cllhn) <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more ‚Äûconcise‚Äù adjective without using ‚Äûvery‚Äù. Example: very rich = affluent.
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that .It's straight to the point (just like the Google Search homepage). So what's the problem? <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn ‚ùå There are 3 main flaws:
1. Site feels messy
2. Design lacks consistency
3. Elements feel a little too cramped
We'll approach it ‚Äûvia negativa‚Äù style: by removing stuff rather than adding.
üë©üé® Let's work on that that using @figma
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 1Ô∏è‚É£: Decluttering üßπ
The most important step would be to remove the clutter ‚Äì the annoying newsletter popup, the newsletter section and the newsletter banner. We'll get back to it later.
This has already made a difference. The interface looks significantly cleaner. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 2Ô∏è‚É£: Let the design breathe üí®
Let's add more whitespace ‚Äì the more the better. This will achieve a better visual separation.
Now the `very + x = y` line instantly grabs our attention. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user discussed how to improve the UI/UX of a website called LoseTheVery, which helps find concise adjectives. They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

Text:
User: FigJam is a valuable tool for my team and me. It allows us to efficiently produce low-fidelity wireframes, develop visual designs, and engage in collaborative ideation on a shared canvas.
User: FigJam makes it easy for multiple users to work together on the same canvas in real time, regardless of location. This helps the team conduct brainstorming sessions and ideate together for their tasks. 
Its intuitive interface helps easily create diagrams, flowcharts, mind maps and other required diagrams. 
Also, figmJam provide the integration facility with other Figma products and third-party applications like slack.
User: There is nothing to dislike in FigJam but something that I find odd FigJam is cursor chat feature.
Summary: The user finds FigJam valuable for their team, as it enables efficient collaboration on low-fidelity wireframes, visual designs, and ideation on a shared canvas. They appreciate its real-time collaboration, intuitive interface, and integration with other Figma products and third-party apps like Slack. However, they find the cursor chat feature odd.

Text:
User: Records for qualification learning are used with personal accounts so that records for qualification learning can be viewed on various devices, but anyway, shortcomings are conspicuous and difficult to use. I don't recommend it at all as an app when you want to watch content across multiple devices.
First, if you put in a lot of photos, character input becomes heavy. It's like a bad word processor from a year ago. Furthermore, when ‚Äú/‚Äù is inputted, it goes into command mode without permission, and it becomes like a freeze.
After adding AI to the function, even if you try to insert a photo with the insertion function (press + on the screen), it will prioritize AI character input, so it now takes about 1 minute to insert the photo. The addition of the AI function was a real inconvenience, and I can only think that it was added out of complacency. What's more, you can't disable the AI function yourself.
When I asked for a solution to such a complaint, I received a notification that ‚Äúthe AI function was disabled,‚Äù but it was not disabled at all, and they were left alone and unable to respond to inquiries.
Summary: User finds the app difficult to use due to its heavy character input and AI function, which takes too long to insert photos and prioritize AI character input. They also find it inconvenient that the AI function cannot be disabled.

Text:
User: Miro provides an ideal software solution for collecting comments and feedback on wireframe designs, showing what they would look like with elements rearranged, and sharing them with others we are collaborating with. 
Team members can review content in their own time and leave post-it notes, comments and annotations with the flexibility to be able to draw, cut and paste etc. to get thoughts across. When we provide our feedback to others, it's very clear which part of the design each piece of feedback relates to and visually shows what we think it should look like.
User: Very flexible, easy to use, intuitive keyboard shortcuts for adding elements to the board make it quick to get thoughts down. Default colours and styles look good. 
Easier to navigate than visio.
User: Doesn't have BPMN symbols, and swimlane structure where space can easily be added in the middle of a diagram so not well suited for process mapping - I still use visio for that.
Summary: Users find Miro ideal for collecting feedback on wireframe designs and collaborating with team members, as it is flexible, easy to use, and has intuitive keyboard shortcuts. However, it lacks BPMN symbols and swimlane structures, making it less suitable for process mapping compared to Visio.

Text:
User: We have used other platforms in the past with similar capabilities, but FigJam is very easy to use. It helps us diagram out our workflows and processes, but internally and externally for clients. The important thing is that someone outside of our organization (that doesn't use FigJam every day) can easily use it and collaborate.
User: Being able to collaborate with both internal and external stakeholders is very easy. The UI makes it easy to create and ideate our processes and sharing the FigJam with others is seamless. They don't need to download anything to hop in and start editing.
User: There isn't much I would say I dislike about FigJam. There are some limitations in choices when building out flows, such as shapes or colors, but it hasn't effected me from being able to create what I need.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam as a one-stop shop for collaboration, especially in remote-first environments. They use it for various purposes, including ideation, flow mapping, and user research planning. Users also value the ongoing updates that improve usability, performance, and speed, but suggest additional customization options, such as background colors and styles.

Text:
User: We‚Äôre working on a larger Component library that includes non-published components (components with the prefix _ or .) as base components in order to simplify large, complex components. We intended ‚Äì in some specific cases ‚Äì to offer regular components as templates, that a designer would then have to detach and work with a bunch of base components to build the desired design.
What we have come to realize with this approach, however, is that these non-published components don‚Äôt receive updates from the library when they are updated in the main library.
Is this intended behaviour?
We basically have the option to simply publish these base components as regular components, but that of course would mean cluttering up the assets overview with a bunch of modular components.
User: hi, Raphael. our team is also facing the same issue for a while. Have you or your team figured out the workaround for this issue? I wish Figma can solve this issue fundamentally. @Josh thank you
Summary: Users are facing issues with non-published components in Figma not receiving updates from the main library, making it difficult to work with complex designs. They are considering publishing these base components as regular components but are concerned about cluttering the assets overview.

Text:
User: 
Describe the problem your experiencing and how your idea helps solve this
When you create an autolayout frame, it always defaults to 10px. Many design systems call for an 8px grid and in many cases, users don‚Äôt want ANY padding especially where edge-to-edge designs are concerned.
Ask questions to bring the community into the conversation
What are everyone‚Äôs thoughts about the following solutions?:
Default autolayout padding based on the big nudge amount in your settings
Allow for tokenization of padding/margin grids and offer up autolayout parameters based upon those tokens
Allow users to override the padding to 0px at the creation of the autolayout frame by using an alternative key command like ctrl+shift+a (command on mac)

User: Fastest way I found to apply auto layout with 0 paddings: 
Select object ‚Üí option+cmd+G ‚Üí shift+A
User: Actually, even faster: Select object ‚Üí cmd+G ‚Üí shift+A
Summary: Users discuss the issue of autolayout frames in Figma defaulting to 10px padding, which is not suitable for all design systems. They suggest solutions like basing default padding on the big nudge amount in settings, allowing tokenization of padding/margin grids, and using alternative key commands for 0px padding. Some users share their methods for applying auto layout with 0 padding quickly.

Text:
User: Miro is enabling a platform in which multiple users can consume content (created by teams) and contribute. 
I like all the features built to make that collaboration more efficient
User: I like the real time collaboration capabilities (value), I like the community aspect of Miro (e.g. free templates that speed up your work), I like the easiness and simplicity of the tool (usability)
User: I have mixed feelings about being a one-stop shop for everything a designer needs 
(PowerPoint, digital, whiteboard, design capabilities) and the fact the miro is not excelling in any of the areas. 
The highest benefit from the value proposition is the light-way collaboration aspect and how the tool is optimized for that (everyone can use it) 
At the same time, I appreciate some design capabilities, so I don't need to be jumping from tool to tool until all the concept is ready to be "migrated" to an execution tool (like Figma)
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's real-time collaboration features, community aspect, and ease of use. However, they have mixed feelings about it being a one-stop shop for designers, as it doesn't excel in any specific area. They value its lightweight collaboration aspect and some design capabilities, but still need to use execution tools like Figma.

Text:
User: It allows me to put all the pieces of my project in one place, so nothing gets lost. When you have an evolving project with research and numerous iterations it helps to be able to see all the info in one place and makes it easier for others to understand the full picture. 
 
I also use miro to share out work and do critiques. It is easy to have collaborators follow me on the board while I am presenting. I will generally share my screen while presenting, but it can be hard to see small details so having others in the board helps with this. There are comment and sticky notes available for peers to leave feedback too.
User: The board is endless and I can fill it with as much content as I want. There is a timer and you can set yourself to be followed around the board which makes critiques easier. It is extremely easy to add arrow connections. Overall, it's simple and easy to use.
User: Miro has cool features that are somewhat hidden so I didn't realize they existed for awhile. Because boards can fill up easily it helps to share a link for a frame directly and it can be done, but it's hidden behind a meatball menu. There are stickers, which come in handy, but are hidden behind a plus on the sidebar.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's endless space and easy collaboration features, making it an intuitive and visual platform for various tasks. However, they face difficulties with loading times when boards have many images and elements, suggesting a need for improved performance to support extensive collaboration.

User: There are so many great features about Notion, but also quite a few missed ones.
I love all the different database styles and how easy it is to change from one to another or link them to another page, but on the iPad it‚Äôs incredibly frustrating to see so much wasted screen real estate. There‚Äôs absolutely no way to change the column sizes on any database view on mobile devices. When I have a column that‚Äôs just a checkbox, that‚Äôs bad. Half my screen is empty space instead of the data I need to see.
Great app in terms of logging data, but this seems like a key feature that should not have slipped through the cracks‚Ä¶
Summary: User loves using Notion as a database setup and self-management tool across all their devices, but finds the iOS app frustrating due to formatting issues and lack of fluidity. They suggest improving the iOS app to make it more efficient and fluid.

Text:
User: The ability to quickly collaborate on user flows and audit our product with non-designers has been made super quick with the use of FigJam. We are also utilizing FigJam for sprint retros, which allows other roles to become power users of FigJam, benefitting our team using the tool for different purposes and not having another learning curve.
User: I like the speed at which I can collaborate with my teammates for a variety of topics. I spend most of my time using the timer for timebox ceratin conversations around audit and design decisions which we use FigJam for. Additionally, creating user flows within FigJam has been tremendously helpful.
User: Currently, while components are available within FigJam, there isn't an easy way to visibly pull in the components without copying them over from a design file. Additionally, if I want to scale components I've copied into a FigJam, they can not be manipulated, and thus I spend more time jumping back and forth through files rather than having a focused conversation around review/feedback within FigJam.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam's quick collaboration features for user flows and sprint retros, allowing non-designers to become power users. They enjoy the timer for timeboxing conversations and find creating user flows helpful. However, they face challenges with components, as there is no easy way to pull them in from design files, and scaling copied components is not possible, leading to more time spent switching between files.

Text:
User: Project time line and deliverables. The Miro board captures deliverables per stakeholder and when, setting up the expectations. The timeline is also important for project reach and target goals. 
The flexibility allows collaborative input, effort, etc. on processes we are not aware of.
User: Accessible and easy to use. Easy for collaboration. 
Can track changes and revert changes by looking through history. 
Many pathways to build a project from start to finish and a way to organize strategy.
User: Large Miro board(s) may take time to load. Slow page upload would display a blurry board. 
Comments are timestamped and call callout stakeholders. 
Some setup are not locked, so some users may unintentionally move the setup.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro as their top choice for collaboration with clients, as it allows real-time feedback, process documentation, and easy onboarding. It is particularly useful for remote teams and different time zones. However, users face issues with size capacity, slow performance with too many screenshots, messy boards, and minor formatting problems.

Text:
User: People often ask me for good examples of executive communication: let's talk about @joshm, the CEO of @browsercompany. ‚Üì
(And the intelligent and underrated use of YouTube for a business) <STRICT_LINK>
User: Its particularity? He chose as a social network to express himself... YouTube. Uncommon.
Concretely, @browsercompany has a channel with 20k subscribers and 2 types of videos:
- the culture and vision of the company
- tutorials and advice for its users
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: We will mainly focus on the first category, the one in which @joshm is personally involved.
In terms of form, these videos are YouTube-friendly, that is to say:
- exclusive (no balanced body videos on all channels)
- 10-20 minutes
- with a chapter
User: There are 2 formats that I particularly like:
1) its Q&A in early 2023 to report and answer, for example, the question of its business model... with embedded graphs and dataviz. 72k views, 3rd channel video.
<STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: What is interesting is that this video starts from a tweet that he posted in early December, just before the 2nd meeting of the @browsercompany board... with the desire to be transparent and accountable to his users (‚Äúbuild in public‚Äù).
<STRICT_LINK>
User: And, hey presto, 2 weeks later, he answers it in this famous video:

Text:
User: Everyone: "Use @googledocs it's simple ‚Äì No use @evernote and @NotionHQ it's shared ‚Äì No do @RoamResearch it's serious ‚Äì No, use Apple Notes and Google Keep..."
Me: They ALL run INSIDE my @obsdmd ü§£üòé ü§Ø
Be a rebel üëá <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd Obsidian is built on a technology called "Electron".
Electron is just a Chrome browser, that runs like an app on your desktop.
So essentially Obsidian = Snazzy Browser for your notes.
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd This allows us - in theory - to browse any website.
(In practice it works 80% of the time, hence I couldn't get it to work with @tana_inc or @logseq )
While Obsidian does not support that out of the box - with a plugin it's easy. Let's get to it!
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Go to Settings > Community Plugins. Search for "Custom Frames"
Install it. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq In the Obsidian settings there will be now a new entry "Custom Frames" (towards end of your list)
Find the "New Frame" button and click it. A Frame is such a browser window, that we can use to access all of the services.
The new entry will appear in the list above the button. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Configure your Frame
1 Set the URL (<STRICT_LINK>, <STRICT_LINK> or <STRICT_LINK> - copy & paste from Browser)
2 ‚úÖ "open in center" to open the service like a tab (otherwise it's in the sidebar)
3 ‚úÖ "Add Ribbon Icon" to display a side icon. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Specify the icon you want to use.
Go to <STRICT_LINK> and find an icon you like.
Copy paste it's name into the "icon" textfield in previous step. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq RESTART OBSIDIAN
Your new ribbon icon should now appear on the left.
You will have to log in to Google/Apple/Evernote/... the first time. But then it will remember you. (Just like in a browser)
On the top right you find a few buttons, to reload the page. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq Summary:
‚ñ∫ Download "Custom Frames" plugin
‚ñ∫ Add frames to any website, as Obsidian is technically a browser.
‚ñ∫ This technique works with ANY website. So you can integrate google calendar, facebook or a todo app into obsidian!
User: @Artifexx @googledocs @evernote @NotionHQ @RoamResearch @obsdmd @tana_inc @logseq @SaveToNotion #thread
Summary: User loves the app but is experiencing issues with not being able to access their notes, which they need.

User: It helps to organize and frame work in hybrid teams. 
It engages teams working online. 
It helps you track your progress and put a lot of information in one place in a clear way.
User: It gives endless possibilities for variations of building meetings in my work (project manager). 
 
Team integration, brainstorming, or working on a lean canvas business. 
 
You can always surprise the participants of the meeting.
User: Sometimes it's a bit of fun to share a board with other participants so they can edit/vote. 
 
In the end it always works out, but the process is probably not perfect.
Summary: The user appreciates the ability to organize their project in one place and share it with collaborators, as well as the ability to add comments and sticky notes. They also appreciate the endless board feature and the ability to follow themselves around the board for critiques. The user finds the platform easy to use and appreciates the hidden features.

Text:
User: Miro solves the visualization problem for my clients by showing how my solutions (I sell software) work within their business models. Using Miro goes beyond the pre-sales process, as it also helps to diagram implementation processes, identifying the various technical and human aspects of the equation. 
 
While words go a long way, making a diagram and showing processes step-by-step make operations functional in my line of work. It's also great to build business plans for teams, as it allows everyone to collaborate without the hindrance of size limitations in a presentation or a document.
User: Miro provides an all-hands approach to workflow design, where my team can not only collaborate and operate effectively, but I can also work my way through various business, marketing, and sales demands. 
 
From collaborations to creating operational plans to designing workflows and chat journeys for my clients, Miro is an all-encompassing tool to drag-and-drop design. It's easy to use and intuitive, giving users a simple approach to anything they desire to illustrate, with pre-designed templates that make working a breeze.
User: Sometimes the scroll methodology can be a hassle, specially when you're first starting to use it. While it does impact usability perception, it's not as much as a hassle once you get the grip of how navigation works within Miro.
Summary: Users find Miro helpful for visualizing solutions, diagramming implementation processes, and facilitating collaboration in various business aspects. It offers an intuitive drag-and-drop design with pre-designed templates, making it easy to use. However, some users find the scroll methodology challenging initially, affecting usability perception until they become familiar with the navigation.

Text:
User: I use Miro for mind maps, team whiteboard sessions, sprint and product retrospectives, collaborative wireframing with Experience designers, and could go on with this list. It has application with a number of product management tasks.
User: I use Miro for a long list of important product management activities. It has a nice set of wireframing tools and is easy for someone who wants to sketch out ideas without using advanced design tools like Figma of Invision. I also use it to collaborate with stakeholders within the company when framing problems. The team there regularly makes product enhancements that make the tool even better.
User: The organizational structure of the tool leaves a bit to be desired. This may be user error more than anything but, sometimes, after creating several different boards on a similar topic, it's hard to organize them into a folder structure that makes it easy to find the board I'm looking for.
Summary: The user finds Miro useful for product management tasks, including collaborative wireframing, mind mapping, and sprint retrospectives. They appreciate the ease of use and the collaborative features. However, they find it difficult to organize their boards into a folder structure and find the organizational structure lacking.

Text:
User: Figma helps brainstorm ideas collaboratively with Figjam, where they have many tools like a whiteboard, mindmaps, empathy mapping, and more this helps me and the team solve design problems more efficiently in one place. It also has the option to comment on the designs, which allows me to get feedback from other stakeholders quickly and is very convenient.
User: Figma can be used for UI designing a web application, mobile application and other digital experiences. Figma is a great application to prototype and test your designs with real users to get feedback before the development. Figma has powerful prototyping tools that can help creating great product experiences and has a lot of community resources
User: A downside of Figma is that you cannot use it without an internet connection it can be an issue when working remotely with unreliable internet. its a bit difficult to understand for a biggner
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's collaborative features, such as Figjam, which offers tools like whiteboards, mindmaps, and empathy mapping for efficient problem-solving. They also value the ability to comment on designs and receive feedback quickly. Figma is useful for UI design, prototyping, and testing, with powerful tools and community resources. However, the lack of offline functionality and a potentially steep learning curve for beginners are drawbacks.

Text:
User: FigJam is solving the problem of communicating about technical system layouts with people who are not accustomed to verbally processing such layouts.
User: FigJam makes creating diagrams and flowcharts very easy! In my job, I often need visual aids to explain technical systems, and I need to create those aids more or less on the fly. FigJam has been a lifesaver in that regard.
User: My only complaints about FigJam are very small, the biggest of which is that I wish it were simpler to create multiple wire attachment points on one side of a shape, using a snap-to-grid alignment. There are times when I need 4+ discrete wires running into one side of a shape, and I don't necessarily want them all going to the central point.
Summary: User appreciates FigJam for its ease of creating diagrams and flowcharts, especially for communicating technical systems. They wish it had a feature to create multiple wire attachment points on one side of a shape, using a snap-to-grid alignment.

Text:
User: 1/ a month ago i asked ChatGPT to help me cultivate more discipline. had been feeling chaotic, unfocused, and just not like myself.
gave me 10 things to do. it worked.
big fan of AI as personal coach. no more reading airport books. just a few bullet points w minimal filler.
User: 2/ the list was:
- declutter your environment
- prioritize your tasks
- set clear goals - limit screen time
- learn to say no
- automate and delegate
- cultivate a minimalist mindset
- simplify your finances
- create routines
- practice mindfulness
User: 3/ i ported this list into @NotionHQ and then used their embedded AI feature to expand each list item into practical steps with examples
i then made daily action items to help me actually *do* these things every day
and then i blocked time on my calendar to do the action items
User: @Melt_Dem @NotionHQ impressive
Summary: User finds Notion to be a great app for collaboration and brainstorming, but has experienced numerous bugs and glitches, including issues with adding checkboxes and creating to-do lists. They also mention that the app is slow and buggy, and the AI tool is not useful for their needs.

Text:
User: Miro reduces boring presentation slides where the user only listens to the presenter talk. Miro allows engagement and input from other users. This makes meetings much more productive.
User: I love that Miro has an extensive collection of templates that make creating boards for meetings and discussions easy. Miro also makes collaboration and team engagement easy. I can give all my team members access to my board right before the meeting and allow engagement.
User: It is not necessarily bad, but Miro's extensive collection of templates and possibilities sometimes makes it harder to use it for simple tasks like jotting down meeting notes.
Summary: Users find Miro to be an effective collaboration tool that helps run meetings smoothly, reduces manual work, and saves costs. They appreciate its user-friendly interface, available templates, sharing capabilities, and affordability. Miro has positively impacted their workplace, and they have no significant dislikes about the tool.

Text:
User: It helps me bring together disparate pieces of information into a central repository of information - single source of truth.
User: Unlimited board size is a big positive for me. So many other applications simply grind to halt, under the weight of extensive UX research artifacts
User: Perhaps my biggest gripe would be the inability to import documents previously created in Lucid chart.
Summary: The product is helping the User to quickly analyse large amounts of data, identify correlations and gain new insights, all within a visually appealing format. Users appreciate the product's simplicity and intuitiveness, as well as its unlimited whiteboard space which is great for collaboration, forming new ideas, and making insights. The User finds that the product can become clunky when uploading multiple files, and some PDFs are difficult to read. Additionally, the User has to continually log in to their work account if it has been inactive for a short while.

Text:
User: A little bit about us. Why ‚ÄúSecondBrain‚Äù? Inside thread üßµ‚¨áÔ∏è
User: SecondBrain is a concept that is booming recently, given the boom in creating second digital brains. For this reason, we want to get closer to the Spanish-speaking community and create a community around #productividad and #herramientas #digitales.
User: But what are second digital brains? They are tools that allow you to manage and organize your information, thoughts and tasks. They're like an extension of your brain, allowing you to store and retrieve information efficiently.
User: Examples of second digital brains are Evernote, Notion, Trello and Todoist. These tools allow you to create notes, to-do lists and projects in an efficient and organized way. We are specialized in @NotionHQ, but we will not leave out other solutions.
Summary: User is excited about the new features in Notion, including the ability to create a new note from scratch, and the ability to add a new note to a folder.

Text: User: The calendar on Notion has been my saviour throughout my undergraduate degree due to the ability to visualize my days and what tasks I need to complete. I am extremely disappointed that the calendar view has changed on the mobile app (on both iPhone and iPad) so it only shows dots on the days I have a task, not the tasks themselves anymore. I am considering another planning application due to this change of not being able to see my tasks at a glance. Please revert the calendar view; there were no issues with it previously, so I do not understand why it needed to change to something less convenient.
Summary: User is disappointed with the change in the calendar view on the mobile app, which only shows dots on days with tasks instead of showing the tasks themselves. They are considering switching to another planning application due to this change.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

Text:
User: A diverse and easily accessible whiteboard tool for use during meetings or to collaborate on early-stage ideas. 
Collaborative brain dump before meeting to introduce topics or after meetings to record toughts.
User: Easy to create and share dashboards. 
Tagging features are nice. 
Drag and drop file features work well. 
Live sessions are easy to start and work well as a collaborative space to work during meetings.
User: Integrations with other apps are surface-level. 
There is no baked-in intelligence to the organization of connected objects. 
Large boards become very slow and hard to use.
Summary: The user appreciates the diverse and accessible whiteboard tool for use during meetings and collaboration, as well as the tagging features and drag-and-drop file features. They also appreciate the ease of creating and sharing dashboards and the integration with other apps. However, they find the organization of connected objects to be surface-level and the large boards to be slow and hard to use.

Text:
User: Hi all, I am working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from our team library. Through research I think the way is to first use Figma REST API to get the keys of styles from our library file, and the use figma.importStyleByKeyAsync() to import the style. However, the issue is, this requires me to put my Access token in the plugin, and I don‚Äôt want to. Is there a way for plugin to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin?
Or are there any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin? Thanks a lot!!!
User: You have several ways:
Users will create their own personal access tokens, which will be inserted into the input field of your plugin.
Users will open the necessary library files, run the plugin there to get the necessary keys, return to another file to continue working.
Hardcode the keys in the plugin.
3.1. Or add these keys to, for example, a JSON file that you or anyone else can keep updating as needed.

User: Hi, thanks for the reply! I see, I will give option 3 a try, to hard code the keys in the plugin, and keep the plugin for internal use first. The other ways seem to have some extra steps for people who uses plugin.
Summary: The user is working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from their team library. They are looking for a way to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin, or any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin.

Text:
User: It has a larger workspace than what I typically use in Microsoft Powerpoint. Allows for a much larger workspace to create in and can shift easily between different sections.
User: Miro provides a great whiteboarding experience for our teams as they work together with others in a virtual strategic planning environment. I love that we can set up custom boards, or pull in examples from others as well and modify them to meet our needs. There are a lot of great features that I still need to explore to make sure I'm getting the most of out of this tool.
User: I still feel like there is a lot to learn about how best to use this system. I've sat through a few trainings, but it's not always easy to know how to use the various features within the tool, and how to help others take advantage of these features. The connection to our agency planning platform works, but always requires us to log in before we can access within that system. Because the Miro access shuts off after just a few hours, it requires me to log in frequently to make sure it continues to work successfully in our system as I'm setting up a session, or trying to work on sessions with others. It would be great if we could log in once and have it work consistently if I'm on the same computer or at least be good for 24 hours of access.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's large workspace and whiteboarding capabilities for virtual strategic planning. However, they find it challenging to learn and utilize all the features and face frequent login issues when connecting to their agency planning platform. They suggest improving the login process for better user experience

Text:
User: Serving as a one-stop-shop for designing and planning an intensive leadership course; delivering the course itself (various group and individual activities will be performed in a Miro board); team collaboration and content visualization.
User: Nearly limitless toolset coupled with intuitive functionality; plays nicely with links, pasted and imported resources, and videos; allows you to dump, organize and map all the various pieces of a vast (or simple) project; offers amazing opportunities for team / group collaboration; insanely useful tool not just for planning but for presentation as well - can also easily be leveraged as a (FUN!) teaching tool. New features and integrations are continually added, so even if something isn't possible or easy now, you can bet it will be added soon.
User: While intuitive, there can be a bit of a learning curve for new users (for instance, learning how to pull oneself across the board versus grabbing and moving board items). Board owners must be thoughtful in locking or hiding items they don't want moved or deleted ahead of time to ensure visitors don't inadvertently mess up your masterpiece. There are still some hard-to-explain quirks - for instance, some URL links (for whatever reason) show up as just links when pasted, whereas others show up as a summary snapshot of the resource.
Summary: User is a teacher and uses Notion to create interactive lessons for their students, mentioning that it's a great tool for their students to use.

Text:
User: Miro helps us have one place for designs, significant milestones, and team collaboration. It enables work globally and a quicker location to go back and find previous decisions and collaborations.
User: Visual data sharing! It is a great place to put pictures and ideas and map processes. It is like having a visual management board in the traditional "war room" but digital so anyone can access it, and it is saved. Being able to use templates is also huge for getting teams started
User: It does not integrate well with some apps or display items. Tables are still not ideal, and it is often better to work in excel and copy-paste your data into Miro. Scaling can also be a little clunky, where it can be harder to keep things visible at a high enough level but also readable when sharing sections. 
 
The menus and controls are also not super intuitive. It definitely takes time to bring new members up to speed.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its centralized design collaboration, visual data sharing, and template features. However, they face challenges with app integration, table functionality, and scaling. Additionally, the interface is not intuitive, making it difficult for new members to learn quickly.

Text:
User: Documenting information in diagrams/maps helps the team visualize complex information architecture and align on foundations. 
Sketching ideas in low fidelity increases our time to value at early design stages by allowing us to validate concepts before investing in high-fidelity visualizations. Having a space to collaborate on these low-fidelity designs makes the validation process more efficient and consolidates the thinking. 
Using FigJam to share information with less design-savvy coworkers offers a friendly way to collect and organize inspiration or audits.
User: FigJam makes it easy for me to sketch ideas, map information in diagrams, and collaborate with others. There's just enough design functionality to bring concepts to life without getting lost in the details. Additional tools make workshops or brainstorming sessions fun and easy for my non-designer colleagues to pick up. I love having access to community-made templates and graphics for inspiration.
User: I wish participants could be invited to edit files without having a licensed seat. I have run interactive workshops with participants who do not regularly use the tool, and getting folks proper access in these cases is a bit tricky. In cases where I have colleagues who need temporary access to files, I use open sessions, but need to reopen them each time the colleague requires edit access.
Summary: Users find FigJam helpful for visualizing complex information, sketching ideas in low fidelity, and collaborating with non-designer colleagues. However, they wish there was an option to invite participants to edit files without requiring a licensed seat, as it can be challenging to grant temporary access for interactive workshops.

Summary: Users appreciate FigJam as a one-stop shop for collaboration, especially in remote-first environments. They use it for various purposes, including ideation, flow mapping, and user research planning. Users also value the ongoing updates that improve usability, performance, and speed, but suggest additional customization options, such as background colors and styles.

Text:
User: Provides an alternative to project stakeholders who would normally sift through various Excel and Word docs for project onboarding and collaboration. 
 
Makes it easy to gain measurable feedback (votes and post-it notes) quickly. Makes remote working incredibly easy.
User: Providing a central source of truth with various mediums to share information and bringing stakeholders up-to-speed. 
 
Excellent for project collaboration, feedback sessions and brainstorming. 
 
Love being able to easily add images, texts, slides and post-it notes. 
 
Great templates!
User: Sometimes hard to navigate around boards. Functions can be glitchy at times. 
 
When inviting new users to group sessions, they can be overwhelmed by the range of functions.
Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: Autolayout with hug content on width or height should resize to zero (or whatever the applied padding is) when all content is hidden. Now when all contents are hidden it remains as the dimensions of the last visible item it had. Anyone have a workaround or know if there is a way to avoid this bug?
User: I am also experiencing this. The container with auto layout has its height set to ‚ÄúHug contents‚Äù with no vertical spacing, and no vertical padding, and child element heights are also ‚ÄúHug contents‚Äù.
However, the issue seems to be from what occurs when you hide layers because their height automatically changes to ‚ÄúFixed‚Äù. BUT even just deleting the layers at once still leaves the container at its previous height despite still being set to ‚ÄúHug contents‚Äù.
Something‚Äôs up with this.
Summary: Users are experiencing an issue with Figma's auto layout feature, where the container does not resize to zero when all content is hidden. The problem seems to be related to hidden layers having their height automatically changed to "Fixed." Users are seeking a workaround or solution to this bug.

Text:
User: Miro supports our team as a platform for digital collaboration -- it facilitates hybrid work, transitioning our information from the remote environment into the office and back.
User: Having worked in mixed creative, product, and engineering teams, I find Miro an effective tool for visual thinking and documentation. The tools are accessible for newcomers to adopt but scale well for power users to leverage templates and tools that adapt to content and user needs across a project or workflow's stages.
User: Whether at the board-level, or the team-level, it's up to individuals and their teams to manage board sprawl and keep things organized. Depending on the information guidelines of your organization, there may be some friction involved in ensuring that the right individuals are granted the correct level of access to certain types of content in a timely manner.
Summary: The user appreciates Miro as a platform for digital collaboration, facilitating hybrid work between remote and office environments. They find the tools accessible for newcomers but scale well for power users to leverage templates and tools that adapt to content and user needs across a project or workflow's stages. The user also mentions the importance of managing board sprawl and ensuring the right individuals have access to the right content in a timely manner.

User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!

User: I‚Äôm wondering if we are close enough to see a drastic shift in design tools moving away from the top bar, sidebar, canvas, sidebar model. There‚Äôre examples in this direction, eg Play, but that‚Äôs like the other extreme. Probably the sweet spot is in the somewhere in the middle.
User: Hierarchy and organisation can maintain their association with the tree model but parts of the props can move to each and every pixel in the canvas?
User: Another way to get inspired and think about this is looking at builders, people who physically build stuff like roads, gardens, houses, electrical installations etc. There are certain patterns emerging like specialized tools, big or small hacks when lacking the tools‚Ä¶
User: They carry a bunch of general tools with them, have extra tools nearby and focus on speed or/and quality. When in multiplayer mode, each person has a specialized position or supports the main builder with orchestrated moves. Their canvas is always messy to the eye.
User: I think a way for @figma to speed up Workflows, especially as they want to onboard new users globally, would be shortcuts for plugins and a clean up and redesign of all the helpful stuff added everywhere the last year. Same idea for other design tools.
Summary: The user suggests that design tools like Figma could benefit from a shift away from the traditional top bar, sidebar, and canvas model. They propose drawing inspiration from builders who use specialized tools and focus on speed and quality. The user recommends implementing shortcuts for plugins and redesigning the interface to improve workflows and attract new users globally.
