Text:
User: 10 tools I use every week as a product manager:
User: 1. @asana 
This is our tool of choice when it comes to organizing work throughout the company.
Simple but powerful, it does everything we need to keep our teams organized and our work visible.
User: 2. @MiroHQ 
I've been using Miro for everything lately: product briefs, data analyses, brainstorming, mockups. 
It's a tool that can do a ton of things well, and helps make visuals much easier to consume vs. a document.
User: 3. Looker
We've used Looker for several years, and it's our go-to spot for building reports and dashboards.
Our core team dashboard and pricing/conversion dashboards both live here, and I check each daily.
User: 4. @Amplitude_HQ 
For product analytics, we use Amplitude. Looker gives me high-level business metrics; Amplitude gives me the details.
We use this for understanding the user behavior behind the metrics.
User: 5. @CrazyEgg & @hotjar 
Two tools that do similar things: we use one for our website and one for our app.
These give us even more qualitative data behind our metrics, with things like heat maps and screen recordings.
User: 6. @SlackHQ 
I barely use email any more, and while the Slack overload is real, it does enable fast async communication among our teams, wherever we are.
It's also great for consolidating notifications from other tools (Asana, Google Docs, etc.) if you set up the integrations.
User: 7. @Officevibe 
Our HR team implemented this tool, and as PM, it gives me a bunch of metrics about how my team is doing.
It gives me some data backing for how the team is feeling, and shows me when I might need to spend time on morale.
User: 8. @figma 
Miro is great for lo-fi prototypes and brainstorming, but at some point it moves to Figma.
This is where we build prototypes for user testing, comment on designs, and ultimately deliver the final spec to developers.
Summary: The user works a 9-5 job and runs a freelance design business, using various tools to stay organized. They use Todoist, Notion, Clockify, SumUp, Typefully, Miro, Slack, Gmail, Google Calendar, and Apple apps. They have not heard of superhuman yet, but may create a thread to discuss the pros and cons of each tool.

Text:
User: Miro helps to keep track of user feedback alongside screenshots of the product. It also allows for the team to collaborate in one space. It's very efficient!
User: Intuitive features, pleasing aesthetics, and the ability to collaborate with multiple users makes doing tasks in Miro more rewarding than other software.
User: While it's possible to separate projects into multiple Miro boards, it would be nice if there was a more built-in nesting feature. Adding a lot of screenshots can make Miro slower to load or it's more difficult to maintain resolution.
Summary: User praises Miro for its intuitive features, pleasing aesthetics, and ability to collaborate with multiple users, making it more rewarding than other software. They also appreciate the ability to separate projects into multiple boards, but suggest adding a built-in nesting feature to improve loading speed and maintain resolution.

Text: User: You cannot purchase the AI feature through the subscription that is built in in the iOS app. Instead, you need to go into the webpage and enter all the information, although I have already subscribed it to other AI products, I don‚Äôt mind a easy way to pay for a subscription for this app as it could be easier to work with in terms of writing. However, if you want me to enter everything on your website and with the steep pricing, it would be too much trouble for me. I do not need that iOS subscription for the pro features, I only tried to use the AI feature to write.
Summary: User finds the AI feature in the iOS app difficult to purchase and prefers to use the webpage for subscription payments, as it is easier to work with and less expensive. However, they are not interested in the iOS subscription for the pro features and only want to use the AI feature for writing.

Text: User: I am surprised by this app because it has a really wide range of functionalities. But where I find it really superb is when it comes to taking notes on articles. Everything is easily organized in order to better find your way around. In addition, the AI present in the app is quite effective, which is appreciable.
Summary: User is surprised by the app's wide range of functionalities and appreciates its ability to organize notes on articles, with AI being effective.

Text:
User: I primarily use it for early creative processes, to allow back and forth work with teams on the other side of the planet. There are also language difficulties, so a visual tool is ideal. For me personally, it's about developing characters and storylines with cross-disciplinary teams.
User: It is stable and allows for quick whiteboarding of ideas and back and forth iterations quickly.
User: Notes aren't ideal; hard to notice them and to go back and view old notes and their resolutions. Google Docs has a better system. Also, the restrictions on the unpaid version can make collaboration very difficult, especially in a large organization. Last issue is security, and protecting IP.
Summary: The user primarily uses Figma for early creative processes and collaboration with international teams, appreciating its stability and quick whiteboarding capabilities. However, they find the notes feature lacking compared to Google Docs, and face challenges with collaboration restrictions on the unpaid version and security concerns for protecting intellectual property.

User: I looked for it, but I couldn‚Äôt find something similar, so sorry if it‚Äôs a duplicate.
It would be great if in the auto layout mode the numeric variables (paddings and spacing) could be set also from a static variable, like it was a style.
It would be awesome in a design system perspective!
User: This topic was automatically closed 90 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
Summary: Users discuss the issue of autolayout frames in Figma defaulting to 10px padding, which is not suitable for all design systems. They suggest solutions like basing default padding on the big nudge amount in settings, allowing tokenization of padding/margin grids, and using alternative key commands for 0px padding. Some users share their methods for applying auto layout with 0 padding quickly.

Text: User: The app is amazing, I use it every day of my life, it helps a lot, but when Notion AI came along, I immediately started using it many times. The links on the site do not work in the pricing section, nothing works in the application (I have IOS, I don't have a computer) either. As a rule, the site just throws me at my notion. I wrote to the support email, I was answered with a message like I was completely stupid, saying, go to the pricing section, find notification ai and follow the steps. Text:
User: The @figma community's feedback is gold.
It helped me squash bugs in my wildly popular widget (32k installations in eight months!) and create a super powerful to-do tool right in Figma.
<STRICT_LINK>
User: But there's no shortcut to communicating with users. üòî
When troubleshooting, I used to waste precious time searching for the problem instead of reaching out directly.
I tried transferring communication to an external source, but it wasn't always user-friendly.
User: I'm still on the lookout for ways to quickly connect with users or catch bug reports.
Maybe the growth of the Figma community will prioritise this issue, and there will be a solution for creators like me.
Will you help us out, @figma?
Summary: A user appreciates the Figma community's feedback, which helped improve their popular widget and create a powerful to-do tool. However, they struggle with efficiently communicating with users for troubleshooting and are seeking a quicker way to connect with users or receive bug reports. They hope Figma will prioritize this issue and provide a solution for creators.

Text:
User: If your @figma files are low on memory and you've taken lengths to reduce file size but don't see an increase in memory, it's likely your version history. Fix by publishing the library, CUT and paste everything into a new file, then publish the new file.
User: @katiecooperco @figma Does this preserve the linked component instances? It's a brilliant tip!
User: @SamIam_Designs @katiecooperco @figma i'd expect the connections to be protected so long as you _cut_ and paste!
docs, if it's helpful: <STRICT_LINK>
User: @AlPackah @SamIam_Designs @figma Yes! I‚Äôve done it many times. cut cut cut
Summary: A user suggests that if Figma files are low on memory despite efforts to reduce file size, the issue may be related to version history. They recommend fixing this by publishing the library, cutting and pasting everything into a new file, and then publishing the new file. This method is confirmed to preserve linked component instances.

User: I'm not saying this has actually happened yet (still looking into it), but beware when installing Wordpress plugins for AI products like ChatGPT - I installed a whole heap of plugins to see where they were at, and then didn't use them for a month, and this morning I got an email‚Ä¶ <STRICT_LINK>

User: Also, I have been recovering from surgery and these usage records show usage that I am 100% certain didn't come from me, because I installed those plugins prior to April 3, and the keys show last usage of 19 April. Have obviously revoked.

User: The only other thing I can think of is that @NotionHQ might be doing API calls, but I highly doubt. That is the only thing I have installed on my machine but I haven't connected with Make etc yet. Anyway, just a heads up to everyone to be very careful with these things - scammers‚Ä¶

Text:
User: Hi. I‚Äôm new to Figma, and i‚Äôm currently struggling with this trouble.
So, I‚Äôm trying to recreate the www.pandaexpress.com website, and i‚Äôm with the banner part.
 
 
 <STRICT_LINK>
 
 
My steps are:
Create the base structure
Group it
Duplicate it
Adjust the circle and image for second asset
Make it interactive from prototype tab
Create a component set.
On the Design Frame, i add the component and it went crazy with the line that dragged into the previous asset frame. And when i present it, none of my clicks works with the banner. Ive cross checked the prototyped, and I‚Äôve selected the ‚Äúon click.‚Äù
Can anyone please correct me on which step did I do wrong?
Thankyou.
User: Only link the two variants together within the component. Don‚Äôt also link the component or any of its variants to the instance of that component.
User: Another thing might be the way you created the component. I‚Äôd make the two states first, then make them both components, then select them both and click ‚ÄúCombine as variants‚Äù in the right panel, then prototype the variants together within the component.
User: this solve my problem !!! thankyou very much !!
Summary: A user was struggling with creating an interactive banner in Figma while recreating the Panda Express website. They received advice to only link the two variants together within the component and to create the two states first, then make them both components, combine as variants, and prototype the variants together within the component. This solution resolved the user's issue.

User: Miro is creating a low-cost space for our dispersed teams and clients to meet virtually and unlock both key questions and solutions driving toward our project goals and milestones.
User: Miro is a great collaborative tool, and one that we use both internally and with our external clients. We have formulated complex business objectives through workshops, and Miro is such a great tool to replace the whiteboard / sticky note in-person sessions when you have extremely dispersed teams.
User: Miro is not highly intuitive for me just in terms of mouse / keyboard functions. I hate the thought of needing to take time to figure out if I can change these settings, and it would be really cool to almost have different preset options (almost like a preferred controller setup for a gaming system).
Summary: The user appreciates the low-cost collaborative tool Miro for its ability to facilitate virtual meetings and solve complex business objectives. They find the tool intuitive but wish it had preset options for mouse and keyboard functions, similar to a preferred controller setup for gaming systems.

Text:
User: Miro helps me work remotely and more efficiently. It provides an online, real-time workspace for my entire team that helps us collaborate efficiently no matter where we're located.
User: My favorite thing about Miro is how it simplifies remote collaboration with its comprehensive collection of features, including collaboration, text editing, and visual effects. It has an easy learning curve that allows all users to be up and running quickly with no more than a few minutes of training. In addition, I appreciate having access to the library of pre-built templates that save me countless hours when coordinating geographically dispersed teams. These benefits make Miro an industry standard for enabling effective communication between remote workers on collaborative projects.
User: I find that the complexity of MIRO's features can make it difficult to learn, but once you understand its capabilities and features, there is no limit to the tasks you can accomplish. Although a free account does not have all the same options as a paid account - such as private boards - with careful collaboration between team members using different accounts, your project will still be successful.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its comprehensive features that simplify remote collaboration, easy learning curve, and pre-built templates. However, some users find the complexity of its features challenging to learn initially, and note limitations in the free account compared to paid accounts.

User: The collaboration element of the board. The ongoing development and new features Miro continues to release. The diversity of exercises or workshops that can be hosted in Miro. The ability to enable hybrid or fully remote teams to collaborate effectively.
User: For people who have not yet used an online whiteboarding tool, the navigation and basic features might take a bit of getting used to. However, this can be overcome with some basic training or youtube videos.
Summary: Users find Miro valuable for enabling real-time collaboration among distributed teams and appreciate its adaptability for various meetings and workshops. They also like the continuous development of new features. However, some users may need basic training or resources to get accustomed to the navigation and features of the online whiteboarding tool.

Text:
User: When working remote as a product manager, it can be tricky to get everyone on the same page. FigJam allows everyone to share a single space, and it truly feels like you're in the room together. I have used it in situations as the sole driver while sharing my screen with the team to get a quick diagram or mind map put together, and I have also used it collaboratively with my team as a digital whiteboard. You can bring people into FigJam and have them collaborating within minutes whether they are familiar with the tech or not.
User: Being able to join with several colleagues, throw together a quick brainstorm and work quickly has been great! I have used FigJam professionally to lay out calendar schedules, run retros, and run client workshops. It is even valuable to go back to your data and organize everything into a visually consumable map. This is a personal note, but I even used FigJam with my wife (who at the time was on a job away from our home) to lay out our entire wedding floor plan and seating chart!
User: The templates can feel a little daunting, I often can't find *exactly* what I wanted or was looking for, but usually a quick search online or asking colleagues leads me to finding a better template. That, or I just go through and make my own layout because it's just that easy!
Summary: Users find Figjam to be an effective collaboration tool for remote teams, enabling brainstorming and project planning in a single, consolidated space. It has successfully replaced in-person whiteboard sessions and is highly appreciated by users, with very few dislikes.

Text:
User: Hi there, I am currently laying the foundations for a Design Language System. At the same time another team is working on the first of a series of Apps. My intention is to take the components that they create for that first app and then add them to the design system, so we can re-use elements for all the future Apps
The DLS and the the first App will be created as two separate design files within the same project. My hope was that at various intervals I would be able to copy and paste content from the App into the DLS then publish the library from the DLS and get the other team to use the library swap feature to swap their local components with those from the DLS published library.
But my initial tests lead me to believe that this isn‚Äôt possible. It seems that you can only use library swap on two externally published libraries rather than an external library (the DLS) and a local library (the App). Is this the case?
If so, what is the suggested workflow in this situation?
Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Many thanks
User: This topic was automatically closed after 30 days. New replies are no longer allowed.
Summary: Three ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin are suggested: users creating personal access tokens, users opening library files, and hardcoding/updating keys in a JSON file.

User: Its really a heartbreaker that exporting the slices to pdf is not available in Figma. Sketch has it and it was working really great for us.
Some of our multinational stakeholders, whom we cannot insist to install or start an account for Figma or anything else, as they rely on pdf documents for design review or sharing with internal team. Sketch helped to convert the slices to pdf which was very light weight and compressible. When we moved to figma, the internal team as well few clients worked well with figma collaboration (same we did with Sketch too) and but the later ones didn‚Äôt. And now we are forced to go back to Sketch, as we understand that its the app that we could rely to accomplish all our requirements.
User: A post was merged into an existing topic: Export Slices to PDF
Summary: User is frustrated with the lack of PDF export from slices in Figma, as it requires additional workarounds for exporting assets. They also mention that exporting PDF from slices is not available in Sketch, which helped them with their mobile development needs. The user mentions that their multinational stakeholders prefer using PDF for design review and sharing with internal team. They also mention that Figma collaboration is not working well with their internal team, and they are forced to revert to Sketch for their needs.

Text:
User: We're a hybrid company and working in Product, we often need to have collaborative sessions across teams where some members are remote and some are in person. This is by far the best replacement for old-fashioned in-person whiteboarding with sticky notes, and it's even better because you can save it and easily access it later.
User: It's been conducive to facilitating collaboration on designs, whiteboarding, brainstorming, process reviews, and strategy sessions. Figjam's design makes it easy to use for a wide variety of scenarios. We've used it asynchronously to prep for a discussion as well as simultaneously in-meeting as a way to accomplish in-person whiteboarding-type conversations, especially when some participants are remote.
User: The UI took a little getting used to, and there was a short learning curve to figure out how to access different elements and add them to the page.
Summary: Users find Figjam to be an excellent replacement for traditional in-person whiteboarding, as it facilitates collaboration across remote and in-person teams in various scenarios, such as design, brainstorming, and strategy sessions. However, there is a slight learning curve to get accustomed to the UI and accessing different elements.

Text:
User: Miro gives us the ability to collaborate, teach, learn, share, and be in one place no matter where in the world we live. It is extremely valuable in these times where costs are of the utmost concern and we try to continue our ability to get together as teams to accomplish our goals.
User: I like the ability to customize and build the collaboration space that is most effective. I look through the templates and Miroverse to begin as inspiration and then build to support the goals of the session.
User: The structure for us to do multiple sessions within our company is due to the terms of our contract. It becomes a little prohibitive based on the number of people and days we need to be most effective.
Summary: The user finds Miro excellent for facilitating collaboration during workshops and team-based activities, praising its real-time collaboration capabilities, wide range of tools and templates, and rich media integration. However, they experience performance issues with large boards or many simultaneous users and feel that customization options can be restrictive.

Text: User: I really think this app is great for everything. The only problem I have is when you have too many workspaces then you have to pay up.

User: I don't dislike much about Miro - I always find little improvements to be done such as the canvas size why not start at 100 for all the work that we add and then people can zoom in and out and the center also! like a little mark to show the centre of the canvas

However, they face challenges in locating work on the canvas due to varying zoom levels and placement by team members. They suggest marking the center of the canvas and starting at 100% zoom for consistency.

Text:
User: Miro is an excellent and exceptional tool for myself and also my customers. 
It's an amazing tool for documentation and visual thinking. 
Allows teams from different locations to interact and share ideas.
User: Miro usability and flexibility is the reason why we decided to use it. 
It is simple and easy to adapt the application. 
It supports powerful tools i love most such as sticky notes, mapping, brainstorming, polls, etc. 
One can comfortably use it from any device as it supports mobile version, desktop version and browser version. 
Miro is not expensive compared to other alternatives out there.
User: One of the challenges is that sometimes navigation isn't good with zooming in and out and also browsing is a little bit cumbersome when there is too much content on the same board.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its usability, flexibility, and powerful tools like sticky notes, mapping, and brainstorming. It is suitable for remote teams and supports multiple devices. However, some users face challenges with navigation, particularly when zooming in and out or browsing boards with a lot of content.

Text:
User: It‚Äôs known the text line hight it‚Äôs a nightmare. However, I‚Äôm struggling with the text box hight even more with Figma Auto Layout.
image2966√ó1878 323 KB
image3896√ó1958 419 KB
When giving ‚Äúpadding‚Äù on Figma auto-layout to a button, the text position (inside the box, not the box) is not in the centre height. In the following example, you can see that in one font type there is 2 px space at the bottom and 1 at the top and in the other one, 2px at the top and 1 at the bottom.
That‚Äôs led to; 1, the text is not in the centre height, 2, the padding is getting extra which then lead to the wrong implementation.
Later on CSS, the text div won‚Äôt behave like that and will wrap right around the text.
The ideal is that the space (padding) above and below the text is even and exactly as set in the padding.
Is anyone have a solution for this challenge?
User: I am having the exact same issue (to the point that I thought I wrote this post ) We are trying to define fonts, text box behavior, and auto-layout for a design system, so this is a serious problem.
There is more space above the ascender than there is below the descender. Ideally it should be equal!
2023-05-19_<ISBN>√ó1080 28.3 KB
User: You can now use vertical trim to remove the extra space above and below text:
twitter.com
Figma
@figma
4/32 Leading trim
Align and style your text just the way you want it by trimming that extra spacing. <STRICT_LINK>
4:21 PM - 28 Mar 2023
470
28
User: Wow cool! Thank you!
Summary: Users are struggling with text box height and text positioning in Figma Auto Layout, leading to incorrect implementation. They discuss the issue of uneven padding and seek a solution. One user shares a Figma update that introduces vertical trim to remove extra space above and below text, which seems to address the problem.

User: We‚Äôve used couple times Figma‚Äôs observation mode while user testing. We noticed that if your prototype has animation which contains overlay, that overlay is not visible for observators. Only person who is using prototype can see overlays. This is critical problem which deteriorates observation feature.
User: Hello, everyone! I encountered the same issue and noticed that it only occurred when the overlay was triggered by an instance. As a temporary solution, I detached the instance, which allowed me to view the overlay in observation mode.
I hope this can help!
Summary: User experienced a critical issue with Figma's observation mode, where the overlay was not visible for observers. They discovered that the issue only occurred when the overlay was triggered by an instance. A temporary solution was to detach the instance, allowing the user to view the overlay in observation mode.

Text:
User: Miro makes my creative, collaborative workflow more efficient. With it, my whole team can add ideas and visuals of the specific part of the project they are responsible for in one single place. Without having to make a lot of meetings or building presentations that are not as fast to be edited, we can make alignments and approvals.
User: What I like most about Miro is that I'm able to create an online, easily accessible from a computer or phone, blank page where I can connect and create with my team at the same time. It gives us endless possibilities to be creative and to organize everything in the same place.
User: The only thing I dislike about Miro is when the board has too much content, and the platform starts to be very slow to edit and freezes. Making sure Miro works smoothly, even with heavy boards, is the only thing I see as a need right now.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its ability to streamline creative collaboration and provide a single platform for idea sharing and project management. They enjoy the accessibility and endless possibilities for creativity. However, they experience performance issues when boards have too much content, causing slow editing and freezing. Improving performance with heavy boards is a suggested improvement.

Text:
User: I really love ‚Äúnested instance properties‚Äù feature but it works for one component instance only. It would be useful if nested instance properties were available when I select several ‚Äúparent‚Äù instances.
My example
Component structure:
component Label - used for different statuses - has text property Label for text inside 2) component Table Cell - used for building tables - has variants for different types of cells
Case: I create column of statuses in the table, it includes cells which include label. If I want to update text in one label I can use nested label‚Äôs text property. But when I want to update text in several cells nested instance property disappears and I need to select label instead of cells or use some plugin for bulk text update.
PS: thanks to figma team for your incredible work User: I would also love to see support for this!
Summary: Users appreciate the "nested instance properties" feature in Figma but wish it could be applied to multiple parent instances simultaneously. They provide an example of updating text in several table cells, where the nested instance property disappears, requiring manual selection or using a plugin for bulk text updates.

Text:
User: Lack of visual communication: Traditional communication methods like emails or chats can sometimes make it difficult to convey complex ideas or visualize a concept. FigJam solves this problem by providing an easy-to-use whiteboarding tool that allows teams to quickly create visual representations of their ideas and share them with others.
User: FigJam is a collaborative online whiteboarding tool created by Figma that allows teams to work together in real-time to brainstorm, plan, and visualize ideas. One of the best things about FigJam is its ease of use and intuitive interface, which makes it simple for even non-designers to quickly create diagrams, flowcharts, wireframes, and other types of visual content.
User: sometimes UI could be complicated if you're a user that are not familiar with the FIGMA infinite canvas system (that you can scroll a lot and not find the end). Aside from that, is great
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam for its easy-to-use whiteboarding tool that enables better visual communication and collaboration among teams. However, some users find the UI complicated, particularly those unfamiliar with Figma's infinite canvas system.

Text:
User: Flexible platform for remote teams to work together on a visual level.
User: As a user of FigJam, I absolutely love the collaborative features of this tool. It's so easy to share my FigJam boards with team members and work together in real-time, no matter where we are located. The interface is also really intuitive and user-friendly, which makes it easy to get started with minimal training. Another thing I love about FigJam is its versatility - I can use it for everything from brainstorming ideas to creating wireframes and user flows.
User: It doesn't offer as many advanced design features as some other design tools on the market. While it's great for brainstorming and creating quick sketches or diagrams, it may not be the best choice for more complex design work.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam's collaborative features, intuitive interface, and versatility for remote teams, making it suitable for brainstorming, wireframes, and user flows. However, it lacks advanced design features compared to other design tools, limiting its use for more complex design work.

User: If your @figma files are low on memory and you've taken lengths to reduce file size but don't see an increase in memory, it's likely your version history. Fix by publishing the library, CUT and paste everything into a new file, then publish the new file.
User: @katiecooperco @figma Does this preserve the linked component instances? It's a brilliant tip!
User: @SamIam_Designs @katiecooperco @figma i'd expect the connections to be protected so long as you _cut_ and paste!
docs, if it's helpful: <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user suggests that if Figma files are low on memory despite efforts to reduce file size, the issue may be related to version history. They recommend fixing this by publishing the library, cutting and pasting everything into a new file, and then publishing the new file. This method is confirmed to preserve linked component instances.

Text:
User: Easier collaboration for remote teams. Having oversight on work and documenting in a single location - helps with visibility and engagement amongst team members.
User: Awesome oversight for projects as a whole, to plan, document, workshop, etc. Probably best tool for virtual workshops. 
 
Generally pretty intuitive to use, especially for new users. Also like that it's evolving to integrate other apps and more features.
User: Unable to make visuals and diagrams interactive. 
 
Sometimes fatigue is moving across the board and zooming in and out - unsure if I create things at the right scale. Also an issue for new users is zooming, moving across the board. 
 
Tables can be clunky, I like using simple tables to track information cause it's quick and easy for organizing info. 
 
Not very good at copying and pasting elements from other sources (eg. ppt tables) into Miro. 
 
I wish I could consolidate my personal and work account so I don't have to log in and out.
Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: Online diagramming among multiple team members in hybrid setup. Having multiple diagrams in one canvas is also a plus.

User: 1) When exporting to pdf, it does not capture the title of the frame - it should capture the title of frame, its a must. 
2) When we land on page, it should be by default on 100% zoom, currently it is not 
3) There should be a feature to organize the blocks in the diagram, so that we dont spend time organizing it 
4) Double arrow is missing from the connector list 
5) Connectors should show overlapping when crossing another connector
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for online diagramming and collaboration among hybrid teams, as well as its variety of templates. However, they suggest improvements such as capturing frame titles when exporting to PDF, setting default zoom to 100%, organizing blocks in diagrams, adding double arrows to connectors, and showing overlapping connectors when crossing another connector.

Text: User: It was good at first. However, fees increased by adopting unnecessary AI. I want you to stop rushing into things you don't need and making them expensive. I'm not satisfied with this ‚ë†. Dissatisfied ‚ë° is that you can't change (break) steps with the smartphone app. Note is designed to be entered for each WordPress-like paragraph (paragraph), but a break is not possible with a smartphone application. On a PC, you can do it by holding down the Shift key. Dissatisfaction ‚ë¢ is that the margin and padding for each paragraph when the steps are broken are narrow. Even though it's every paragraph, even if the characters are embedded so harshly. In the end, a paragraph with an empty line will be added. If these are improved, I'll gladly continue using it for a fee. I wonder if engineers aren't very particular people. Unlikely ‚Üí postscript. It's too much of a mystery that you can't sort the top positions on a smartphone.
Summary: User is dissatisfied with the increased fees for adopting unnecessary AI features and the inability to break steps in the smartphone app. They also find the margin and padding for each paragraph narrow, causing unwanted paragraph additions. The user suggests improving these features to continue using the product for a fee.

Google urgently introduced the security update version 112.0.5615.121. Most browsers update automatically, but users can also manually check if they have the latest version installed.
In the three-dot menu in the upper right corner of the browser, select ‚ÄúHelp‚Äù and select ‚ÄúAbout Chrome‚Äù to check the version number. <STRICT_LINK>

Text:
User: I think Miro is a very simple tool that comes between Designers and Non-designers to simply communicate through visuals rather than verbally speaking about it. With Miro, in my organization, everyone just simply hop on and draw something to visualize their ideas. I found this significantly helpful to communicate within a team.
User: Miro is the easiest tool to interact with. When it comes to bringing your idea to paper, Miro provides quick solutions such as a broad range of templates, which I like the most. I think for Designers like myself that work closely with POs, it's important to have a tool that both can use.
User: When it comes to organizing the boards, I find it sometimes difficult to find the specific board that I'm looking for. Maybe having the ability to folder the boards could be useful, but also inside boards, I wish I could organize my stuff more. Maybe something like Figma where you can have pages inside each board.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's simplicity and ease of use for communication between designers and non-designers, as well as its range of templates. However, they find organizing boards challenging and suggest implementing a folder system and pages within boards, similar to Figma, for better organization.

User: Miro allows us to work on projects concurrently with multiple users. Collaboration sessions don't usually require users to take away update tasks. The document gets updated during the collaboration session.
User: I started using Miro when COVID hit, and we started working from home. We originally started using it as a simple whiteboard replacement. As we became more familiar with the tool, we saw its power as more than a whiteboard replacement.
User: Miro is very comprehensive. The comprehensiveness leads to frequent software updates. It becomes a little irritating that whenever you open the software, it prompts you to restart to download the updates.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's collaborative capabilities and initially used it as a whiteboard replacement during remote work. However, they find the frequent software updates irritating and disruptive to their workflow.

Text:
User: Miro gives a remote team a place to collaborate that is accessible on any device with internet access. It has become as fast as writing notes by hand, rather than the sometimes extensive start-up required on other platforms. Even rudimentary diagrams and sketches are easy to create in real-time. There is an opportunity to have asynchronous discourse through the comments.
User: It is extremely intuitive to get started as a new user. It has become an essential tool for remote collaboration on my team of primarily visual thinkers. It is easy to go from loose sticky note ideas to a full deliverable sketch (or even the final deliverable in some cases). The tool is so flexible we have had to apply some rigor as a team to use it consistently and get the most out of comments, notes, etc. 
 
I love that the Miro team is always pushing updates and new features. I also like the available training tools, templates, and frequent presentations hosted by Miro that feature Miro employees as well as outside users.
User: The dislikes are more about features I wish were included, such as better interoperability between Miro and Excel, as well as data visualization capabilities. I would like the ability to create vector symbols/shapes and add custom fonts. I also wish that there were more features that catered to printed media - such as the ability to create paragraph styles and formatting templates with labels that could be adjusted on an instance-basis, but still referred back to a primary layout.
Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

Text:
User: It solves the same problem as other whiteboard app does. The fact it comes as part of Figma is a huge plus. I might consider using something else if it was a big add-on or wasn't part of the main platform. There are better apps, but the fact that this baked ina s part of Figma is the biggest reason I use it. It's great that it allows me to quickly spin up a board and hammer out visual concepts quickly and I'd happily use this to create UR artifacts, but it has some drawbacks and I wouldn't be able to facilitate some activities.
User: Figjam is a great tool that fulfills a lot of the functionality you get in more advanced whiteboard apps and does more or less a good job of it. The ability to deep-link to elements in a board, and make sections and post-its, is fine and works pretty well.
User: There could be more functionality to format and resize post-its. It'd also be really helpful, for the facilitation of workshop activities, to be able to show and hide sections. this would ideally be on a user or for users or user groups. More mechanics like this, which allows groups of participants and facilitators to work together, would have a positive impact on running workshop activity withing the Figma platform and in FigJam.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam as a whiteboard tool integrated within Figma, which allows them to quickly create visual concepts. However, they suggest improvements such as more formatting options for post-its, the ability to show and hide sections for specific users or groups, and additional features to facilitate group collaboration during workshops.

User: @figma is so terribly buggy lately with component properties and overrides. @sketch has (or had?) lots of shortcomings (like variants or prototyping features...), but at least it felt reliable in terms of overrides and not messing up styles in a component.
User: @dodojewski Hi there! Thank you for flagging this! Could you please send more details on what you‚Äôre seeing here?: <STRICT_LINK>. Our technical quality team will investigate further.
User: @figma already sent screen recordings to support. and i actually figured it out. i combined components together and one set remembered old properties, but those weren‚Äòt shown at all or displayed as faulty in the new component group, but they were conflicting‚Ä¶ very weird.
User: @figma i found out, cause copy/pasting the whole component set into a new file suddenly showed that extra property‚Ä¶
Summary: User experienced issues with Figma's component properties and overrides, finding it buggy compared to Sketch. They discovered that combining components caused conflicts due to old properties not being displayed correctly in the new component group. The issue was resolved by copying and pasting the component set into a new file, which revealed the extra property.

User: A perfect collaborative whiteboarding tool is a rare find. FigJam solved most of our team's problems. I can now keep all my important files organised in a single figma account and create different teams + edit my figma designs and get the feedback on my design in the quickest way.
User: I remember using Figma as a collaborative whiteboarding tool for my team since all the other such apps weren't as engaging. Then came FigJam and we couldn't stop using it because it is an extremely powerful tool with the most complex tools put in the simplest ways. Love its UI the most.
User: FigJam has a list of helpful tools and is perfectly real-time. I have never faced any issues while using any of the tools, widgets or features. One thing that I want to highlight they can work upon is to add a natural smoothness slider to the pen and highlighters so it works great even on trackpads.
Summary: The user praises FigJam as a perfect collaborative whiteboarding tool, praising its powerful tools and intuitive UI. They also appreciate the real-time nature of the app and the helpful tools. However, they suggest adding a natural smoothness slider to the pen and highlighters to make it work better on trackpads.

Text:
User: How might we collaborate efficiently in a hybrid work environment? 
 
Workshopping within miro means people can participate in workshops remotely, regardless of where they are in the planet. This has also meant that travelling for workshops has become less important - saving the business money.
User: Obviously the pandemic force a lot of us to find new ways to collaborate and connect without being face to face. Miro was clearly ahead of the game in this regard. But even since we're seeing more of each other in the flesh, miro still seems to be adding value with how easy it ease to document workshops, quickly capture ideas, and bring people together to brainstorm.
User: There are very few things to dislike about miro. There are some very minor things like how tables not being incredibly user-friendly, limitations in how you can modify shapes (particularly for the sake of creating wireframes). But all in all, this stuff is nice to have and the fact that you can even do basic wire framing along side everything else that you can do is a win.
Summary: The user finds Miro excellent for facilitating collaboration during workshops and team-based activities, praising its real-time collaboration capabilities, wide range of tools and templates, and rich media integration. However, they experience performance issues with large boards or many simultaneous users and feel that customization options can be restrictive.

A user shared their daily tech stack for their freelance design business, which includes Todoist, Notion, Clockify, SumUp, Typefully, Miro, Figma, Slack, Gmail, and Google Calendar. Another user asked why they chose these apps and shared their own tech stack.

User: I would otherwise be doing the same in Figma, but Miro is quicker allowing me to type in the shapes and connect arrows and lines to shapes. The arrow/lines will anchor to the shape, which mapes it really easy to move shapes (notes) around the board without having to grab the whole shape/line, like I would in Figma.
User: I like that you can easily plot out ideas through notes or shapes with the handy arrows/lines that connect them together. I also like to use templates, as then I don't need to create new templates or copy them from other miro boards.
User: I find grouping objects and selecting objects within the group a bit cumbersom. I also don't like that when I trpe within a box/shape, that there isn't much padding between the text and the edge of the shape, the text can bud right up next to the edge which I find strange.
Summary: Users prefer Miro over Figma for quickly creating and connecting shapes, arrows, and lines, as well as using templates. However, they find grouping and selecting objects within groups cumbersome and dislike the lack of padding between text and shape edges.

User: I have a deeply nested component that‚Äôs confusing me. This may be by-design, but if not I‚Äôm hoping for some pointers to be aware of‚Ä¶
I‚Äôm building a ComboBox component. Inside o that is a TextInput component. Inside of that is a text layer and an icon component. It looks like this:
CombobBox component
TextInput component
Icon component
test layer
The behavior I‚Äôm seeing is that my ComboBox is not consistent when I select the same properties in the various components. ComboBox has a couple variations with a customized Icon (layer swap override) ‚Äì one for when a dropdown is displayed and one for when it‚Äôs not displayed. If I change properties at the TextInput component (e.g., status property from ‚Äúdefault‚Äù to ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù), it will honor some color changes but not the icon I set. If I set them in the reverse order (CombboBox and then TextInput), the right icon gets shown.
Sorry if it‚Äôs confusing. Here‚Äôs a simplified file where I tried to show what I‚Äôm seeing: <STRICT_LINK>
-t
Summary: User is confused about the inconsistent behavior of a ComboBox component, where the same properties in the various components affect the appearance of the component. User: The pre-built templates help a lot when creating visual flows. This gives me a visual way to explain processes to my team and others.
User: The flexibility it provides. Multiple users who can work on the same board and the ability to update info in real time is extremely useful.
User: There is a bit of a learning curve to start using it. It's hard to expect users who are unfamiliar with Miro to be able to easily navigate around a board.
Summary: The user appreciates Miro as a platform for digital collaboration, facilitating hybrid work between remote and office environments. They find the tools accessible for newcomers but scale well for power users to leverage templates and tools that adapt to content and user needs across a project or workflow's stages. The user also mentions the importance of managing board sprawl and ensuring the right individuals have access to the right content in a timely manner.

User: It's not immediately intuitive. When there are new users brought into a meeting utilizing Miro they can't immediately jump in. Requires some ramp up/training before being able to jump in
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's ability to align remote meeting participants and create engaging, self-documenting workshops. The speed and fluidity of the application enhance the facilitator experience. However, the licensing model and board structure can be confusing for infrequent collaborators, and users suggest improving security by including the entire enterprise as users and charging only for power users.

Text:
User: Making everything visual and allowing connection points helps team members see the larger picture. Having the ability to create high-level roadmaps helps to understand the strategy. Other tech options (MS Whiteboard, Excel, etc.) are available today but are not nearly as effective.
User: I truly enjoy the collaborative nature of Miro. The fact that everyone on my team can hop on and add content is super helpful. It allows me to understand better where people are coming from and lets me draw (literally) correlations between ideas.
User: One downside of using Miro is the licensing aspect. It would be great if there were a way to have a less expensive licensed option for business that doesn't allow for all of the bells and whistles. Many team members, for example, will stick to creating stickies and emojis and never use any templates or more advanced features.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's visual and collaborative features, which help teams see the bigger picture and understand strategies better than other tools like MS Whiteboard and Excel. However, they suggest offering a less expensive licensing option for businesses that don't require advanced features, as some team members only use basic functions like stickies and emojis

Text:
User: Miro help us to improve our processes by getting ideas in brainstormings for example. We also map process and use it to find the root causes of problems

User: üöÄ How to turn an ‚Äûalmost perfect‚Äù UI/UX to ‚Äûperfect‚Äù.
Using <STRICT_LINK> as a perfect example (created by @cnnr_cllhn) <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more ‚Äûconcise‚Äù adjective without using ‚Äûvery‚Äù. Example: very rich = affluent.
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that .It's straight to the point (just like the Google Search homepage). So what's the problem? <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn ‚ùå There are 3 main flaws:
1. Site feels messy
2. Design lacks consistency
3. Elements feel a little too cramped
We'll approach it ‚Äûvia negativa‚Äù style: by removing stuff rather than adding.
üë©üé® Let's work on that that using @figma
Summary: A user discussed how to improve the UI/UX of a website called LoseTheVery, which helps find concise adjectives. They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

Text:
User: Miro solves several problems for product managers, including collaboration, ideation and brainstorming, project management, prototyping, and remote work. It provides a centralized platform for product managers to collaborate with their team members and stakeholders, regardless of their location. Miro's digital whiteboard allows product managers to brainstorm and ideate with their team, visually organize their ideas, and prioritize their tasks. It also helps product managers manage their projects effectively, create and manage product roadmaps, user story maps, and agile and Scrum methodologies.
User: Miro is an excellent tool for collaborating and brainstorming with teams remotely. Its vast canvas space, extensive library of pre-made templates, and user-friendly interface make it easy to create and share ideas visually. I particularly like its real-time collaboration feature which allows team members to work together seamlessly, regardless of their location. Overall, Miro is a robust and flexible tool that can be used for various purposes, from project management to creative brainstorming sessions.
User: Miro's pricing structure could be seen as expensive, especially if users only require a few of the advanced features. Our enterprise license charges the same cost per user, even if most staff only use it intermittently. As power users our team gets great value from the product but the accountants just see 60% of the company using it a few times a month and complain loudly. 
If using SSO, shared boards often link to the online version rather than the native app and the constant signing-in can become frustrating.
Summary: User is benefiting from Miro's range of templates, diagrams, and sticky notes which make it easy to share complex ideas visually, resulting in improved collaboration and a more efficient workflow. The User finds Miro to be an incredibly powerful tool for collaborating with teams, due to its easy-to-use interface and real-time collaboration features. Additionally, the platform's extensive range of features are highly customizable, allowing for greater flexibility when working on projects. Users may find the pricing structure of Miro to be expensive for smaller teams or individuals, and the extensive range of features can be overwhelming for new users. However, Miro provides helpful support resources such as video tutorials and a user community to help users get up to speed quickly.

Text:
User: We want to start using versioning in our projects and we are trying to figure out the best way to do it.
The approach that makes more sense to us is to create a new branch on each file for the new version.
Our issue is that we have team members working on each version (1 and 2) but we can‚Äôt create a new feature branch for the version 2 branch (we don‚Äôt have this issue for version 1 because that is the main branch).
Our question is if does exist an official way to work with different versions in the same file in order to handle versioning or if there is a better way to do this.
Example of what we need
Button v1 branch (main)
a new feature for Button v1 (a new branch from the main branch)
Button v2 branch (version 2 branch)
a new feature for Button v2 (a new branch from version 2 branch)
The second question is how to handle major, minor, and patch updates into Figma (following semantic versioning definition)
Our idea is to handle major changes with branches, and minor/patches with version history. What do you think?
There is a recommended way to handle versioning?
Summary: The user is seeking advice on using versioning in Figma projects, specifically on creating branches for different versions and handling major, minor, and patch updates. They are considering using branches for major changes and version history for minor/patches, and are asking for recommendations on the best approach.

Maybe you can leave that on all the time as so artboards always have a 80px margin between each other. Of course, this is just for top level canvas items (no artboards inside of artboards).
Summary: The user suggests a feature that can be turned on or off to help with auto-layout of the canvas. When on, it would move artboards in 20px increments, detect logical stacking and auto arrange them with an 80px margin between each other. This feature would only apply to top level canvas items.

Text:
User: Using new tools to increase the academic workflow is good.
However, is there a risk of getting overwhelmed?
Do you suffer from tech procrastination?
#AcademicChatter @ThePhDPlace @PhDVoice A üßµüôÇ <STRICT_LINK>
User: There's literature search tools, note taking tools, brainstorming tools, editing tools, time management tools, citation tools, tools linking among tools. And new ones every day.
They are good. But do you need to use them all?
No you don't.
Should you try some of them?
Sure!
User: There is something like tech procrastination. You can go down rabbit holes of tool use, trying new ones, listening to more YouTube tutorials, subscribing to more newsletters.
But in the end, you still need to do the work as a researcher. Nothing can replace thinking, lab work.
User: So try new things out, and if it makes sense for you, the way you work, the way you think, your topic, your personal preferences - fine! But you shouldn't feel like you're falling behind if you're not trying out every new thing out there.
User: This is not anti-tech at all, I love exploring new things. But they really can be a distraction. The FOMO is real. They are time drains. There are costs.
So, do your work. Do your research. And sample these new tools every once in a while...but don't procrastinate with tech.
User: @mrillig That's why I prefer tools like @NotionHQ, that combine almost all of them in one client (AI tools, Note-taking, time-managment etc.)
Summary: The user works a 9-5 job and runs a freelance design business, using various tools to stay organized. They use Todoist, Notion, Clockify, SumUp, Typefully, Miro, Slack, Gmail, Google Calendar, and Apple apps. They have not heard of superhuman yet, but may create a thread to discuss the pros and cons of each tool.

Text:
User: I use Miro mainly for workshoppign internally or with clients. I use the consulting plan to balance cost with flexibility and confidentiality. I often use miro even during face to face workshops to capture the productions in real time.
User: Overall an excellent choice for facilitating collaboration during workshops and team-based activities. Its real-time collaboration capabilities enable users to work together seamlessly, whether in-person or remote, fostering a more interactive and productive workshop experience. The wide range of tools and templates, such as mind maps and Kanban boards, caters to various use cases, making it easy to adapt the platform for different activities. Furthermore, Miro's integration with rich media such as videos and PDF ensures effortless sharing and access to work across platforms, streamlining team collaboration.
User: Performance issues can arise when working with large boards or a high number of simultaneous users, which may result in lag or slow loading times. Additionally, the platform's customization options can sometimes feel restrictive, especially when users require more flexibility in tailoring Miro to their specific needs.
Summary: The user finds Miro excellent for facilitating collaboration during workshops and team-based activities, praising its real-time collaboration capabilities, wide range of tools and templates, and rich media integration. However, they experience performance issues with large boards or many simultaneous users and feel that customization options can be restrictive.

User: I think it has been easier on products like Mural to make an outline of your work to jump around. If the feature exists I don't really see it used.

Text:
User: collating many screenshots and adding notes. Very useful for combining screenshots with diagrams, text and offering more collaboration between viewers. Fairly simple to pick up and use, which is great. It would be nice to have a start screen for a project to help the casual user.
User: I use Miro for my individual work projects, and to collaborate with teams. For my own work, Miro is great for collating screenshots, creating diagrams and adding notes / commentaries. The infinite canvas is great for just gettng started and getting ideas out. For a team, it's very good for creating lightweight tables and timelines. There are good tools for collaboration.
User: I use Miro to collate and to share when I'm 'driving' the presentation. It's less good for linear presentation. You can create an ordering of canvases, but I get worried about leaving a recipient of my link to Miro to find the first board and then go into presentation mode. It would be nice to have a link to share that handles that, so it's easy to open and view linearly before getting to the full canvas view.
Summary: The User is benefiting from the product by being able to collate many screenshots and add notes, which allows for more collaboration between viewers. It is also easy to pick up and use, although a start screen for a project would be beneficial for casual users. The User enjoys using Miro for individual work projects and team collaboration. They appreciate the infinite canvas for getting ideas out, as well as the tools for creating lightweight tables and timelines. The User also finds the collaboration tools to be very good. The User finds Miro useful for collating and sharing information, but not as good for linear presentations. They would like a link to share that makes it easier to open and view the information linearly before getting to the full canvas view.

User: Graphic design for a wide range of needs
User: I use Figma nearly every day for my graphic needs - I love that I don't have to have a ton of graphic skills to create and edit very polished designs. Furthermore, my graphic designers created some nice templates that are easy for me to update and re-use. It's easy to navigate and if I need to learn something new the docs are super useful.
User: It does take a little time to get onboarded but that's because it's a powerful tool with a lot of options for customization!
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's intuitive UI/UX and its ability to facilitate collaboration within their design team, acting as a design repository. They find it easy to use with ready-made templates, but suggest adding step-by-step guides or pop-up tips for non-professional designers.

User: we are able to conduct workshops remotely and get even better results than we would have if we were in person on a whiteboard. It is also great to have all documentation in the same place.
User: Miro is a intuitive system that anyone can get up to speed and use within 5 min. It means that during a workshop you can get tangible outcomes early on. A workshop that previously took half a day, you can get the same result in 60min. Competing tools are somewhat on same level but I prefer the UI of Miro.
User: One downside is that since banking is a regulatory space, we are limited in how we can utilise the tool in terms of integration, not much to do with Miro but a general downside.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's simplicity, templates, real-time collaboration, and ample workspace for brainstorming and problem-solving. However, they feel that Miro offers more tools and integration options, suggesting that easy access of Miro use could be beneficial

Text:
User: Intro
There is an interesting concept in Figma that‚Äôs used and was presented by multiple people and has different names: Placeholder, Slots, Dummies, Layout Blocks, and so on:
‚ùñ Placeholder component is the base one.
‚óá Placeholder instances may be nested into another ‚ùñ Component.
‚óá Placeholder instances nested into ‚óá Component instances may be swapped with any other component instances‚Ä¶
More details in this video by @Adam_Ruthendorf-Przewoski.
The next step of its evolution is Layout Blocks by @Mr.Biscuit.
An issue
I have a base ‚ùñ Placeholder component:
‚óá Placeholder instances may be nested into other components (‚ùñ Column here):
image2080√ó384 8.54 KB
What I need is to nest a ‚óá Column instance into another ‚óá Column instance by swapping one of the ‚óá Placeholders.
This is needed to customize Auto Layout spacings and other properties:
image804√ó564 8.43 KB
But when I try to do this I see an error message Failed to set component: cycle detected!:
I totally understand why we‚Äôre not allowed to nest instances into their Main components ‚Äî it will create an endless cycle such as infinite screen share:
image1600√ó808 102 KB
But actually, it is not endless ‚Äî we always will have the last one ‚óá Placeholder instance as a stop point:
image804√ó932 11.4 KB
My Demo file to better understand what‚Äôs going on.
Possible solutions
There are a couple of solutions that solve this issue but still are not optimal:
Have multiple absolutely identical components to nest one into another.
image1568√ó1242 22.3 KB
For the upper-level use a component with more placeholders inside and hide unnecessary ones.
image1092√ó644 12.3 KB

User: I think the only solution for now is to create a ‚ùñ Main Container component with ‚óá slot instances inside. Then you need to create also another component for ‚ùñ Column/Row with variants. With this, you can upto 2nd level only. Unless yo create a similar column component with different name
image1159√ó633 36.5 KB
Summary: The user discusses the concept of Placeholder components in Figma and the issue they face when trying to nest a Column instance into another Column instance, resulting in a "cycle detected" error message. They suggest possible solutions, such as creating a Main Container component with slot instances inside and using Column/Row components with variants, but these are not optimal and only work up to the 2nd level.

Text: User: I know it is already compatible but you could make a completely new app very similar to notion but slightly changed so it is more compatible with mobile since it‚Äôs very hard. You could change it so underneath the ‚Äúhealth and feedback‚Äù there are a selection of buttons that will help navigate around notion, and if you make more than 3 pages then you could make it scrollable so you scroll on that small part so it won‚Äôt get in the way of the buttons, or just put them to the side. Maybe add a choice to let notion know that you are on mobile instead of making a new app! So it gives you a choice as to if you are on phone, iPad or computer. Text:
User: I‚Äôd like Figma links to open in the Mac desktop app, but they only open in the browser. The option to ‚ÄúOpen in App‚Äù doesn‚Äôt exist in my Preferences menu in Figma in either the browser or desktop app.
I‚Äôve tried reinstalling the app, reloading all tabs, and restarting my Mac ‚Äì‚Äì of the things recommended here:
 
 
 
 Figma Links Not Opening in Desktop App, Despite Setting Ask the community
 
 
 Anyone else having an issue opening Figma links in their desktop app? I‚Äôm using MacOS and trying both Chrome and Safari. 
The link does switch focus to the Desktop App, but it doesn‚Äôt open up to the linked file/page/frame. Turning the ‚ÄúOpen in Desktop‚Ä¶‚Äù setting off allows the link to open correctly, but in the browser.
 

User: Hey All!
I found out why there is no way to open any Figma link in Safari.
You need to enable only the ‚ÄúHide IP address from trackers‚Äù option in your Privacy settings.
Make sure to quit Safari completely and then reopen it.
image1042√ó246 48.3 KB
All the best,
Daniel
User: and, of course, if it doesn‚Äôt work you must click on the ‚ÄúOpen in Desktop App‚Äù when you‚Äôre link is open in restarted browser.
file-OoNIeh58Bs1114√ó1529 110 KB
Summary: A user faced issues with Figma links not opening in the Mac desktop app and only opening in the browser. They tried reinstalling the app, reloading tabs, and restarting their Mac without success. Another user suggested enabling the "Hide IP address from trackers" option in Safari's Privacy settings and clicking on "Open in Desktop App" after restarting the browser.

Text:
User: Its really a heartbreaker that exporting the slices to pdf is not available in Figma. Sketch has it and it was working really great for us.
Some of our multinational stakeholders, whom we cannot insist to install or start an account for Figma or anything else, as they rely on pdf documents for design review or sharing with internal team. Sketch helped to convert the slices to pdf which was very light weight and compressible. When we moved to figma, the internal team as well few clients worked well with figma collaboration (same we did with Sketch too) and but the later ones didn‚Äôt. And now we are forced to go back to Sketch, as we understand that its the app that we could rely to accomplish all our requirements.
Summary: User is frustrated with the lack of PDF export from slices in Figma, as it requires additional workarounds for exporting assets. They also mention that exporting PDF from slices is not available in Sketch, which helped them with their mobile development needs. The user mentions that their multinational stakeholders prefer using PDF for design review and sharing with internal team. They also mention that Figma collaboration is not working well with their internal team, and they are forced to revert to Sketch for their needs.

User: It solves the need to have to use multiple tools to collaborate and capture different requires that all feed into building the right product for our customers
User: It is a blank white board that allows you to easily collaborate with team members, organize workflows, capture user journeys and use existing templates
User: I wish it would be easier to copy and paste excel spreadsheets
Summary: The user appreciates the diverse and accessible whiteboard tool for use during meetings and collaboration, as well as the tagging features and drag-and-drop file features. They also appreciate the ease of creating and sharing dashboards and the integration with other apps. However, they find the organization of connected objects to be surface-level and the large boards to be slow and hard to use.

Text:
User: It bring transparency and visibility to team members' work and feedback. It makes us to keep our artifacts living and any time ready to be updated collaboratively.
User: The ready Miro templates expedites our deliverables and it make our sessions super collaborative and efficient irrespective of our location either in the office or while working remotely.
User: Copying the content from and to MS Office is challenging; especially not being able to copy paste a table from Excel. Also, grouping the cards for bulk updates are painful when sizing and font changes needed.
Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: Mainly digital transformation planning and solution design development and communication. The ability to collaborate remotely accelerates progress.
User: Ease of use is the best 'feature', very easy for new users to get started and gaining benefit from collaborating on diagrams, designs, analysis, brainstorming.... Then it's easy to gradually start using more advanced features as you go. 
As a more experienced/advanced user I like: 
- the wide range of templates 
- icons 
- voting functionality 
- tables/grids
User: I think the board organisation coukd be better. Especially when you move from a free account to a paid account, the filing system can get a bit disjointed.
Summary: The user appreciates Miro as a platform for digital collaboration, facilitating hybrid work between remote and office environments. They find the tools accessible for newcomers but scale well for power users to leverage templates and tools that adapt to content and user needs across a project or workflow's stages. The user also mentions the importance of managing board sprawl and ensuring the right individuals have access to the right content in a timely manner.

Text:
User: The main problem it is solving for me and the team/company, is that it allows some processes and collaborative tasks to be done much simpler and online. 
 
Processes that are sometimes difficult to visualize in a meeting can usually be created in MIRO. With your own creativity being the limitation. Besides that it is great to improve interactiveness. By having team members actively write and move things on the board it creates a much more active session
User: Quite easy to understand, very easy to collaborate with team members. And the creative potential is very high compared to a lot of other collaboration platforms.
User: I wish it had even more templates. Especially templates that stand in relation with AGILE workflows and ways of working. E.a. to support SCRUM refinements, SCRUM reviews etc. 
Also a wide variety of templates for Roadmaps in all shapes and sizes could be great, as this is what it is used a lot for.
Summary: The user finds MIRO to be a great collaboration platform for team members, allowing them to create processes and tasks more easily and collaboratively. They also appreciate the high creative potential and wish for more templates and templates related to agile workflows and SCRUM reviews.

Text:
User: Collaboration tools are very important in this remote world that we're living in. FigJam provides our teams with a "natural" medium to collaborate with. We love it for retrospectives, group plannings, brainstorming, etc.
User: FigJam makes it easy to collaborate with a team on a variety of different use cases. From whiteboarding, to retrospectives, to planning meetings, to organizing information.
User: Because it is mostly unstructured, you or your team is left to decide what structure works best for your use case.
Summary: Users find Figjam to be an effective collaboration tool for remote teams, enabling brainstorming and project planning in a single, consolidated space. It has successfully replaced in-person whiteboard sessions and is highly appreciated by users, with very few dislikes.

User: I work in a consulting company where whiteboarding is a core component of our Problem Solving and collaborative approach. with Covid Miro became out go-to platform
User: - Use case within collaborative workshops (templates, breakouts with music, bringing people with you) 
- it's very user friendly and easy to use allowing new joiners to be part of the solution quickly
User: - I work across a series of programs and sometimes when I do work cross-softwares (e.g., copying things from other tools) it doesn't work great 
- When we work with members outside our organization it is somewhat limiting (though I am not sure if this is driven by our own security)
Summary: The user works in a consulting company and uses Miro for collaborative workshops due to its user-friendly interface and ease of use for new joiners. However, they face challenges when working with other software and collaborating with external members, which may be due to their organization's security settings.

Text:
User: I‚Äôve been a designer for a little over 13 years. Early in my design career, I started feeling like I wanted a more ‚Äòtechnical role‚Äô and switched to front-end development.
I remember the exact moment that the concept of components and systems thinking clicked for meüí°
User: At the time, I was building custom WordPress themes. 
Within my theme, I'd have a partials folder, full of my silly little components.
And I had my templates folder, full of my silly little templates.
User: Pulling components from my partials folder into my templates enabled me to have really modular, maintainable and organised template files.
Seeing it all come together was a huge a-ha moment for me, but I didn't know why ‚Äì¬†at the time, design systems wasn't a well-known concept.
User: I spent a tonne of time playing with Sass, extending classes, using mixins, and all that fun, CSS goodness.
‚úΩ
Looking back at it now, I realise that what I was really (kind of) doing, was implementing a simplified version of component properties.
User: Code felt natural and intuitive ‚Äì I loved the idea of having a bunch of components that I could pull from and iterate upon rapidly.
I wanted to be able to replicate that workflow in design so badly. But design tooling wasn't anywhere close to what it is now.
User: Designing in Photoshop involved a tonne of manual copying, pasting and replacing... The process felt outdated and ineffective, and often resulted in a tonne of inconsistencies.
I dreamed of a tool that could reflect some of what we do in code... even the tiniest bit.
User: When I learned about Figma a few years later, it felt like a huge weight had been lifted, and my passion for design exploded.
I'm so grateful to be working at a time where technology is evolving so rapidly, and some of the gaps between design/dev are starting to thin out.
User: This was a lot of tweets about nothing, but I woke up feeling so in love with my career. 
And just generally grateful that I get to sit around all day, working on design systems, architecting components, crafting design patterns and collaborating with developers. üòçü•∞ü•π
User: I don't think I'd be so passionate about my career if @figma didn't come around when it did üòç It's setting the standard of things to come, and we're only at the beginning. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's simplicity and ease of use for communication between designers and non-designers, as well as its range of templates. However, they find organizing boards challenging and suggest implementing a folder system and pages within boards, similar to Figma, for better organization.
