Text:
User: .@_Dave__White_ and I are excited to open source our power tool for interacting w/ LLMs: Flux.
Flux allows you to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel.
Try it out at <STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: Flux's tree structure lets you:
‚Ä¢ Get a wider variety of creative responses
‚Ä¢ Test out different prompts with the same shared context
‚Ä¢ Use inconsistencies to identify where the model is uncertain <STRICT_LINK>
User: Flux also:
‚Ä¢ Has a robust set of keyboard shortcuts
‚Ä¢ Allows setting the system message and editing GPT messages
‚Ä¢ Autosaves to local storage
‚Ä¢ Uses the OpenAI API directly
‚Ä¢ Is open source and MIT licensed
Bug reports & PRs welcome on Github: <STRICT_LINK>
User: Flux has been a major boost to our workflows and we hope it can do the same for you.
Thank you to @repligate for inspiring us with Loom, @ctjlewis for maintaining the awesome openai-streams library Flux is built on, and of course @_yangyou for her brilliant designs and feedback.
User: P.S: This is only a bare bones version of what we imagine Flux could become.
If you're interested in working with us on Flux or @_Dave__White_'s new game (<STRICT_LINK>), we'd love to talk w/ you.
Reach out via DM or at {t11s, <EMAIL_ADDRESS> ‚ú®
User: We have been working on an LLM collaboration tool using @ceramicnetwork's @ComposeDB and, of course, flux. 
Think of @figma for prompt design. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: Flux is an open-source power tool for interacting with LLMs, allowing users to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel. It offers a variety of creative responses, tests different prompts with shared context, and identifies model uncertainties. Flux also features keyboard shortcuts, system message editing, autosaving, and direct use of the OpenAI API. The creators are open to collaboration and are working on an LLM collaboration tool using Ceramic Network's ComposeDB and Flux, similar to Figma for prompt design.

Text:
User: Hi,
Today during UI class I have discovered an annyoing behavior. I tried to create a simple product card with a picture and a ‚ÄúSpecial offer‚Äù label placed inside the picture.
In order to reproduce the issue:
Step 1: Create a text field, turn it into Auto Layout and give it a fill color, just to create a label basically, like ‚ÄúFLASH SALE‚Äù etc‚Ä¶
Step 2: Add a rectangle and fill it with an image.
Step 3: Turn both into an Auto-Layout frame and try to adjust the label and the image so that the label sits inside. While doing so, you shall discover that the image covers the label and hides it, even when the label layer is above the image.
Despite that, when merging a text and an image into Auto-Layout and only then turning the text to Auto-Layout as well to give if a fill color - this method works perfectly fine, but at last both methods shall lead to the same result as far as I am concerned, so there might be a bug here. Or is it?
Thanks.
Summary: User encountered an issue in Figma where an image covers a "Special Offer" label when both are turned into an Auto-Layout frame, even if the label layer is above the image. The issue does not occur when merging text and image into Auto-Layout first and then turning the text into Auto-Layout to give it a fill color. The user suspects a possible bug.

Text:
User: In my organisation, I used Figma to collaborate internally with the design team and build creative content templates. This helped save the designer's bandwidth and dependency too. It also acted like a Design Repository for our internal team.
User: I love the intuitive UI/UX of the tool. It is also straightforward to use, drag and drop the design elements. A lot of ready-made templates make the work effective. It is a clean and smooth tool, I would like to say!
User: I am not sure, but I guess the only thing I miss is a step-by-step guide or tips. It would be great to get pop-up tips, as everyone using the software isn't a pro designer.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's intuitive UI/UX and its ability to facilitate collaboration within their design team, acting as a design repository. They find it easy to use with ready-made templates, but suggest adding step-by-step guides or pop-up tips for non-professional designers.

Text: User: Why do they say that the app comes in Spanish, when both on the iPhone and iPad it is not like that and there is no section where it indicates that the language can be changed?
Summary: User is confused about the app's language options, as it is not available on the iPhone and iPad, and wonders why it is advertised as being in Spanish.

Text:
User: There is a lot of things it benefits me at work. It's a simpler design tool when compared to other Adobe tools. I can complete my task faster than using other tools. And sharing my work with other parties and communicating/commenting on my work is much easier when using Fimga.
User: There is a lot of features it's better than many other similar tools. But if I have to pick one, I think it must be the "Share" function. It's by default a web-based tool. Though it provides a desktop application, I mainly use the web version. Sharing my work with different parties is just never easier than before, owing to its web-based nature.
User: "PDF to Figma", it is a real problem for many designers. Currently, figma doesn't natively support drag & drop PDF into a design file. It needs a plugin to do that. Hopefully, we can have such native function soon.
Summary: The user finds Figma beneficial for its simplicity, faster task completion, and easy sharing and communication features compared to other design tools. They particularly appreciate the "Share" function due to its web-based nature. However, they suggest adding a native "PDF to Figma" feature, as it currently requires a plugin.

Text:
User: We are a fully remote and distributed team, so collaboration across distances is the main problem it quickly solves. The other is its potential - I use it to solve literally any problem I encounter - either with a quick brainstorming session or a more thought out workshop.
User: How quickly it is to add ideas to the space using stickies. The increase in plugins for different tasks and processes. The collaborative aspects and how fun it is.
User: The only downsides that come to mind are the limitations regarding font selection or shape creation, etc. If it had a few more capabilities like Figma (with a different editing experience) it'd be versatile enough for pretty much all tasks, rather than having to jump back and forth between Figma and Figjam to do some tasks
Summary: Users find FigJam helpful for real-time collaboration in a virtual setting, appreciating the whiteboard-style layout and real-time editing and commenting features. However, they note that design capabilities are more limited compared to Figma.

Text:
User: Figjam has helped solve some of our collaboration problems with having a distributed and remote team. Brainstorming and collaboration meetings that previously were done in person in a meeting room with whiteboards are now done using Figjam.
User: Figjam is a great collaboration tool for brainstorming new ideas and recording different types of data in a consolidated space. It has been great in helping to discuss and plan large projects by providing a single place where all the different aspects of the project can be stored and shared.
User: There is actually very little that I dislike about Figjam. It serves its purpose very well.
Summary: Users find Figjam to be an effective collaboration tool for remote teams, enabling brainstorming and project planning in a single, consolidated space. It has successfully replaced in-person whiteboard sessions and is highly appreciated by users, with very few dislikes.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üåü Believe in yourself and your idea. As a solopreneur, self-confidence is crucial. Keep pushing forward, even when things get tough. You've got this!
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

User: 1/ a month ago i asked ChatGPT to help me cultivate more discipline. had been feeling chaotic, unfocused, and just not like myself.
gave me 10 things to do. it worked.
big fan of AI as personal coach. no more reading airport books. just a few bullet points w minimal filler.
User: 2/ the list was:
- declutter your environment
- prioritize your tasks
- set clear goals - limit screen time
- learn to say no
- automate and delegate
- cultivate a minimalist mindset
- simplify your finances
- create routines
- practice mindfulness
User: 3/ i ported this list into @NotionHQ and then used their embedded AI feature to expand each list item into practical steps with examples
i then made daily action items to help me actually *do* these things every day
and then i blocked time on my calendar to do the action items
User: @Melt_Dem @NotionHQ Look at you!
Summary: User finds Notion to be a great app for collaboration and brainstorming, but has experienced numerous bugs and glitches, including issues with adding checkboxes and creating to-do lists. They also mention that the app is slow and buggy, and the AI tool is not useful for their needs.

Text:
User: Collaborative space - it meeds our needs specifically for the design team to be able to share our work and thinking through diagrams and such.

Summary: User praises the collaboration, comments, and grouping features for improving decision-making capabilities and real-time collaboration. They appreciate the tool's ability to add comments and reactions to sticky notes, flowcharts, mind maps, and wireframes.

Text:
User: It's helping us to work in hybrid envrionments and enables workshops to go ahead without everyone being physically present. Furthermore, we can make collaborative decisions more easily in innovation settings.
User: It's easy to learn and use for my colleagues and clients - frequently they can get started without any real training. I also like that it helps me think through problems easily without the bounds of paper and space.......it's available everywhere I have an internet connection.
User: I find that sharing with non -members could be easier. I also find the templates are harder to customise for your needs and that takes more time than it should.
Summary: Figma is beneficial for users in hybrid environments, enabling workshops and collaborative decision-making in innovation settings. It is easy to learn and use, accessible anywhere with an internet connection. However, sharing with non-members could be easier, and customizing templates can be time-consuming.

Text:
User: - Online collaboration with team members. 
- A visual and active way to involve other participants. 
- Documentation of unstructured discussions. 
- Asyncronous collaboration
User: I am a novice user with expereince using other workshopping tools. 
Starting up to use the product was easy. I like that the onboarding helping messages are not coming up at the very first login, but slowly appearing when doing the work. So I actually have possibility to try them one-by-one. I am not overwhelmed with the amount of new information. 
I like that I can invite participants who does not have Miro account as a participant.
User: It is not very clear from the documentation what kind of user access shall I use when inviting external participants for workshops. What is the difference between view/comment/edit or visitor/guest users? 
I like the Figma Section feature, I have not found yet the alternative of that in Miro.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's online collaboration, documentation of unstructured discussions, and asynchronous collaboration. They found the onboarding process easy and liked the gradual introduction of helpful messages. However, they are unclear about the different user access levels for external participants and miss the Figma Section feature in Miro.

User: I‚Äôm a designer and I‚Äôve recently been learning low code development. So I‚Äôve been inspecting designs on Figma to implement. This has really helped my understanding more the POV of a developer when inspecting Figma. I noticed that you can get pretty much all the info you need on the inspect tab but if you need to export something you have to go back to the design tab all the way to the bottom.
Now this is when you are an editor on the file. The view only POV is easier to export cause even though export is a different tab, its not cluttered. But when you‚Äôre an editor on the file switching between design and inspect is hectic.
So I suggest if there could be an export option too on the inspect tab.
Summary: The user suggests adding an export option to the inspect tab to make it easier for editors to switch between design and inspect.

Text:
User: Miro solve the problem of aligning people in a remote meeting and having a shared understanding of what needs to be achieved in the meeting. It also provides a say to prepare strucutre of workshops that are engaging and self documenting.
User: The speed and fluidity of the application makes you able to create concepts and structures on the fly as you are facilitating a meeting. The added controls make for a great facilitator experience.
User: The license model and structure of boards is confusing to people that are infrequent collaborators on the tool. It would be better for security as well if you could include your whole enterprise as users and pay for the number of power users not for idle users that need secure access to boards once per year.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's ability to align remote meeting participants and create engaging, self-documenting workshops. The speed and fluidity of the application enhance the facilitator experience. However, the licensing model and board structure can be confusing for infrequent collaborators, and users suggest improving security by including the entire enterprise as users and charging only for power users.

Text:
User: I need a fast, easy, and collaborative way to wireframe and fat-marker sketch ideas with my design and engineering team. We also use it for retrospective meeting whiteboards
User: I love that Figjam is in the Figma suite and is so simple and easy to use. As a Product Manager, I am not adept enough at Figma to use it as a whiteboard, so I use Figjam to mock up ideas and do light wireframing before turning ideas into designs in full Figma.
User: Figjam's strength is also its weakness- it is very simple and lacks some other whiteboard features found in competing whiteboard products like Miro. If they continue adding features, I think that Figjam will be a market leader soon.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's FigJam as a virtual whiteboard for sharing team ideas with a wider audience, highlighting its fast, snappy, and easy setup. They also mention its simplicity and ease of sharing with new users. However, they note the recent restrictions on the free tier and limitations in shapes and formatting options.

User: Over the past 6 months, I've been on the hunt for a new browser that can replace Chrome for me as a writer and product engineer. And I found it...
<STRICT_LINK>
User: I was looking for 3 things from a new browser: privacy, performance and productivity. After testing the usual suspects like Firefox, Safari, and Brave and trying out some new kids like @KagiHQ's Orion, @SigmaOS, and @browsercompany's Arc - I eventually switched to...
User: @KagiHQ @SigmaOS @browsercompany Arc by the @browsercompany üéâ! You can read my full reasoning and review of all the browsers on my blog - but Arc has just completely stolen my heart ‚ù§Ô∏è.
User: @KagiHQ @SigmaOS @browsercompany As a writer, Arc's spaces and fullscreen workflow makes me feel so organized and focused when doing research; and as an engineer, it provides Chrome's dev tools with some added feature sugar that makes it a joy for development work.
User: @KagiHQ @SigmaOS @browsercompany I highly recommend you join Arc's waitlist and try it out yourself. And if you want to try it earlier, DM me for a referall üëç!
Summary: User is excited about the new Arc browser and has 4 browsers now.

Text:
User: I‚Äôve been looking for an app with the kind of capabilities notion has for sometime, but was hesitant to download because of all the reviews relating to its poor performance on the iPad (which is where I do most of my work), but eventually decided to give it a go since most of the reviews I saw were at least a year old and I figured they might have sorted out the bugs in it by now.
They have not. I‚Äôm writing this, not 20 minutes after initially downloading and testing it out and it‚Äôs already very clear to me that it simply doesn‚Äôt work. This is only a matter of the interface (which I would say is not super intuitive anyway) - I could have overlooked that, assuming I would get used to it with time - the very basics were not functional. It‚Äôs a battle to do even the simplest actions; scrolling down the page, selecting a template, deleting and creating pages - all the things you rely on regardless of whether the interface is to your liking. Was very willing to give this a good try before I disregarded it, but I don‚Äôt even see how that would be possible without risking all of my uni work/notes. Definitely needs a rethink, which is a shame because, according to the reviews, it works so well on laptop/PC and is obviously very effective. But this app is not conducive to working on an iPad, which effectively renders the point of having a tool that‚Äôs supposed to keep everything in one, easily accessible place moot, because, if you use a tablet (even if it‚Äôs not your main device) you simply can‚Äôt use it on there and so would either not be able to use your iPad anytime you wanted to make a note, or would have to have two separate systems. Would 100% give it another go if this problem is fixed, but at the moment, it‚Äôs just not working.
Summary: User praises the app for its powerful features and versatility, but suggests improving iPad versions, mentioning bugs, freezes, and other issues.

Text:
User: Figma is used for both our greyframes (medium-fidelity layout documents) as well as our final designs. It's collaboration tools are second to none and clients love getting the up-close look at their products. This really feels like a tool by web developers for web developers, though I will admit that the recent acquisition by Adobe makes me pretty nervous.
User: Figma is an excellent tool that forces a full paradigm shift for us designers. With auto-layout, objects on the page flow freely down the page, just like on the web. It's a 99% complete implementation of flexbox in a design program. Once you've gotten into the mindset shift of rows and columns (everything on a web page is just a nested collection of either rows or columns) you can use auto-layout to position everything on your page, and gone are the days of reflowing the entire comp because the length of the paragraph changed! (Looking at you, Photoshop).
User: The image manipulation tools are lacking. An image is either an object, which is fine, or a background. But there is no ability to set focal point on the backround, or borrow some of the CSS cover/constrain background positions.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its collaboration tools and auto-layout feature, which simplifies the design process and effectively implements flexbox. However, they find the image manipulation tools lacking, particularly in setting focal points and background positions. Some users are also concerned about the recent acquisition by Adobe.

User: Miro has been good at creating good visuals. They are helpful when I have to explain how we will work from that point on. The meetings are organic, quite explanatory and very light.

Text:
User: I actually use Figma anytime I want to edit anything. I used it for UX/UI schooling but now I work as a graphic designer and drafter where I constantly find myself pulling things into Figma for editing and finishing touches before I send it out.
User: Once you learn the different hot keys and shortcuts, you will be on your way to becoming a master at Figma! I love Figma because I can get things done quickly. Not just quickly but also your design be exactly what you want it to be. I also love the prototyping and smart animate is a life saver. And having an amazing community to be able to utilize.
User: When using the resize option, (Ctrl-K), the design options on the side toolbar go away. Which is fine and makes sense, I think. But often times I forget I'm on resize and am lost trying to figure out why everything is gone. But honestly at this point I know why and then just go back to selector mode.
Summary: The User is benefiting from Figma by using it for editing and finishing touches for their work as a graphic designer and drafter. The User loves Figma because it allows them to get things done quickly and accurately, as well as providing helpful features such as prototyping and smart animate. Additionally, the User appreciates the supportive community available to them. The User finds that when using the resize option (Ctrl-K), the design options on the side toolbar go away, which they understand but can be confusing if they forget they are in resize mode.

Text:
User: Notion would be amazing if if it was easy to do easy things. There is a lot of functionality that would make your life a lot easier. What takes away from all of this potential is a buggy and nagging experience trying to input information.
Trying to add a to-do list (checkbox) - click the Hamburger menu with your finger (iPad), list comes up, click ‚ÄúTo Do List‚Äù, menu goes away‚Ä¶ to do list item doesn‚Äôt populate. Try using touchpad, follow the same steps‚Ä¶. to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
Create a bullet point, and click the hamburger menu, ‚Äúchange to..‚Äù, ‚Äúto do list‚Äù, to do list doesn‚Äôt populate.
You are also able to do slash commands. So I press ‚Äú/‚Äú. I see the menu open and it closes immediately. The to do list is only an example. There are endless nagging bugs like this throughout the experience. So instead of being able to use the app to enhance workflows and life in general, you are constantly fighting the app.
I stopped using Notion for about 8 months and used a number of other products. Because of all the data in notion and all of the ‚Äúthings‚Äù I had set up already, I came back to because SURELY they had fixed the bugs. It‚Äôs the exact same. No more consistent or stable than it was 8 months ago.
What is really annoying to me, is that they release new features. New and shiny things like their AI tool. I WOULD RATHER HAVE AN APP THAT WORKS PROPERLY and not have AI. I don‚Äôt care about AI. I just want to be able to input data. If that works, AI would be amazing.
It will be long and arduous, but i‚Äôm moving to ClickUp.
Summary: User dislikes the clunky execution of Notion on iPad and finds it difficult to work with due to the lack of tabs and keyboard shortcuts. They also mention that the app is not as intuitive as other apps they have used.

Text:
User: Miro is helping us work virtually and collaborate in a shared space in a flexible manner. We are able to collaborate on mapping existing processes, dynamic thought mapping by categories, and a general shared space to easily collect thoughts and move them around quickly as the discussion evolves.
User: Miro is excellent for virtual whiteboarding and an excellent live collaboration tool for teams to utilize for a multitude of planning and brainstorming activities.
User: The downsides I've experienced with Miro is that it can be difficult to organize the boards you've contributed to or are actively participating in vs ones that you've previously contributed to and to separate them by categories. I haven't found a good way to categorize boards and so they all kind of land on my favorites or recent boards list and that's it, then I just have the board names to use to find what I'm looking for.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its virtual whiteboarding and live collaboration capabilities, enabling flexible teamwork and dynamic thought mapping. However, they find it challenging to organize and categorize boards, leading to difficulties in locating specific boards.

Summary: The product is helping the User to quickly analyse large amounts of data, identify correlations and gain new insights, all within a visually appealing format. Users appreciate the product's simplicity and intuitiveness, as well as its unlimited whiteboard space which is great for collaboration, forming new ideas, and making insights. The User finds that the product can become clunky when uploading multiple files, and some PDFs are difficult to read. User: Is there an easy-to-use tool to train existing LLMs with my own data? For example, I would love to give it access to my entire @NotionHQ base so it has context for what I‚Äôve already written and can write in *my own* writing style. Does this exist?

Summary: Flux is an open-source power tool for interacting with LLMs, allowing users to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel. It offers a variety of creative responses, tests different prompts with shared context, and identifies model uncertainties. Flux also features keyboard shortcuts, system message editing, autosaving, and direct use of the OpenAI API. The creators are open to collaboration and are working on an LLM collaboration tool using Ceramic Network's ComposeDB and Flux, similar to Figma for prompt design.

User: Miro solves two huge problems for me. 
 
1. Remote working and having collaborative sessions with other team members. Before I found Miro, having these sessions was incredibly hard 
2. When you write on a whiteboard, at some stage it gets rubbed off. Miro you can have endless whiteboards that you never need to delete
User: Miro is incredibly helpful for a number of reasons. The best way to look at it is like a whiteboard with all the relevant tools, online. You can use it for brainstorming sessions, mapping customer journeys, comparing notes and heaps more. It feels like I have only just scraped the surface with what is possible on Miro.
User: Honestly, there aren't many downsides to using Miro. The hardest part is probably getting use to it and understanding what you should use for certain things. Maybe some more tutorials would be helpful.
Summary: Users find Miro extremely useful for remote collaboration and as a digital whiteboard with endless space. It offers various tools for brainstorming, mapping customer journeys, and more. However, some users suggest more tutorials to help with understanding its features and usage.

Text:
User: Before Figma I had a hard time meeting up with customer requirements for Prototyping and Wireframing of mobile apps and web landing pages, I was using Photoshop and it was quite tasking. With Figma, my designs are easier, I complete them faster and I have access to more methods specifically meant for UI/UX
User: It is not as restrictive as other design applications. It is very free, easy incorporation of external files that contribute to the general design, and an interface that even a beginner can get around with ease
User: Requires a fast internet connection, and saves all your work to the cloud so a stable internet connection is a must while working. Cloud storage is an appreciable feature but offline functionality is a must-have feature as well
Summary: Users find Figma helpful for prototyping and wireframing mobile apps and web landing pages, as it is less restrictive and easier to use than other design applications like Photoshop. However, they mention that it requires a fast and stable internet connection, as all work is saved to the cloud, suggesting that offline functionality would be a valuable addition.

User: Conversations around open source in design - I‚Äôm curious if this would this improve involvement of designers in open source. Indulge me.
Having a design system where standards are defined and designers can jointly contribute components
User: These components would be based on the core styling of that design system. 
This would also include improvements to accessibility guidelines and improvements in documentation.
In turn anyone can use these components either as they are or make slight adjustments.
User: I think @figma already has a foundation to enable this - however it needs to be defined.
Having an actively maintained DS in the public domain. Not tied to any organization.
Anyone can pick it up and suggest improvements.

Summary: User is curious about the potential impact of open source design on designers' involvement in open source. They mention a design system with standards defined and components contributed by designers, which can be used by anyone. They also mention the possibility of an actively maintained design system in the public domain, which anyone can use and contribute to.

Text:
User: Continuing the discussion from Dynamic number of nested component instances:
I have components that might include a number of instances of another component, e.g., rows or columns in a table, options in a select/dropdown, etc. To accomplish this, I have to either create a separate variant for each potential number of nested instances, or create the component with the maximum possible number of nested instances and make the instances hide-able. Neither is optimal‚Äîthe first could lead to a crazy number of variants, and the second could result in a large number of hidden layers, which hits performance pretty hard.
It would be great to be able to specify a component instance to be nested in a ‚Äúparent‚Äù component then allow an arbitrary number of the nested ‚Äúchild‚Äù instances in instances of the parent component.
Summary: The user is discussing the difficulty of creating components with a dynamic number of nested instances, and suggests that it would be beneficial to be able to specify a component instance to be nested in a ‚Äúparent‚Äù component and allow an arbitrary number of the nested ‚Äúchild‚Äù instances in instances of the parent component.

They particularly enjoy the brainstorming capabilities and integration of frames for storytelling. However, they find Miro expensive due to per-user licensing and would prefer the option to share read-only boards without consuming additional licenses.

User: It would be extremely useful to have raw SVG paths exposed for the PATH object type. Not the path outlines, just the d attribute of the path. Not having this has make the api essentially unworkable for certain things, like when the absolute smallest SVG possible is required.
The only way to programmatically get the real path commands for a PATH type object is to go through the image rest api, retrieve the svg and parse it to get the d attribute.
User: The only way I know how to achieve this image is to outline a stroke, which turns it into a shape, then apply a stroke to that shape.
If that is what you are doing, the information represented by your purple line no longer exists for the node. That loss happens when you outline the stroke and all the information we have to provide is the dashed line stroke geometry.
Am I understanding that correctly? Can you share a file with this node in it if not?
image1152√ó379 13.8 KB
image1062√ó307 21.5 KB

User: Sorry - let me try to explain again.
In your example - I want to get the path command that draws the black line, but what I get out of the API is the path command that draws the outline of the path stroke, as if I had clicked ‚Äòoutline stroke‚Äô.
User: yeah, sorry if what i was saying wasnt clear. i had to outline the black line to get the dashed line. if i didn‚Äôt outline the black line, i would get the code you are looking for. you‚Äôre saying the stroke you have isn‚Äôt outlined and it is returning an outlined path? that should not be happening.
Summary: The user is saying that they had to outline the black line to get the dashed line, and that the API should not be returning an outlined path if the stroke is not outlined.

Text:
User: Hi all,
After the most recent update of Figma - Pushed a couple of days ago, prototypes using Figma‚Äôs nested component prototyping have been affected. This has been cross checked on web links / alternative machines.
This has new overwrites that aren‚Äôt included and are causing very concerning issues, especially on components that use auto layouts. This, ultimately, means if we hadn‚Äôt complete a round of user testing a couple of weeks prior we would have some serious issues.
Is anyone else getting anything similar?
Thanks,
Alex
User: I have the same issue, and it is not still resolved. Was it fixed with the weekend update for everybody else as well?
User: Yeah, seems to be fixed for me now. I‚Äôve named everything back to how it was and it‚Äôs still working.
User: Thanks man, works for me after renaming. Doesn‚Äôt work after reseting name back. Still better than nothing, but it is a real pain as thats part of our design system and i should provide some guideance how to use that component
Summary: Users are experiencing issues with Figma's nested component prototyping after a recent update, particularly with auto layouts. The problem has been reported to the support team, and they are now in contact with the user.

Text:
User: Currently, when you test a prototype on a mobile device it will fit the prototype to the width of the testing device, despite the fact the zoom mode is called ‚ÄúFit to screen‚Äù or ‚Äúcontain‚Äù in the URL request param. Which results in a bad experience when the prototype is designed in a higher aspect ratio than the device you‚Äôre testing the prototype with. Main CTAs placed on the bottom of the screen will appear underneath the fold for example.
It would be ideal if you select ‚ÄúFit to screen‚Äù the artboards will actually fit the screen. So if the testing device has a less high aspect ratio than the artboard, space will be added to the sides of the prototype. And if the testing device has a higher aspect ratio than the artboard, space will be added to the top and bottom of the prototype.
The ‚ÄúFit width‚Äù zoom mode can be used for the current behavior.

User: 1. The point is that you can't select and drag all blocks or multiple blocks at once within a page. If you want to move the source to another location, you have to copy it one by one. I hope it can be improved soon. It's really inconvenient. If only these two things are solved, it's 5 points.
‚Äî
Add a new
3. The handl<IP>for moving or modifying blocks doesn't appear in the iPad app, so it's very inconvenient when changing colors or changing attributes. I wonder why this isn't fixed... Strangely enough, it's much more comfortable to go directly to Chrome and make edits on the iPad than the app. The reason for the separate app is unclear. I'm going to lose my score because of this lol
Summary: User finds the app inconvenient due to the inability to select and drag multiple blocks at once and the lack of double window support. The user also mentions that it's more comfortable to edit on the iPad than the app, which is strange considering the separate app.

Text:
User: üöÄ How to turn an ‚Äûalmost perfect‚Äù UI/UX to ‚Äûperfect‚Äù.
Using <STRICT_LINK> as a perfect example (created by @cnnr_cllhn) <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more ‚Äûconcise‚Äù adjective without using ‚Äûvery‚Äù. Example: very rich = affluent.
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that .It's straight to the point (just like the Google Search homepage). So what's the problem? <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn ‚ùå There are 3 main flaws:
1. Site feels messy
2. Design lacks consistency
3. Elements feel a little too cramped
We'll approach it ‚Äûvia negativa‚Äù style: by removing stuff rather than adding.
üë©üé® Let's work on that that using @figma
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 1Ô∏è‚É£: Decluttering üßπ
The most important step would be to remove the clutter ‚Äì the annoying newsletter popup, the newsletter section and the newsletter banner. We'll get back to it later.
This has already made a difference. The interface looks significantly cleaner. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 2Ô∏è‚É£: Let the design breathe üí®
Let's add more whitespace ‚Äì the more the better. This will achieve a better visual separation.
Now the `very + x = y` line instantly grabs our attention. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 3Ô∏è‚É£: Making buttons prettier üíÑ
Buttons look chaotic here: randomly spaced, different padding, etc.
Let's increase the font size, adjust the padding and replace the word ‚Äûrandom‚Äù with a dice icon. We'll also ‚Äûinvert‚Äù the third button.
The buttons now look modern and consistent. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 4Ô∏è‚É£: Typography üñäÔ∏è
The typography is a mess (4 diffrent typefaces on one page!). Let's reduce our typeface choices to just 2. We'll leave the sans font, but let's choose a different serif font.
I would choose a humanist style serif. Let's go with ‚ÄûCrimson Pro‚Äù. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user discussed how to improve the UI/UX of a website called LoseTheVery, which helps find concise adjectives. They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

Text:
User: I use it for several things: private documents to guide my thinking and notes; collaborative whiteboards; sharing diagrams with colleagues; and documentation.
User: As far as I'm aware, Miro is unique in its ability to enable a user to rapidly build diagrams in real-time while other users observe or contribute simultaneously. I can create flow charts and diagrams so quickly. And it's easy to make the results look great.
User: The tables feature is lackluster, but it's still an experiment. Other than that, the licensing model has been slightly annoying to deal with. If I want a colleague to contribute to a board, they need a full license, even if they use it for 30 minutes and never use it again. This arrangement doesn't feel optimal from a fairness and value point-of-view, but I still find the tool to be worth the money.
Summary: The user finds Miro unique in its ability to enable rapid diagram creation in real-time, while others can observe or contribute. They appreciate the ease of use and the ability to create great-looking diagrams. However, they find the licensing model to be slightly annoying and would prefer a more fair and value-oriented arrangement.

Text:
User: Miro has become our virtual office since we started telecommuting. It has been the best choice for us. 
 
We use Miro to exchange ideas, visualize data in user-friendly formats and plan some processes.
User: Miro excellently simulates a whiteboard to create a virtual space that I really like. I can hardly feel the difference between this software and the whiteboard I have in my office. 
 
Thus, the platform has become an ideal virtual office for real-time collaboration. 
 
Some features like sticky notes, surveys and polls enhance the experience.
User: The categorization of the boards is complicated. I am still looking for a way to sort them out that I like. However, the performance and features keep me sticking with this software.
Summary: Users find Miro to be an effective virtual office for telecommuting, offering a realistic whiteboard simulation and features like sticky notes, surveys, and polls for real-time collaboration. However, they find the categorization of boards to be complicated and are seeking a better way to sort them.

Text:
User: FigJam is the one-stop shop for collaboration in my current team, and many teams I've been a part of in the past. It's a our virtual whiteboard for low-fidelity ideation, brainstorming, and alignment activities.
User: I use Figjam daily for all ranges of team collaboration ‚Äì from rapid ideation to flow mapping, and user research planning to facilitating product workshops. It's a critical tool for a remote-first environment, and I always appreciate all the ongoing updates that add to usability, performance, and speed.
User: There's not much to dislike about FigJam since the product has ongoing updates that always seem to address whatever feedback I have! Some additional customization (e.g. background color and styles) could be fun, but the tool is already extremely flexible for all sorts of use cases.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam as a one-stop shop for collaboration, especially in remote-first environments. They use it for various purposes, including ideation, flow mapping, and user research planning. Users also value the ongoing updates that improve usability, performance, and speed, but suggest additional customization options, such as background colors and styles.

Text: User: The app itself is so amazing that I'm always thankful to use it very well. However, for users who work on documents and general tasks, poor Bluetooth keyboard connectivity is too fatal. Even if I try to type text from the iPad to the Bluetooth keyboard, the cursor disappears and I can't write at all. So in the end, I have to use a separate laptop, which is such a fatal flaw that makes my personal reason for buying an iPad and starting to use Notion come to nothing. Please improve the Bluetooth keyboard connectivity. By the way, I mainly use Cyclone's K3 model. If only keyboard connectivity were improved, it could be recognized as the best app that could not be expressed even with five stars. The fact that I can't use an external keyboard is so decisive for me.
Summary: User is satisfied with the app but has issues with Bluetooth keyboard connectivity, making it difficult to use on the iPad. They suggest improving the keyboard connectivity to make the app more useful for their needs.

Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

Text:
User: **Arc browser continuous review**
Tl;dr: I'm loving it! So far, it's been a fantastic experience. Arc brings a lot of fresh air to a place where innovation seemingly stopped.
What is Arc? Check out @browsercompany <STRICT_LINK>
Dive into the thread below üßµ (1/n)
User: 1. First-time use experience
Really well done. I enjoyed the semi-interactive intro/learning experience. The keyboard shortcuts were introduced, too.
Setting up the colour scheme was excellent. Straight away, you know these guys are trying to do something different üòç
User: 2. First-time use (contd.)
I wish there was a bit more 'practice your shortcuts'; the only one that stuck with me was the one I already use elsewhere (‚åò+T).
Saying that, ‚åò+T execution is excellent and can be used for commands, very much like ‚åò+K in other apps.
User: 3. Split view
This is my #1 feature so far.
It seems to me that the people at @browsercompany invested in getting to know users.
One would doubt there could be anything left to learn about using a browser in 2023. What 'customer problems' are there left to solve?
And still!
User: 4. Split view (contd.)
Split view solves a problem many of us have when we attempt to multitask. Our current workarounds include constantly rearranging windows (üíö to you BetterSnapTool) etc. It's chaos!
Time will tell if Split view solves this, but right now, I'm thrilled!
User: 5. Split view (contd.)
The microinteractions here feel just right. Intuitive, discoverable. The onboarding helped, too.
User: 6. Profiles
This is a big one for me. I struggled with this on Chrome. My solution was to strictly use Chrome for work stuff plus Safari for personal use.
But obviously, that doesn't work well.
User: 7. Ecosystem
My incumbent browsers allow me to browse across devices with one app ecosystem. I can easily continue on my iPadPro Safari, where I left off on my laptop and then seamlessly move to my phone.
Arc needs a mobile/tablet app.
User: 8. Mini Arc
I took the plunge and made Arc my default browser, and suddenly links from Slack opened in Mini Arc.
Great when I need to quickly check stuff and close the tab. But if I need to stay longer in the context, I still need to move from the Mini Arc to the full Arc.
User: 9. Sidebar
Shifting the tabs from the top bar to a sidebar was smart. This suits me for a few reasons
a) wide angle screen form factor
b) utility of vertical space is better for Spaces, history etc., all co-existing in one area
User: 10. Sidebar
However, my eyes were trained to look for tabs on top of the screen for so long that having them on LHS feels weird. This might change after a few more days.
I'd love the ability to move the sidebar between LHS and RHS, depending on when I place Arc on my monitor.
User: 11. Ecosystem (contd.)
I expected browsing on Arc won't be seamless across devices w.out native iOS apps. Turns out the iPadOS/MacOS continuity pushes the current tab across devices on the same iCloud account.
Not sure about the predictability of this, but so far looks good!
User: 12. Living with Arc
- can't imagine giving up Spaces
- pinned folders/bookmarks as expected
- keep forgetting to use Favourites
- have a love/hate relationship w. links opening in overlay
@browsercompany I *really* want to change icons on pinned folders, pretty please!
User: 13. The iOS app dropped
Unexpected but pleasant! Can't wait to dive in :-)
<STRICT_LINK>
User: Hey @browsercompany I need your help!
Is there a way to tell apps to open links in a specific space?
E.g. my Slack always open links in my work space/profile?
I'm logged into two different Google accounts across two spaces.
Summary: User is excited about the new features in the latest version of BrowserCO, including the split view and Easel, and is looking forward to becoming an Arc power user.

Text:
User: I can analyse data in visual form really quickly on Miro - it really helps connect the dots when you can see all of the information in one space. it is also really helpful as a collaborative tool - i no longer have to be the single scribe, everyone can contribute actively during brainstorming and it really helps with getting open feedback from stakeholders which is not often easy to do verbally. i don't think i could be without miro especially in a remote working environment.
User: Working fully remotely, Miro is my most frequently used software because there is no other tool that lets me collaborate, ideate and present information across screens more easily than Miro. I can't say that i even miss physical brainstorming boards because i no longer have to transfer handwritten notes to a digital format - it saves so much time and nothing goes missing. it's really easy to track information and review past discussions because everything is captured digitally. all of the tools and templates are very handy, i don't have to think to much about how to structure information - it's plug and play and there's so much you can do. the interface is very intuitive.
User: Miro on ipad pro could be improved to leverage the capabilities of tablets. i use miro exclusively on my computer and hardly ever on the ipad because it is very buggy and takes too long to do what i would normally do on a computer. writing is fine but it's not enough for me to also use miro on my tablet - it's a shame but i guess Freeform is a good simple and free alternative. it would also be great if Miro could be used in offline mode with an option to sync once online.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's simplicity, templates, real-time collaboration, and ample workspace for brainstorming and problem-solving. However, they feel that Miro offers more tools and integration options, suggesting that easy access of Miro use could be beneficial

Text:
User: During workshops, I mainly use it to brainstorm all together or one after the other as a desynchronized tool when we can not meet all together. I encourage my team to input their ideas directly into Figjam and collaborate to organize the file as a comprehensive reference document for the future of the project.
User: Figjam is a powerful tool for enhancing collaboration and idea visualization. With its real-time collaboration feature and commenting system, teamwork becomes effortless. The file management system and template library are unparalleled among the competition, making it a standout option.
User: Multi account management and several workspaces can make the experience a bit difficult on the daily basis. I often find myself lost searching for my current workspace.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma's Figjam for its real-time collaboration, commenting system, and file management, which enhance teamwork and idea visualization. However, they find multi-account management and navigating multiple workspaces challenging, making the daily experience difficult.

Text:
User: If your @figma files are low on memory and you've taken lengths to reduce file size but don't see an increase in memory, it's likely your version history. Fix by publishing the library, CUT and paste everything into a new file, then publish the new file.
User: @katiecooperco @figma Does this preserve the linked component instances? It's a brilliant tip!
User: @SamIam_Designs @katiecooperco @figma i'd expect the connections to be protected so long as you _cut_ and paste!
docs, if it's helpful: <STRICT_LINK>
User: @AlPackah @SamIam_Designs @figma Yes! I‚Äôve done it many times. cut cut cut
User: @katiecooperco @AlPackah @figma Copy Pasta ‚úÖ <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user suggests that if Figma files are low on memory despite efforts to reduce file size, the issue may be related to version history. They recommend fixing this by publishing the library, cutting and pasting everything into a new file, and then publishing the new file. This method is confirmed to preserve linked component instances.

Text:
User: Dear @NotionHQ,
I recently obtained my certification from your platform, and while I appreciate the knowledge and skills I gained from the experience, I believe it's time for a change in your testing methods.
User: @NotionHQ We're in 2023, and your current question-and-answer format feels outdated. With the vast resources available to us online, including Google, Notion docs, and ChatGPT, it's unnecessary to rely solely on memorization and rote learning.
User: @NotionHQ I suggest implementing a challenge or project-based approach to make the tests more engaging and interesting. Spending an hour answering questions only to fall short of the 70% passing mark feels like a waste of time, and time is a valuable commodity for everyone.
Summary: User is excited about the new Notion platform and is testing it for internal documentation.

Text:
User: Collaborating with people in different locations and timezones 
Repository - bringing multimedia assets related to a single project into one space 
Collaborating without a tool like this would be incredibly difficult.
User: As a UX researcher, I've been using Miro for years. It helped me collaborate remotely before the pandemic forced everyone to go remote. I've used it for project management, research synthesis, collaboration and feedback and even lightweight design. The templates help save time when putting together something like a Gantt or Kanban board. An absolute must for remove workshops: love the timer, background musing, voting, 'Follow me' mode. Very easy to learn.
User: The UI has gotten a bit busy, with controls in all 4 corners of the screen. I supposed it's expected for a tool that does so many jobs.
Summary: The user finds Miro excellent for facilitating collaboration during workshops and team-based activities, praising its real-time collaboration capabilities, wide range of tools and templates, and rich media integration. However, they experience performance issues with large boards or many simultaneous users and feel that customization options can be restrictive.

User: It doesn‚Äôt look like there‚Äôs an obvious way to change the order of exposed nested instances. Right now the order seems to be based on reverse layer order. It‚Äôd be great if the order can be manually adjusted.
User: Just wanted to +100 this request. Exposing nested props is what makes Figma super scalable with complex Design System components (e.g., molecules, organisms, templates) and not being able to control the order of these props almost defeat the whole purpose as these props will bounce around based on variants & sub-variants‚Ä¶
Please Figma team!
Summary: Users are requesting a way to manually adjust the order of exposed nested instances in Figma, as the current order seems to be based on reverse layer order. They believe this feature is crucial for scalability with complex Design System components and controlling the order of properties.

Text:
User: cranked out 3600 word blog post today
HOW TO RESCUE YOUR FIGMA FILE FROM THE DEPTHS OF HELL AND LIVE TO TELL THE TALE üî•
silly but passionate title. it's about reducing memory usage.
subscribe to my newsletter if you want to be notified when it drops: <STRICT_LINK> <STRICT_LINK>
User: this monster is so long because i committed to writing detailed, step by step instructions.
and it's not some dinky 3 step "deLeTE hIdDeN laYeRs"
this thing is METICULOUS üò§ i leave no one behind ‚ù§Ô∏èüî•
User: like, if you're in Figma-hell, and you're googling how to get this file fixed, the last thing you need is some bullshit SEO-gaming gloss-over article with 3 steps explaining how to click on layers and delete them üôÑ
not on my blog. nope.
User: - how to make a wicked strategic action plan and target the most gnarly parts of your file first.
 
- multiple plugins (most are free!) you can leverage to speed up this work.
whole post is designed to get you back to a safe amount of memory usage as quickly as possible.
User: i spent all day on this and need to let it simmer and do a round of editing later, but i'm really excited to put this out in the world. first blog post of 2023 is üí™üí™üí™
shout out to @gleb_sexy and @sedatcak ‚≠êÔ∏èü§ùüíØ you've each inspired and facilitated this post in a big way üíñ
User: the editing hat is on ü§† here's a teaser outline of this soon-to-launch blog post:
‚õ∞ Milestone 1: Develop a plan of attack
- Prepare your detective notes.
- Find the highest concentration of layers.
(üëá cont.)
User: ‚õ∞ Milestone 2: Reduce as many layers as possible.
- Remove draft material
- Remove unnecessary hidden layers from regular frames
- Remove all unnecessary hidden layers from main components in your local file
(üëá cont.)
User: ‚õ∞ Milestone 3: Reduce variant count
- Introduce "exposed nested instances"
- Eliminate ‚Äúfaux-repeater" properties in favor of using ‚úé content carriers
- Consider divesting from variants altogether üôä
(üëá cont.)
User: ‚õ∞ Milestone 4: Compress images. 
- Leverage the Downsize plugin and ImageOptim
‚õ∞ Milestone 5: Simplify complex vectors.
fin.
User: i put a lot of thought into the order of these steps. my hypothesis is this is the most effective order to gain back Figma file memory as quickly as possible.
again, my newsletter subscribers will be the first to know when I hit publish: <STRICT_LINK>
User: published üî•
<STRICT_LINK>
User: looks like @figma made some big enhancements to the "resource use" panel, which is now "memory usage"
<STRICT_LINK>
happy days!

<STRICT_LINK>

User: Before starting each project, I meet with my clients to know what they want. To do this, we connect through Miro and create a dashboard to facilitate these explanations so that what is most important is recorded. 
The result of this session is what I use as a basis for the approach of the project in question virtual office.
User: Miro's navigation was the reason why I decided to use it. It is so good that anyone can adapt to the software with a couple of simple directions. 
I love that the templates can be modified with a few clicks to suit the moment's needs. 
And their visuals are lovely, complete and easy to understand.
User: Miro has no fundamental weaknesses. It is software that does what it is supposed to do. If it is necessary to use other apps, it is because Miro is not designed for it.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its easy navigation, customizable templates, and visually appealing interface. They find it effective for client meetings and project planning, and believe it fulfills its intended purpose without any significant weaknesses.

User: FigJam is helping us work through complex product logic with clients. As we make bespoke software solutions, we need to understand the core outcomes that a client is looking to achieve and then we can walk them through multiple ways to optimize the process of achieving those outcomes.
User: FigJam is an amazing tool. I often use it for logic flows for internal decisions as well as the logic flows for product decisions with external clients and partners.
User: I wish there were two versions, one for product decision making and then a live/simplified version that could be used during meetings for walking through product decisions with less-technology focused people.
Summary: Users find FigJam helpful for working through complex product logic with clients and internal decision-making. They appreciate its ability to optimize processes and facilitate collaboration with external partners. However, they suggest having two versions: one for product decision-making and a simpler, live version for meetings with less tech-savvy individuals.

„ÉªHaving to press the completion button in the upper right corner every time you perform an operation is troublesome. Place the button in a place where it's a little easier to press (like the bottom), or make it possible to complete the operation by simply scrolling

Text:
User: I have a problem with the horizontal scroll of my prototype, it works perfect only if I don‚Äôt apply the dropshadow to the cards. I can‚Äôt figure out why, can anyone help me?
No dropshadow
With dropshadow
As you can see, the link with dropshadow, horizontal scroll works strange the initial position has a space and also the final‚Ä¶
thank you
User: @Raffaele_Parlato hey I also faced the same problem, and hours of researching I found the issue. Instead of applying dropshadow on every card individually, but instead group the cards together and then applying it as a whole. This should completely fix the problem.
User: @Raffaele_Parlato I‚Äôm not exactly sure what the issue is here with the scrolling, (I‚Äôm just guessing the system adds the shadow to the size of the cards) but I also found another problem with this which is the shadows actually overlap on one another (although it may not seem so, I used the colorpicker to test). but when you group them together, the shadows are always at the bottom and do not go over other cards.
Summary: Users faced issues with horizontal scrolling in Figma prototypes when applying dropshadow to individual cards. A suggested solution is to group the cards together and apply the dropshadow to the entire group, which also prevents shadow overlapping.

User: Hi all, I am working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from our team library. Through research I think the way is to first use Figma REST API to get the keys of styles from our library file, and the use figma.importStyleByKeyAsync() to import the style. However, the issue is, this requires me to put my Access token in the plugin, and I don‚Äôt want to. Is there a way for plugin to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin?
Or are there any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin? Thanks a lot!!!
Summary: The user is working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from their team library. They are looking for a way to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin, or any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin.

User: Cost - might affect small teams. When boards are significantly large, we experience some lagging.
Summary: The architect user appreciates Miro for enabling idea sharing and innovation in large team sessions through whiteboard drawings and easy authentication and content sharing. However, they mention the cost might be a concern for small teams and experience lagging with large boards.

Text:
User: Hi, I believe I‚Äôve exhausted all the existing help articles on this.
I‚Äôm having a hard time with something that should be very basic. I have 25 or so screens, the ONLY interaction between them is that the user should be able to click and/or press the arrow key to navigate LINEARLY between them.
Sometimes it works (especially if I go slowly, it works every time). But sometimes it doesn‚Äôt, sometimes it inexplicably jumps through sections (pretty much only happens if I press the arrow keys quickly). It appears that if I click through it goes linearly every time without skipping screens. So the problem is only with the arrow keys (which I can‚Äôt disable so I need to understand the behavior before handing off to my client).
I‚Äôve adjusted all the artboards. The desired order is Row 1 Left to Right, Row 2 Left to Right (as described in the documentation). All rows have the exact same Y coordinate. All columns have the exact same X coordinate.
I‚Äôve spent hours on this already and this is really basic behavior so I‚Äôm not sure why it‚Äôs so hard, I want it to act like powerpoint in presentation mode.
Any help is appreciated. I can‚Äôt really share the prototype because I‚Äôm on NDA.
User: Or up vote the solution here‚Ä¶
 
 
 
 Remove auto creating flow starting points Share an idea
 
 
 I love the new feature that allows multiple prototypes per page. One issue I‚Äôm having with it, is it assumes I want everything to be a new flow starting point each time I don‚Äôt link something from the first flow starting page. 
It has a very linear mindset. When I work/prototype I tend to work on a section, then link it back and that creates many flow starting points on accident and I have to delete them. 
It‚Äôd be nice if either - it only created the first one, and doesn‚Äôt assume you want many o‚Ä¶
Summary: User is having trouble with a basic feature in Figma, where clicking and/or pressing the arrow keys to navigate linearly between screens works sometimes and not others. They have adjusted all artboards and the desired order is Row 1 Left to Right, Row 2 Left to Right, but the issue persists. The user is concerned about the linear mindset of the feature, as it creates many flow starting points accidentally and needs to be adjusted.

Text:
User: Miro helps with the problem of gaining consensus among a disparate group of Product team planners. Miro boarding all the different ideas, then being able to shuffle them into priority order can more quickly help solidify the team plan and direction.
User: I like the collaborative nature of the Miro app. Live-time editing with multiple team members is easy. It's a good replacement solution for a conference room whiteboard, especially when many members in a large corporate structure often work remotely or travel.
User: Cutting and pasting into the Miro board allows vision comparisons using graphic elements but some desired items can't be easily placed; excel tables and HTML get shredded. Also, I'd like to see a little more robust editing of post-it note styles.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's collaborative features for gaining consensus among product team members and its ability to replace conference room whiteboards. However, they face challenges with importing Excel tables and HTML content and desire more robust editing options for post-it note styles.

Text:
User: Helps to visually explain complex systems in a simple way. Provides value to our consultancy.
User: FigJam's simplicity and ease of use enables fast mapping and sharing of complex systems and dependencies. I've recently created several sprawling figjam charts that outline marketing programs from beginning to end for our clients. They have been so helpful keeping the team informed at a high level and are a great reference to regularly huddle around. 
 
This is just one kind of use - because of its flexibility you can begin to discover ways to think and present ideas large or small. Create fast design mock-ups, review and provide feedback on designs, create storyboards - the list can go on and on. Easily shareable to anyone with little to no trouble with login attempts or dealing with incompatible file types. 
 
It feels so freeing to break from the clunky confines of a ppt slide with its bad clip art and boring bullet points. Expanding across an endless canvas allows us to combat any confusion or anxiety that tends to show up around building complex marketing campaigns. 
 
Figjam has become one the most valuable tools in my arsenal and is one of the best I've seen after almost 2 decades of working with these types of apps. 
 
Highly recommended!
User: Can't think of any at the moment. I need to spend more time exploring all the templates to expand my usage.
Summary: The user highly recommends FigJam for its simplicity, ease of use, and flexibility in creating and sharing complex systems, marketing programs, and design mock-ups. They appreciate the endless canvas, which helps combat confusion and anxiety around building complex marketing campaigns. FigJam has become one of their most valuable tools after two decades of experience with similar apps.

Text:
User: I like using MIro to manage projects, brainstorm, collaborate, visualize data and processes, and it's a great tool for facilitating any conversation and workshop because it encourages active participation.
User: Miro is great for instant and seamless collaboration and has a ton of great features, including sticky notes that you can color-code, pre-filled-out templates to accomplish whatever you need, and a nice, clean, user-friendly interface.
User: The only downside I can see is that it could be technically daunting to some people to learn new software. However, after using it in workshops and encouraging people to explore, they usually come around to it. I also wish that the free version had more free boards to create instead of being limited to 3.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its project management, brainstorming, and collaboration capabilities, as well as its user-friendly interface and features like color-coded sticky notes and templates. However, some users may find it challenging to learn the software, and they wish the free version offered more than three boards.

Text:
User: Team collaboration, brainstorming, idea consolidation, timeline and roadmap creation, documentation of ideation and feedback, easy collaboration with internal and external parties.
User: I have been using Miro on and off for roughly 3 years now, and I always find myself gravitating to it. Whether internal meetings or external meetings with clients, the tool is valuable for conducting whiteboarding sessions, brainstorming ideas, and overall collaborating with larger teams. I have also used it for project retrospectives, creating timelines, and wireframing dashboards. It is user-friendly and has every connection/capability I can think of!
User: I honestly can't think of anything. The connections are great, the interface is sleek, and the application as a whole is very user-friendly. Maybe optimizing mouse scrolls for easier navigation within a board? But even that is very smooth as-is.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro as their top choice for collaboration with clients, as it allows real-time feedback, process documentation, and easy onboarding. It is particularly useful for remote teams and different time zones. However, users face issues with size capacity, slow performance with too many screenshots, messy boards, and minor formatting problems.

Text:
User: I'm not a big planner to begin with, probably due to my lack of enjoyment for more mainstream planners like Google calendar and traditional paper planners. Google (while claiming to be user-friendly) had too many tools and GUI's to navigate through which felt overwhelming to me, while still lacking the flexibility I desired. Paper planners I encountered in the store didn't do the job either because they were not formatted exactly how I wanted, and of course a regular old notebook didn't provide the online accessibility I wanted.
Notion is everything you wanted in a planner, and truly helped bring the planning side of me back to reality. It provided helpful templates I could use to give an overall format for what I wanted to write (checklists, boxes, etc.) which were incredibly customizable. The tool is simple yet powerful, without any unnecessary visual effects or special features you are forced to learn. I love that Notion can be accessed on any device via the website or app, and my plans look the exact same in any format without shifting its orientation or completely up-hauling the website layout. I would recommend this to anyone.
Summary: User loves the app for organizing scripts and weekly planners, but finds it useful for many other things, such as shift work and 24/7 usage.

Text:
User: Is there an easy-to-use tool to train existing LLMs with my own data? For example, I would love to give it access to my entire @NotionHQ base so it has context for what I‚Äôve already written and can write in *my own* writing style. Does this exist?
User: @devansood @NotionHQ Working on it. Might be a bit tho
Summary: Flux is an open-source power tool for interacting with LLMs, allowing users to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel. It offers a variety of creative responses, tests different prompts with shared context, and identifies model uncertainties. Flux also features keyboard shortcuts, system message editing, autosaving, and direct use of the OpenAI API. The creators are open to collaboration and are working on an LLM collaboration tool using Ceramic Network's ComposeDB and Flux, similar to Figma for prompt design.

Text:
User: Mass editing a table/database is so slow and buggy. No copy/paste to updated related cells.
Merge just creates new duplicate rows.
Speed it up, lose the faux AI and clean up tables/database. See AirTable as an example how editing is better. I don‚Äôt need all their features, but Notion is too slow to work with.
Summary: User finds Notion's mass editing feature slow and buggy, and suggests improving speed and removing AI features to make it more user-friendly. They also suggest merging tables and databases to reduce duplicate rows and improve performance.

Text:
User: It really helps with strategy visuals and telling the story of why work is important. It also helps to organize information when needed. I love the ability to create to-dos for areas of my business and represent it in one place.
User: The visualization ability to convey a story. I appreciate the open-source templates. I can use it for almost anything from planning a baby shower to road mapping a development team's work.
User: I don't like how you can't format a shape to mimic another. Sometimes the table formatting doesn't work right. I can't add a row of cells to the top of a table, only below. I wish you could designate that connecting lines don't intersect, and if you have to pull a point to make the connecting lines not intersect, they smooth out so the line doesn't look so jagged. Also, do you have a critical path template? If not, that would also be very helpful.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma's visualization capabilities for various purposes, including strategy visuals, organizing information, and creating to-dos. They also enjoy the open-source templates. However, they dislike the inability to format shapes, issues with table formatting, and jagged connecting lines. They suggest improvements in these areas and request a critical path template.

Text:
User: I first came across it during an online course and fell in love with it! So I adopted it for my teams working from home. Now we are pretty much back in the office but its still my go to. We all sit around a massive table to collab and ideate and its all captured in real time on the board. I find it really aesthetically pleasing, which helps. and whatever I need, there is a template for it or something that can be tweaked.
User: The infinity of the boards is excellent - the templates, tools, colours, simplicity of navigation and its super intuitive so you don't have to learn loads of new stuff to use it! I love you can bring people to you - I love the tutorials. I love Miroverses....
User: When I have invited people to join my team, they inevitably love it and go off to create their own, which results in one of my boards being disabled to its a bit of a faff to sling them out of my team, copy the content to a new board and then get my board back. 
Also I really struggle with the % zoom. My boards have been built at 1% so when I copy and paste something in, its always so tiny that I have to locate a spec, and zoom in to highlight this to drag and enlarge. Its a massive pain! I dont know how to fix this now.
Summary: The user appreciates the versatility and ease of use of Miro, especially for remote work and collaboration with clients. They appreciate the templates and templates' ability to store information for later use. However, they find the board too responsive and dizzying when teammates move around it, and they need more practice zooming in and out.

User: Notion itself is powerful, but the app must get a low score! However, all functions cannot be operated on the app. For example, basic operations such as moving positions of some objects on the app are not possible! The interface usually gets stuck and is difficult to operate, and the compatibility is poor. If you don't want to do a more complete edit on the app, you'll die! Very poor experience of use! It's best to use it on a computer!
Also, sharing content from another place to Notion is very difficult to use. After sharing, you have to go back to Notion to do a bunch of operations and organization. This kind of basic requirement should be designed to be easy to use! I don't even understand that I shared a Youtube video to Notion. The result was to set up a page in Notion. Then the title was: What's the point of the URL?! It can't be designed. Can you create a page with the title of the video or go to an existing page and then create an embedded video??
Summary: User finds Notion powerful but finds the app difficult to use due to its poor interface and lack of basic functions. They also find it difficult to share content from other apps and find the title of the shared video to be confusing. The user suggests improving the app's interface and functionality, as well as creating a page with the title of the shared video.

Text:
User: Being able to solidify abstract thoughts and conversations into a cohesive solution. It allows us to see the mess and confusion among our teams and then move toward cohesion and clear direction.
User: Miro allows me to work abstractly and keeping better track of that work. PPT does okay with conceptualizing, but it can only do so much. Miro lets me think more clearly, create integrations, and bring other people along on the journey all the while offering a great interface.
User: There are almost too many options. The templates help with this quite a bit, but deciding on the right approach with so much white space and possibilities can be hard.
Summary: Users appreciate Figma for its ability to turn abstract thoughts into cohesive solutions and providing a clear direction for teams. They find Miro helpful for working abstractly and keeping track of their work, offering a better interface than PowerPoint. However, some users find the numerous options overwhelming and struggle to decide on the right approach.

Text:

User: Templates are limited and need more use cases, and better search option to find the available features or may be a help option which can navigate the user to the right option.
Summary: The user finds Figma helpful for creating and sharing designs using pre-populated templates and appreciates the easy navigation, drag and drop options, and integrations. However, they suggest improvements in the template variety, search functionality, and the addition of a help option for better navigation.

Summary: Users appreciate FigJam's collaborative features, intuitive interface, and versatility for remote teams, making it suitable for brainstorming, wireframes, and user flows. However, it lacks advanced design features compared to other design tools, limiting its use for more complex design work.

Text:
