User: All of the best features are locked by the pro version, which is understandable, but would be great to have a free trial. Also, dark mode would also be a nice feature!
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its engaging and intuitive interface, especially for retrospectives and team-building activities. They find the templates and integrations valuable, but some users wish for a free trial of the pro version and a dark mode feature.

Text:
User: Hi!
Turning off ‚Äúsnap to pixel grid‚Äù in a Figma Design file no longer changes snapping behavior when dragging frames around.
Whether this feature is turned on or off, a dragged frame still snaps to each pixel, no matter how zoomed-in. Note that some other objects (e.g., vector objects) still respect this setting. It‚Äôs just an issue with frames, components, and component instances. Note that If I group the frame, I then can drag the group to any sub-pixel location.
I‚Äôve restarted my machine, restarted Figma, checked for updates, reloaded tabs, tried it in other design files. Tried it in the client, in Chrome, and in Safari. Same problem.
Can anyone else replicate this?
User: Uff‚Ä¶ This is a huge issue for creating illustrations and configuring logos, vector graphics, etc. Please fix this.
Summary: Users are experiencing issues with the "snap to pixel grid" feature in Figma, as it no longer changes snapping behavior when dragging frames, components, and component instances. This is causing difficulties in creating illustrations and configuring logos and vector graphics.

Text:
User: Hi, I have an using when using the Figma.
When I disable the Chrome Hardware acceleration, I am able to open the Figma without any issue, albeit slower.
But when I enable the chrome hardware acceleration setting, everytime I open Figma, my browser will flicker once, and says that my browser did not support WEBGL.
Is there anyway to fix it?
I need to enable the hardware acceleration for other chrome features. But then I won‚Äôt be able to use Figma if I do so.
User: Hi @Tsasqa_Galih ,
Is this happening on a specific file or all the files?
If this is happening on a specific file, then it might be possible the file has reached its memory limits.
Figma is a browser-based app, which means it‚Äôs subjected to a 2GB available memory limit that applies to each browser tab, including those in our Desktop App. When loading or editing Figma files nears or exceeds this memory limit, it can cause performance issues like long load times or crashes.
I recommend you to:
Reduce the size of the file will usually help with load speed
Reduce the size of individual pages (for example by splitting a page into multiple pages) will usually help with rendering performance.
Hidden layers: loading and then hiding a large number of layers, especially in components or with images stored in them, can cause a high use of available memory on loading.
Stacked Masks and Effects like shadows and blurs also take a lot of memory to load.
You can find more tips in our Help Center article on how to Reduce memory usage in files that will help you to avoid hitting this limit again.
If you are still running into issues despite these workflows, you can reach out our support team so they can take a deeper a look into your issues here. Hope it helps!
User: Hi @Celine_Doan
It‚Äôs happening to all files actually.
Which is weird since i can still access all files without issue if i turned the browser hardware acceleration off.
i also tried using my other laptop with the hardware acceleration on to open all the files, and it does not have the same issue.
User: Hi @Tsasqa_Galih ,
Thank you for the details!
Can you also ensure WebGL is enabled in Google Chrome? The steps to do this are in this article: <STRICT_LINK>
If it is still doesn‚Äôt fix your issue, please reach out to the team by filling this form with all detail you recall (WEBGL issue, happening to all files, affecting browser and/or desktop etc): here
Our technical team can investigate further. Thank you!
User: thanks Celine. i followed the steps needed on the article and it still doesnt work.
but i‚Äôll fill the form you provided.
Cheers!
Summary: User experiences browser flickering and WebGL issues when using Figma with Chrome hardware acceleration enabled, affecting all files. The issue doesn't occur when hardware acceleration is disabled or on another laptop. User tried enabling WebGL and following suggested steps, but the problem persists. They will fill out a form for further investigation.

User: i know this has been posted before, but Figma really needs to address this issue. pasting an email address should not just format the existing text as a link with the new text as a destination. when creating prototypes with lots of dummy accounts, or even with real data, copying and pasting lots of emails becomes the hardest part of my day, and there are no key shortcuts either. i have to copy, then right click, paste to replace. or ‚Äúcopy as text.‚Äù it‚Äôs obnoxious, and frankly i don‚Äôt think anyone using Figma has ever needed a functional email link for a prototype, it‚Äôs not like we‚Äôre creating live products where someone might actually click the email link to send an email.
please fix this Figma, it‚Äôs infuriating and breaks the flow of creating prototypes. When basically every prototype i create for work requires a list of users and their contact information, it becomes a daily problem which destroys efficiency. at the very least, allow us to paste them without formatting using cmd+shift+V or something.
User: +1(0000) for me too. This is honestly driving me insane guys. Please just give us an option to paste without formatting, or perhaps stick it in the preferences to turn off hyperlinks on paste? They‚Äôre not necessary.
Summary: Users are frustrated with Figma's automatic formatting of pasted email addresses as links, which disrupts their workflow when creating prototypes with multiple email addresses. They request an option to paste without formatting or disable hyperlinks on paste for improved efficiency.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

User: Figma Jam's customizable templates and intuitive interface make it easy for me to unleash my creativity and explore new ideas in a structured, collaborative environment.

Summary: Users appreciate Figma Jam's customizable templates and intuitive interface, which make it easy to explore new ideas in a collaborative environment. However, being an internet-dependent tool, some users may experience latency or connectivity issues that can hinder collaboration.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üîÅ Iterate, improve and grow. Be open to change and adapt to your audience's needs. Remember, building a business is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìà Track your progress and celebrate your wins! Set measurable goals, analyze your metrics, and appreciate your achievements. This is your journey and every small victory matters!
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

Text:
User: Our iOS developers rely on PDF export in order to grab assets for mobile development. Without being able to export PDF from slices, it requires additional and tedious workarounds for how to export assets.
I‚Äôd like to request PDF export from slices.
User: Its really a heartbreaker that exporting the slices to pdf is not available in Figma. Sketch has it and it was working really great for us.
Some of our multinational stakeholders, whom we cannot insist to install or start an account for Figma or anything else, as they rely on pdf documents for design review or sharing with internal team. Sketch helped to convert the slices to pdf which was very light weight and compressible. When we moved to figma, the internal team as well few clients worked well with figma collaboration (same we did with Sketch too) and but the later ones didn‚Äôt. And now we are forced to go back to Sketch, as we understand that its the app that we could rely to accomplish all our requirements.
User: Thanks for the feedback! We‚Äôve merged your topic with an existing feature request, so we can measure interest from the community.
Summary: User is frustrated with the lack of PDF export from slices in Figma, as it requires additional workarounds for exporting assets. They also mention that exporting PDF from slices is not available in Sketch, which helped them with their mobile development needs. The user mentions that their multinational stakeholders prefer using PDF for design review and sharing with internal team. They also mention that Figma collaboration is not working well with their internal team, and they are forced to revert to Sketch for their needs.

User: I want to love this app so badly, I spent truly all day playing around trying to make it work for me. I watched so many tutorials. But the fact of the matter is its a bad app for iPad. I can‚Äôt afford a real computer so I have to use an iPad instead, and I‚Äôm not alone in this, so I do feel that Notion should be prioritizing this more than they are (and it seems this has been ongoing according to Reddit).
Some issues I‚Äôve faced on iPad:
-Nearly impossible to click and drag blocks successfully and smoothly.
-You can‚Äôt select multiple blocks at the same time.
-I‚Äôve read about and really wanted to use the ‚Äúrepeat‚Äù feature, which is nowhere to be found on the iPad.
Notion marketing team, if you‚Äôre reading this: PLEASE test your app on an iPad and fix it, I‚Äôm desperate to love your app!!!!
Summary: User loves the app but finds it difficult to use on iPad due to issues with clicking and dragging blocks, inability to select multiple blocks, and the lack of the "repeat" feature. They suggest prioritizing the app's development for iPad users and request that the Notion marketing team test the app on an iPad.

Text: User: I love to use the desktop or web apps, so I had high hopes for the iPad version...but no, it's just not even usable. For example, to add a title, normally you use a slash...here, you use the slash, you see the menu with options pop up (you can't continue to type what you need), and then it disappears. Eventually you see that there's a completely different menu which pops up at the bottom, why? Then this menu is also buggy, and doesn't always appear when needed. Also the move page option doesn't seem to work, and there's no way to archive, and so on. The app comes with prefilled project templates with example data that you can't delete. You can't be productive, it's just frustrating.
Summary: User finds the iPad version of Notion unusable due to its lack of usability and bugs, as well as the inability to archive and delete project templates. They suggest using the desktop or web apps instead.

Text:
User: FigJam lets me, my all-remote team, and our stakeholders quickly and easily collaborate to collect and organize ideas. It's incredibly simple and works well for people of all technical skillsets. I use it for hours every day.
User: FigJam is simple and flexible -- my team and I have used it for everything from workflow diagramming to stakeholder workshops on product vision. We've also trained non-designers to use the tool in under 2 minutes. They love it and even use it when we aren't around!
User: The ability to collaborate with non-authenticated users is incredible, but resetting the 24-hour timer is a bit tedious. I understand there has to be some inconvenience to push for more paid accounts, but I wish there was a way to extend those timers. I also wish there was a "vertical alignment" option in the menu bar for moving text to the top or bottom of shapes (in addition to horizontal alignment). But other than small feature requests like this, I have no complaints!
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam for its simplicity, flexibility, and ease of collaboration with remote teams and stakeholders. They find it useful for various tasks, including workflow diagramming and product vision workshops. However, they suggest improvements such as extending the 24-hour timer for non-authenticated users and adding a vertical alignment option for text within shapes.

Text:
User: This app worked fine as a free user, however after becoming a subscribed member, I ran into some annoying and suspicious issues. I wanted to utilize the AI to see where the limits were and then to eventually use it for academic and creative purposes. Of course, there‚Äôs a limit to free uses so I subscribed to a month to see how often I would have to use this and if it was really worth paying for longer. I paid $4.99 for the one month subscription, but it won‚Äôt actually let me use the AI and instead tells me that I need to subscribe, but I already have. The receipt is in my email as proof that I did pay.
My app says I am a subscribed member, so why is it denying me member benefits? I have tried many things to fix this including restarting my phone, restarting the app, deleting and downloading the app again, logging out and then back in etc. Nothing has worked so far. Not only do I feel robbed, but it almost feels intentional because when I tried to use the AI before paying for a subscription, I would only get a message saying that I have run out of free uses, but after subscribing, it sends me straight to the subscription choice page. That gives the impression that the app is purposely not letting me use the AI program even though I have paid for it, regardless of if that is actually the case or not. Looking through some of the other lower reviews, I am not the only one who has ran into this problem. Please fix this because it is frustrating to not be able to use what I paid for.
Summary: I paid for premium, but the app isn‚Äôt letting me actually use premium benefits.
Thank you, Frustrated Notion User
Summary: User purchased a paid subscription but is unable to use the application due to functionality not working. They are unable to use the AI features and are concerned about the money being debited.

Summary: The product is helping users by providing easier collaboration for remote teams, as well as giving them oversight on work and the ability to document in a single location, which increases visibility and engagement amongst team members. Users appreciate the product's oversight for projects, its intuitive design, and its ability to integrate other apps and features. Users experience fatigue when zooming in and out, and find it difficult to create visuals and diagrams that are interactive. They also find it difficult to copy and paste elements from other sources into Miro, and wish they could consolidate their personal and work accounts.

A user shared their daily tech stack for their freelance design business, which includes Todoist, Notion, Clockify, SumUp, Typefully, Miro, Figma, Slack, Gmail, and Google Calendar. Another user asked why they chose these apps and shared their own tech stack.

Text:
User: The company I work at has little to no documentation regarding processes and strategy. With Miro I can easily create the first draft of a diagram/process and quickly add guests to collaborate and have a final version within 1 or 2 sessions of online collaboration. 
Additionally, Miro has helped me shift my problem-solving methodology from pen and paper and prose to visually abstracting the problem in a way that is easier, and more efficient, for my brain to process.
User: The tool's ease of use, the number and diversity of templates and the resources available for support. Creating visually stunning yet simple graphics is incredibly easy. As I began to use Miro more and more frequently in my workflow, my way of thinking and solving problems has shifted to be more visual ‚Äì¬†I am able to abstract my problems and express them on the screen in a powerful way.
User: I wish Miro had better tools to create, modify and import vector graphics. With its current set of tools it's cumbersome to create vector graphics and text, that would take seconds to make with the right set of tools.
Summary: The user appreciates the ease of use, versatility, and flexibility of Miro, which has helped them shift their problem-solving methodology from pen and paper to visual abstracting. They also wish for better tools for creating, modifying, and importing vector graphics.

User: Perhaps the only thing that would change is the possibility of adding more colors than those suggested to try different palettes. And if you can continue adding plugins that would be great because I use them all
Summary: Users find FigJam easy to use for diagramming workflows and processes, and appreciate its seamless collaboration features for both internal and external stakeholders. However, they note some limitations in shape and color choices when building out flows.

User: I love the new feature that allows multiple prototypes per page. One issue I‚Äôm having with it, is it assumes I want everything to be a new flow starting point each time I don‚Äôt link something from the first flow starting page.
It has a very linear mindset. When I work/prototype I tend to work on a section, then link it back and that creates many flow starting points on accident and I have to delete them.
It‚Äôd be nice if either - it only created the first one, and doesn‚Äôt assume you want many or there‚Äôs some kinda preference/setting where I can turn it off.
Do other people delete starting points or have work arounds? Or is there a preference/setting I‚Äôm missing where I can turn it off?
User: Please turn off auto creating Flow Points. I‚Äôve always hated it and annoyed I have to go hunt for the Flow Point to delete it so I can navigate via keyboard arrow keys.
Summary: User loves the new feature for multiple prototypes per page but finds it annoying as it creates multiple starting points without their intention. They request to turn off the auto-creation of Flow Points, as it's a hassle to delete them and navigate via keyboard arrow keys.

Text: User: This app worked fine as a free user, however after becoming a subscribed member, I ran into some annoying and suspicious issues. I wanted to utilize the AI to see where the limits were and then to eventually use it for academic and creative purposes. Of course, there‚Äôs a limit to free uses so I subscribed to a month to see how often I would have to use this and if it was really worth paying for longer. I paid $4.99 for the one month subscription, but it won‚Äôt actually let me use the AI and instead tells me that I need to subscribe, but I already have. The receipt is in my email as proof that I did pay. My app says I am a subscribed member, so why is it denying me member benefits? I have tried many things to fix this including restarting my phone, restarting the app, deleting and downloading the app again, logging out and then back in etc. Nothing has worked so far. Not only do I feel robbed, but it almost feels intentional because when I tried to use the AI before paying for a subscription, I would only get a message saying that I have run out of free uses, but after subscribing, it sends me straight to the subscription choice page. That gives the impression that the app is purposely not letting me use the AI program even though I have paid for it, regardless of if that is actually the case or not. Looking through some of the other lower reviews, I am not the only one who has ran into this problem. Please fix this because it is frustrating to not be able to use what I paid for. Summary: I paid for premium, but the app isn‚Äôt letting me actually use premium benefits. Thank you, Frustrated Notion User
Summary: User purchased a paid subscription but is unable to use the application due to functionality not working. They are unable to use the AI features and are concerned about the money being debited.

Text:
User: Hi all, I am working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from our team library. Through research I think the way is to first use Figma REST API to get the keys of styles from our library file, and the use figma.importStyleByKeyAsync() to import the style. However, the issue is, this requires me to put my Access token in the plugin, and I don‚Äôt want to. Is there a way for plugin to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin?
Or are there any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin? Thanks a lot!!!
User: You have several ways:
Users will create their own personal access tokens, which will be inserted into the input field of your plugin.
Users will open the necessary library files, run the plugin there to get the necessary keys, return to another file to continue working.
Hardcode the keys in the plugin.
3.1. Or add these keys to, for example, a JSON file that you or anyone else can keep updating as needed.
Summary: The user is working on a Figma plugin that needs to import style from their team library. They are looking for a way to authenticate when making REST API calls on behalf of the person who uses the plugin, or any other easier ways to import/access styles from team library file in plugin.

User: I‚Äôve been working on this project but while making the dropdown menu I ran into an issue.
It seems like when the dropdown menu opens it is good but when I tried to do the prototyping to close it, I ran into some issues.
Here is what i did
Screenshot 2023-05-<PHONE_NUMBER>√ó231 32.1 KB
Everything seemed good but when I tried to preview it, it would keep opening and closing rapidly as I moved my mouse over the selected navigation title ‚ÄúShop‚Äù
Here is the link to the file (<STRICT_LINK>)
Thanks for the help guys!
User: Hi there,
So, I guess what‚Äôs happening is that the prototype gets stuck between a situation where it‚Äôs opening an overlay because the mouse is on ‚ÄúShop‚Äù, and also closing the overlay because if the mouse has left ‚ÄúShop‚Äù then it should close. This is why it seems to flicker. To fix this, I‚Äôd recommend using interactive components instead of the Overlay feature. An example of what I‚Äôm talking about is in the community file.
Hope this helps!
User: Hey Gayani,
This helped a lot with the issue but it started another one . So now the issue is that the dropdown now will not close after the mouse is off of it and the navigation title moves up with the dropdown making it disappear from the screen. I copied pretty much everything from the figma file you sent me and tried to fix it but couldn‚Äôt find a solution.
image1528√ó235 55 KB
Summary: User faced an issue with a dropdown menu in Figma, where it rapidly opened and closed during preview. Another user suggested that the issue might be due to the prototype getting stuck between opening and closing the overlay, and recommended using interactive components instead of the Overlay feature to fix the problem.

User: 
Styles1024√ó1024 51.3 KB
When publishing a library I have to uncheck styles that are not meant to be published, and I have to do it every time I publish. Sometimes I accidentally publish styles that were meant to help speed up my work within a file, but that were not meant to be a part of the library. It would be helpful to have an option similar to what I‚Äôve added in the mock-up above. I‚Äôd like to be able to toggle whether or not a style is meant to be a published style.
On a similar note, it would be helpful not only to see which items have changed in the library when I publish, but also what has changed specifically about those items.
User: Thanks for the feedback! We‚Äôll pass this onto our team for consideration.
Summary: User suggests adding a toggle option for styles in Figma to control whether they should be published or not, as they sometimes accidentally publish styles meant for internal use only. They also request a feature to show specific changes in items when publishing a library.

Text:
User: FigJam fills the role of a handful of tools we were previously using across the business. We were able to consolidate and say this is the true, approved tool across the company. It's helped teams align and ensure access across the company via single sign on. The access issues we had previously with InVision/Freehand, Miro, etc. are long gone. No more requesting to view or edit access!
User: Anyone can get in there and start using it. It's pretty intuitive and we use it all the time across many teams to collaborate, brainstorm, plan, whiteboard, etc. We also switched to using FigJam for all team retros in the company. All the templates, timer, stickers, music, and more make FigJam fun to use - but not in a way that distracts from the work.
User: I don't dislike the tool at all. I will say one pain point we ran into is that there currently isn't a way to use stickies while maintaining anonymity. Anyone can go click an icon to toggle the original authors name off and on to see who said it ‚Äì not ideal for retros BUT our account rep taught us to switch to shapes and we no longer have this problem. Would be nice to have a retro setting on a FigJam that would preserve the psychological safety of team members. We feel extremely supported by our awesome account rep.
Summary: The user appreciates Figma and FigJam as a one-stop shop for design and mind mapping, praising its ease of use, stability, and reasonable cost. However, they suggest improving the sharing process, as team account users can currently add editors and charge licenses to the organization, with restrictions requiring an enterprise plan upgrade and increased cost.

Text:
User: Think it's impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience? Think again! I did it, and here's how I did it to earn my first dollars here (üéÅ a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet): <STRICT_LINK>
User: Before we begin:
When I won +$2500 here.
- I had an audience of 500 followers
- I didn't know how to code
- I didn't know anything about Twitter
I did.
So did you.
Now here's how I did it üëá
User: üí° First, you need a brilliant idea. It doesn't have to be groundbreaking, just something you're passionate about. Remember, you're building this solo, so you'll need that passion to fuel your journey.
User: üõ†Ô∏è Once you have your idea, it's time to build without coding! I used @webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge. It's incredibly user-friendly, with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business.
User: @webflow üß† Organize your thoughts and plan your content using @NotionHQ. As a solopreneur, I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks, jotting down ideas, and creating content outlines. Plus, it's super easy to use!
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üéØ Find your niche and target audience. You don't need a massive audience to succeed‚Äîjust a group of dedicated, engaged followers who love your work. Focus on connecting with them and providing value.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ üó£Ô∏è Share your work and gather feedback. Join communities like @IndieHackers, @ProductHunt, and relevant Facebook groups to find like-minded people who can give you insights and encouragement.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üíº Set up a business model that works for you. From subscriptions and memberships to one-time purchases, find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audience's needs.
User: @webflow @NotionHQ @IndieHackers @ProductHunt üìö Educate yourself! Attend webinars, read articles, and listen to podcasts to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and strategies. You don't need a formal education to succeed, just a curious mind!
Summary: User is excited to join the Notion Creator community and share their ideas with others.

Text:
User: Miro solves the issue of having an online space to do all things idea generation + organisation. The interface keeps it simple with the toolbar so you don't get bogged down by the full functionality, but it's there if you need the extra help with structuring information (eg. using templates)
User: Miro is a great platform for brainstorming and idea generation. I use it frequently at work for workshops, as the live collaboration tools make it easy to present and gather feedback. 
 
I like using the sticky notes to structure sections and cluster ideas together. This especially comes in handy when taking notes / synthesising research!
User: - Formatting (bullet points) 
- Image/object alignment 
- Connecting lines between shapes can be clunky/limiting
Summary: Users appreciate Miro for its simple interface and online space for idea generation and organization. They find it useful for workshops and live collaboration, particularly using sticky notes for structuring sections and clustering ideas. However, they mention some limitations in formatting, image/object alignment, and connecting lines between shapes.

User: I'm a copywriter, and using Figma was a big learning curve for me to work with my company's designers. FigJam, on the other hand, was super easy to learn. I use it for even the simplest things like group brainstorming sessions and just mapping out my thoughts. I would say that it's a key tool in our team.
User: I can't say that I have a specific problem with FigJam. It's a great tool. I guess my only callout would be that I'd like to have more features. It's easy to use but I'm sure there are additional features you could add to make it more fun and interactive.
Summary: Users appreciate FigJam for its ease of use, especially for copywriters who need a visual way to organize their thoughts. It has become a key tool for team brainstorming sessions. However, some users would like to see more features added to make it more fun and interactive.

User: Sometimes you want to preserve links to the data and be able to automatically update. 
This is not a strength of the platform as generally speaking the data become separate from the source when pulled in.
Summary: Users appreciate Miro's flexibility, functionality, and ability to visually communicate inefficiencies to internal clients. They also enjoy the collaboration features. However, they find copying graphics between boards frustrating, as it doesn't always maintain the original formatting.

Text:
User: üöÄ How to turn an ‚Äûalmost perfect‚Äù UI/UX to ‚Äûperfect‚Äù.
Using <STRICT_LINK> as a perfect example (created by @cnnr_cllhn) <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn LoseTheVery is a fantastic tool that finds a more ‚Äûconcise‚Äù adjective without using ‚Äûvery‚Äù. Example: very rich = affluent.
The core idea is simple and the UI was chosen to reflect that .It's straight to the point (just like the Google Search homepage). So what's the problem? <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn ‚ùå There are 3 main flaws:
1. Site feels messy
2. Design lacks consistency
3. Elements feel a little too cramped
We'll approach it ‚Äûvia negativa‚Äù style: by removing stuff rather than adding.
üë©üé® Let's work on that that using @figma
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 1Ô∏è‚É£: Decluttering üßπ
The most important step would be to remove the clutter ‚Äì the annoying newsletter popup, the newsletter section and the newsletter banner. We'll get back to it later.
This has already made a difference. The interface looks significantly cleaner. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 2Ô∏è‚É£: Let the design breathe üí®
Let's add more whitespace ‚Äì the more the better. This will achieve a better visual separation.
Now the `very + x = y` line instantly grabs our attention. <STRICT_LINK>
User: @cnnr_cllhn @figma 3Ô∏è‚É£: Making buttons prettier üíÑ
Buttons look chaotic here: randomly spaced, different padding, etc.
Let's increase the font size, adjust the padding and replace the word ‚Äûrandom‚Äù with a dice icon. We'll also ‚Äûinvert‚Äù the third button.
The buttons now look modern and consistent. <STRICT_LINK>
Summary: A user discussed how to improve the UI/UX of a website called LoseTheVery, which helps find concise adjectives. They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

Text: User: I‚Äôve been using Notion for a couple of years and it‚Äôs one of the easiest and most comprehensive applications to use for note-taking on MacBooks. Recently I‚Äôve switched to an iPad and the functionality has drastically deteriorated in my user experience which is concerning as the iPad is usually touted as a functional productivity device, especially to students for notes. The app often glitches, the toolbar at the bottom for editing font often disappears while working on multiple tabs, sometimes font colours don‚Äôt show up on screen even after multiple tries. There‚Äôs difficulty in moving blocks of text around on the screen for re-ordering sometimes, especially when working with stage manager in the smallest pre-set window.
Summary: User experienced issues with Notion on their iPad, such as glitches, disappearing toolbar, and difficulty in moving blocks of text around. They mentioned that the app is not as functional as it was on their MacBooks.

Text:
User: If I apply a color style to an object as a fill (or stroke), I can‚Äôt apply any additional fills to that object. I also can‚Äôt change the opacity of that fill when it‚Äôs tied to a style.
Example: I have a button that is a frame with a blue background which is tied to a color style. I want to create a hover effect for that button by adding an additional 10% black fill on top of my blue color. Currently to accomplish this, I have to detach the blue from it‚Äôs color style, then add an additional fill black on top of it and reduce the 2nd fill‚Äôs opacity to 10%. See example screenshots below.
This not only breaks my blue color style, but if I have black as a style in my design system, I can‚Äôt use that color style either.
Has anyone found a workaround for this that I‚Äôm missing?
Screen Shot 2021-04-16 at 9.09.39 AM2420√ó760 67.2 KB
Screen Shot 2021-04-16 at 9.09.58 AM2438√ó810 67.6 KB

User: need this +1
Summary: User is unable to apply multiple color styles or adjust opacity for fills and strokes in Figma, and seeks a workaround for creating hover effects without detaching color styles. Another user expresses agreement with the issue.
